Title: IBM AIX Buffer Overflow in 'swcons' Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can trigger a buffer overflow in 'swcons' to execute arbitrary code on the target system.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
IBM has issued a fix (APAR IY94901).

The IBM advisory is available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY94901

Title: Solaris TCP Subsystem Race Condition Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can trigger a race condition in the TCP subsystem to cause a kernel panic.  The flaw can be triggered under high traffic load.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can cause a system panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 119998-01 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 119999-01 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102796-1

Title: HP-UX SLSd Bug Lets Remote Users Gain Root Access
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX running SLSd.  A remote user can gain root access on the target system.
A remote user can exploit SLSd to create arbitrary files and gain root access.

HP credits iDefense with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can create files on the target system to gain root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor advises users to disable SLSd:

   1. Run "/sbin/init.d/slsd stop".
   2. Edit /etc/rc.config.d/slsd and set "SLSD_DAEMON=0"

The HP advisory is available at:

http://www1.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00862809

Title: HP-UX ARPA Transport Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX running ARPA Transport.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
No details were provided.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
HP has issued patches, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

HP-UX B.11.11 - PHNE_35183 or subsequent
HP-UX B.11.23 - PHNE_35182 or subsequent 

The HP advisory is available at:

http://www1.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00863839

Title: IBM AIX Buffer Overflows in rsh, rcp, rlogin, and rdist Commands Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
A local user can trigger a buffer overflow in various r-commands to execute arbitrary code on the target system with root privileges.

The rsh, rcp, rlogin, and rdist commands are affected.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued an interim fix, available at:

ftp://aix.software.ibm.com/aix/efixes/security/rcmds_ifix.tar.Z

The vendor plans to issue the following fixes:

      APAR number for AIX 5.2.0:  IY94368 (available approx. 03/21/07)
      APAR number for AIX 5.3.0:  IY94301 (available approx. 03/07/07)

Title: HP Tru64 UNIX ps Command Discloses Environment Variables to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the 'ps' utility on HP Tru64.  A local user can view environment variable values.
A local user can invoke the '/usr/ucb/ps' command to view the values of environment variables of all processes on the target system.

The vendor has been notified.

A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://rawlab.mindcreations.com/codes/exp/nix/osf1tru64ps.ksh

Andrea "bunker" Purificato reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can view the values of environment variables of all processes on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: AIX Buffer Overflow in RDIST Command May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in AIX.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can invoke the rdist command to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the target system with unspecified set user ID (setuid) privileges.

The vulnerability resides in 'bos.rte.libc'.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain unspecified elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (APAR IY94301).

The IBM advisory is available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY94301

Title: Solaris Loopback FileSystem Lets Local Users Move or Rename Read-only Files
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Solaris Loopback FileSystem.  A local user can move or rename read-only files, causing denial of service conditions.
A local user within a non-global zone can move or rename files on a read-only mounted loopback file system.  If the filesystem is shared with the global zone, the files can be moved, renamed, or removed from the global zone.

This can cause denial of service conditions for the non-global zone and the global zone.

Only systems that have non-global zones configured with the read-only LOFS root filesystem using the root filesystem of the global zone as the underlying filesystem are affected.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user within a non-global zone can move or rename files on a read-only mounted loopback file system, causing denial of service conditions.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-28 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-28 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102699-1

Title: Solaris ICMP Echo Packet Processing Error Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a specially crafted ICMP echo packet to trigger a kernel panic on the target system.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-28 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-28 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102697-1

Title: Mac OS X CFUserNotification() Function Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
A local user can call the CFUserNotificationSendRequest() function to cause the UserNotificationCenter.app application to launch with wheel privileges.  If a malicious InputManager resides in '~/Library/InputManagers', the malicious code will be run with wheel privileges.  The malicious code can invoke diskutil and exploit a wheel-writable setuid binary to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

匿名, KF, and LMH discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://projects.info-pull.com/moab/MOAB-22-01-2007.html
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Mac OS X shared_region_map_file_np() Memory Corruption Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can supply a specially carfted argument to the shared_region_map_file_np() function to consume excessive memory on the target system.

Adriano Lima discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Apple Service Location Protocol Daemon (slpd) Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in slpd on Mac OS X.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can supply a registration request with a specially crafted attr-list field to trigger a buffer overflow to potentially execute arbitrary code on the target system with root level privileges.

The local user can also cause denial of service conditions.

KF discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://projects.info-pull.com/moab/MOAB-17-01-2007.html
Impact':
A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.

A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: HP-UX IPFilter Bug Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Version(s): HP-UX B.11.23 running IPFilter with PHNE_34474 installed.
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
HP-UX systems running IPFilter in combination with PHNE_34474 are affected.  No details have been provided.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
HP has issued a fix (PHNE_35766 or subsequent), available at:

http://itrc.hp.com/

The HP advisory is available at:

http://www1.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00837319

Title: OpenBSD ICMP6 Echo Request Bug Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenBSD.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a specially crafted ICMP6 echo request to cause the kernel to enter an infinite loop.
Impact': A remote user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
OpenBSD has issued the following patches:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/4.0/common/008_icmp6.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.9/common/018_icmp6.patch

Title: Mac OS X Heap Overflow in AppleTalk _ATPsndrsp() Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send specially crafted data to trigger a heap overflow in the _ATPsndrsp() function and cause a kernel panic.

It may also be possible to execute arbitrary code on the target system.  However, the report did not confirm remote code execution.

LMH discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory and demonstration exploit is available at:

http://projects.info-pull.com/moab/MOAB-14-01-2007.html
Impact': A remote user can cause a kernel panic on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: FreeBSD Kernel jail(2) Call Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges in Certain Cases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD Kernel in the jail(2) system call.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system in certain cases.
The jail rc.d(8) script does not properly validate paths to check for symbolic links before using the path when writing output from the jail start-up to '/var/log/console.log' and when mounting and unmounting file systems within the jail directory structure.

A local root-level user within the jail can create a symbolic link from a file on the system (outside of the jail) to '/var/log/console.log' inside the jail to overwrite files on the target system located outside of the jail.  This allows the user to execute arbitrary commands with non-jailed superuser privileges.

A local root-level user can also mount or unmount file systems intended to be mounted within the jail at arbitrary points outside of the jail.

This can be exploited when the jail rc.d(8) script is used to start and stop jails.

Dirk Engling reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local root-level user can access files located outside of the jail and execute arbitrary commands on the target system.
Solution:
FreeBSD has issued a fix and has provided the following solution instructions [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 5-STABLE, or 6-STABLE, or to the
RELENG_6_1, RELENG_6_0, or RELENG_5_5 security branch dated after the
correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5.5, 6.0,
and 6.1 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 5.5]
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-07:01/jail5.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-07:01/jail5.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 6.0]
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-07:01/jail60.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-07:01/jail60.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 6.1]
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-07:01/jail61.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-07:01/jail61.patch.asc

NOTE: The patch distributed at the time of the original advisory was
incorrect for FreeBSD 5.5 (both RELENG_5 and RELENG_5_5).  Systems to
which the original patch was applied should be patched with the
following corrective patch, which contains only the changes between
the original and updated patch:

# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-07:01/jail5-correction.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-07:01/jail5-correction.patch.asc

b) Execute the following commands as root:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch
# install -o root -g wheel -m 555 etc/rc.d/jail /etc/rc.d

The FreeBSD advisory is available at:

http://security.FreeBSD.org/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-07:01.jail.asc

Title: OpenBSD Kernel Input Validation Flaw in vga() Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenBSD Kernel.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
If the kernel is compiled with the PCIAGP option but the actual device is not an AGP device, then a local user can exploit an input validation flaw in vga(4) to obtain root privileges.

Only i386-based systems are affected.

Ilja van Sprundel discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
OpenBSD has issued a fix, available at:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/4.0/i386/007_agp.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.9/i386/017_agp.patch

Title: (Solaris Issues Fix for Solaris WAN Boot) OpenSSL RSA Signatures Can Be Forged
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenSSL.  A remote user may be able to forge certain digital signatures.  Solaris WAN Boot is affected.
If an RSA key with exponent 3 is used, a remote user may be able to forge a PKCS #1 v1.5 signature for that key.

Software that uses PKCS #1 v1.5 may be affected.  Software that uses OpenSSL to verify X.509 certificates may also be affected.

Daniel Bleichenbacher reported the type of attack that is possible against PKCS #1 v1.5 signatures.
Impact': A remote user may be able to forge signatures (and certificates).
Solution:
Sun has issued a fix for Solaris WAN Boot, which is affected by this OpenSSL vulnerability.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 121229-02 or later

Note: Systems with the SUNWcry package installed should also install patch 118562-13.

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 121230-02 or later

Note: Systems with the SUNWcry package installed should also install patch 118563-13

Sun is working on a fix for Solaris 9.

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102759-1

Title: Sun Solaris ld.so.1 Bugs Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
Two vulnerabilities were reported in Sun Solaris in ld.so.1.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
A local user can trigger a stack overflow in the doprf() function and an input validation flaw in processing the LANG parameter when processing errors to execute arbitrary code on the target system with root privileges.

Sean Larsson of iDefense Labs discovered the buffer overflow vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 109147-42 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 112963-27 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 109148-41 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 113986-22 or later

A final resolution for Solaris 10 is pending completion.

For Solaris 10, Interim Security Relief (ISRs) are available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/tpatches

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 IDR124828-01

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 IDR124829-01

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102724-1

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Fix) BSD FireWire Driver fw_ioctl() Integer Signedness Error Lets Local Users Read Kernel Memory
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FireWire Driver on several BSD-based systems.  A local user can view kernel memory contents on the target system.
A local user can supply a specially crafted FW_GCROM ioctl with a negative value for crom_buf->len to read kernel memory contents.

The vulnerability resides in 'dev/firewire/fwdev.c'.

Several BSD-based kernels are affected, including DragonFlyBSD, FreeBSD 5.5, MidnightBSD, NetBSD, and TrustedBSD.

Filipe Balestra and Rodrigo Rubira Branco discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.kernelhacking.com/bsdadv1.txt
Impact': A local user can view kernel memory on the target system.
Solution:
FreeBSD has released a fix and has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE, 5-STABLE, or 6-STABLE,
or to the RELENG_6_1, RELENG_6_0, RELENG_5_5, or RELENG_4_11 security
branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.11, 5.5,
6.0, and 6.1 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:25/kmem.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:25/kmem.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in
<URL:http://www.FreeBSD.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the
system.

The FreeBSD advisory is available at:

http://security.FreeBSD.org/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:25.kmem.asc

Title: BSD FireWire Driver fw_ioctl() Integer Signedness Error Lets Local Users Read Kernel Memory
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FireWire Driver on several BSD-based systems.  A local user can view kernel memory contents on the target system.
A local user can supply a specially crafted FW_GCROM ioctl with a negative value for crom_buf->len to read kernel memory contents.

The vulnerability resides in 'dev/firewire/fwdev.c'.

Several BSD-based kernels are affected, including DragonFlyBSD, FreeBSD 5.5, MidnightBSD, NetBSD, and TrustedBSD.

Filipe Balestra and Rodrigo Rubira Branco discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.kernelhacking.com/bsdadv1.txt
Impact': A local user can view kernel memory on the target system.
Solution: Individual kernel vendors will issue fixes for their distributions.

Title: Apple AirPort Extreme Beacon Frame Processing Bug Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in AirPort Extreme.  A remote user on the wireless network can cause denial of service conditions.
The Apple AirPort Extreme driver does not properly process certain beacon frames.  A remote user on the wireless network can send specially crafted beacon frames to trigger an out-of-bounds memory access on the target system, resulting in a kernel panic.

LMH discovered this vulnerability.

The vendor was notified on November 25, 2006.

The original advisory is available at:

http://projects.info-pull.com/mokb/MOKB-30-11-2006.html
Impact': A remote user on the wireless network can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a revised fix (AirPort Extreme Update 2007-002), available via Software Update preferences, or from Apple Downloads at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

The original fix (AirPort Extreme Update 2007-001) provides the same security protections as the revised fix.  However, the revised fix includes an additional non-security fix for a compatibility issue with third-party access points that use WEP.

The Apple advisory is available at:

http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=305031

Title: Solaris SIGKILL/PCAGENT Race Condition Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A local user can cause a kernel panic.
A local user can exploit a race condition in the Solaris kernel between the SIGKILL and /proc PCAGENT signals to panic the system.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patches 117350-40 or later, 123703-01 or later and 116959-15 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patches 118558-30 or later, 117125-03 or later, 121316-02 or later and 113278-14 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patches 120661-03 or later and 118822-19 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patches 117351-40 or later, 123704-01 or later and 116960-15 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patches 118559-30 or later, 120884-02 or later, 121317-02 or later and 119439-06 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patches 120662-04 or later and 118844-19 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102574-1

Title: Mac OS X shared_region_make_private_np() Memory Error Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X.  A local user can obtain system privileges on the target system.
A local user can supply specially crafted input to the shared_region_make_private_np() system call to trigger a memory corruption error and execute arbitrary commands  with system privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions.

LMH discovered this vulnerability.

A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://projects.info-pull.com/mokb/bug-files/MOKB-28-11-2006.c

The original advisory is available at:

http://projects.info-pull.com/mokb/MOKB-28-11-2006.html
Impact': A local user can obtain system privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix (Mac OS X v10.4.9 and Security Update 2007-003), available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Mac OS X Components Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges and Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in Mac OS X.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.  A local user can obtain system privileges on the target system.
A local user can create a specially crafted '.DS_Store' file in a directory.  When the target user browses the directory with Finder, a heap overflow will occur and arbitrary code executed with the privileges of the target user [CVE-2006-4402].

The Installer incorrectly allows system privileges to be used by Admin users when installing certain packages without explicitly requiring authentication [CVE-2006-4404].

The VPN server may execute commands without properly initializing the environment [CVE-2006-4411].  A local user may be able to create files or execute commands with system privileges.

A remote user can create specially crafted HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will cause WebKit to access a previously deallocated object [CVE-2006-4412].  This may cause arbitrary code to be executed with the privileges of the target user.

Tom Ferris of Security-Protocols reported the WebKit vulnerability.
Impact':
A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.

A local user can obtain system privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-007, available via the Software Update pane in System Preferences or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

Title: Apple CFNetwork Lets Remote Users Inject FTP Commands
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple CFNetwork.  A remote user can cause arbitrary FTP commands to be executed.
A remote user can create a specially crafted FTP URI that, when loaded by the target user, will cause arbitrary FTP commands to be executed by the target user on an arbitrary FTP server.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary FTP commands to be executed.
Solution:

Title: Mac OS X Apple Type Services Lets Local Users Gain System Privileges and Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X Apple Type Services.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.  A local user can obtain system privileges on the target system.
The server creates log files insecurely [CVE-2006-4396].  A local user can overwrite or create files with system privileges.

A local user can send a specially crafted service request to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code with system privileges [CVE-2006-4398].  Mac OS X versions prior to 10.4 are not affected.

A remote user can create a specially crafted font file that, when loaded by the target user, will trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the target system [CVE-2006-4400].  The code will run with system privileges.  This vulnerability can be triggered when opened or previewed in Finder.
Impact':
A remote user can create a font file that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.

A local user can obtain system privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-007, available via the Software Update pane in System Preferences or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Mac OS X Security Framework May Use Weaker or No Encryption, Fail to Check CRLs, and Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X Security Framework.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Apple Secure Transport may fail to use encryption or authentication in certain cases [CVE-2006-4407].  Mac OS X versions 10.4.8 and later with Security Update 2006-006 are not affected.  Eric Cronin of gizmolabs reported this vulnerability.  Applications (such as Safari) that use Secure Transport via CFNetwork are not affected.

A user can create an X.509 certificate with a specially crafted public key that, when processed by the system, will cause excessive system resources to be consumed while verifying the signature [CVE-2006-4408].  Mac OS X versions prior to 10.4 are not affected.  Dr. Stephen N. Henson of Open Network Security and NISCC reported this vulnerability.

The Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) service may be unable to retrieve certificate revocation lists when the system is configured to use an HTTP proxy [CVE-2006-4409].  Mac OS X versions prior to 10.4 are not affected.  Timothy J. Miller of the MITRE Corporation reported this vulnerability.

For certain leaf certificates, the system may not check a revocation list [CVE-2006-4410].  Mac OS X versions 10.4.7 and later are not affected.  Jose Nazario of Arbor Networks reported this vulnerability.
Impact':
A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.

The system may fail to use encryption or authentication in certain cases.

The system may fail to retrieve check certificate revocation lists.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-007, available via the Software Update pane in System Preferences or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.3.9
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2006-007Pan.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  b4c9190964cf4f9f674ab7f8cbd2c1cbe196cb2d

Title: (NetBSD Issues Fix) BSD UNIX systrace STRIOCREPLACE Integer Overflow Lets Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in BSD UNIX systrace().  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can trigger an integer overflow to cause denial of service conditions, read from kernel memory, or obtain elevated privileges on the target system.

Chris Evans of the Google Security Team discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
NetBSD has released a kernel fix for NetBSD, which is affected by this vulnerability.

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

  ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-024.txt.asc

Title: NetBSD Kernel Bugs Let Local Users Consume Sockets or Cause a Kernel Panic
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can cause resource leaks or a kernel panic due to several vulnerabilities in the kernel code.

A local user can supply a specially crafted 'name' or 'namelen' parameter to the accept(2) function to leave a dangling socket.  If a copyout(9) call subsequently fails, the socket may remain in the CLOSE_WAIT state.

The sendmsg(2) function does not properly validate the user supply 'msg_controllen' parameter to the sendit() function.  A local user can cause a kernel panic.  Only 64-bit architectures (e.g., amd64, sparc64, and alpha) are affected.

A local user can attempt to read '/emul/linux/proc/0/stat' on a procfs file system mounted with the 'linux' option to cause a NULL dereference, resulting in a kernel panic.

Sean Boudreau discovered the dangling socket vulnerability.  Ryo Shimizu discovered the sendmsg(2) kernel panic vulnerability.  Nicolas Joly discovered the mount_procfs kernel panic vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed kernel.

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-026.txt.asc

Title: NetBSD ptrace() and if_clone_list() Bugs Disclose Kernel Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD.  A local user can read portions of kernel memory.
A local user can supply a specially crafted PT_LWPINFO request to the ptrace(2) function call to cause kernel memory to be leaked.

A local user can exploit the if_clone_list() function to cause the kernel to disclose up to IFNAMSIZ bytes of uninitialized stack memory.

Ben Hawkes of Suresec Pty. Ltd. reported this ptrace vulnerability.   Christer Oberg of BitSec reported the if_clone_list() vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can read portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed kernel.

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-025.txt.asc

Title: Mac OS X DMG Image Validation Error May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X.  A remote user can obtain privileges on the target system.
The com.apple.AppleDiskImageController does not properly validate DMG files.  A user can create a specially crafted DMG image that, when loaded by the target user, will trigger a memory corruption error and execute arbitrary code on the target system.

LMH discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://projects.info-pull.com/mokb/MOKB-20-11-2006.html
Impact': A remote user can create a DMG image file that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: OpenBSD 'ld.so(1)' May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenBSD in 'ld.so(1)'.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
'ld.so(1)' does not properly reset user-supplied environment variables.  This may theoretically allow a local user to obtain information or potentially obtain elevated privileges.  However, the vendor notes that they have not identified any cases in which this would result in a security impact.

Only ELF-based systems are affected.  m68k, m88k, and vax are a.out-based systems and are not affected.
Impact': A local user may potentially be able to obtain information or elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches.

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/4.0/common/005_ldso.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.9/common/016_ldso.patch

Title: HP Tru64 UNIX libpthread Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in libpthread.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
A local user can exploit a flaw in the POSIX Threads library ('libpthread') to execute arbitrary code on the target system with root level privileges.

HP Tru64 UNIX versions 5.1B-2/PK4 and 5.1B-3 are not affected.

The vendor credits Adriel T. Desautels of Netragard, L.L.C with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following Early Release Patches.

HP Tru64 UNIX Version 5.1A PK6 ERP Kit

Location: http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/patch/patchDetail.do?patchid=T64KIT1000974-V51AB24-ES-20061031

Name: T64KIT1000974-V51AB24-ES-20061031

MD5 Checksum: 5d61225e7bdbeed85b8f1a01153673c2

HP Tru64 UNIX Version 4.0G PK4 ERP Kit

Location: http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/patch/patchDetail.do?patchid=T64KIT1000976-V40GB22-ES-20061031

Name: T64KIT1000976-V40GB22-ES-20061031

Title: Apple AirPort Probe Response Frame Memory Error Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in AirPort.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
A remote user on the wireless network can send a specially crafted probe response frame to a driver that is in active scanning mode to trigger a memory corruption error and execute arbitrary code on the target system.

The Apple Airport driver provided with Orinoco-based Airport cards is affected.

Apple indicates that the affected AirPort cards are first generation AirPort cards that last shipped in October 2003.  Cards that are currently shipping are not affected.  AirPort Extreme enabled Macs are not affected.

H D Moore reported this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://projects.info-pull.com/mokb/MOKB-01-11-2006.html
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-007, available via the Software Update pane in System Preferences or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

Title: HP NonStop Server Lets Local Users Access Restricted Files in Certain Cases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP NonStop Server.  A local user can access restricted files on the target system.
The system does not properly evaluate access permissions on OSS directories when there is no optional access control list (ACL) entry assigned.  This may allow a local user to gain unauthorized access to files and directories.
Impact': A local user can gain unauthorized access to files and directories.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (G06.29.02).

The HP advisory is available at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00795238

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Solaris) OpenSSL RSA Signatures Can Be Forged
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenSSL.  A remote user may be able to forge certain digital signatures.  Sun Solaris is affected.
If an RSA key with exponent 3 is used, a remote user may be able to forge a PKCS #1 v1.5 signature for that key.

Software that uses PKCS #1 v1.5 may be affected.  Software that uses OpenSSL to verify X.509 certificates may also be affected.

Daniel Bleichenbacher reported the type of attack that is possible against PKCS #1 v1.5 signatures.
Impact': A remote user may be able to forge signatures (and certificates).
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 119213-10 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 119214-10 or later

Sun is working on a fix for Solaris 9.

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102656-1

Title: Solaris tcp_fuse_rcv_drain() Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris in the TCP fusion code.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can invoke the tcp_fuse_rcv_drain() function when using TCP loopback connections to trigger a null pointer dereference and cause a system panic.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause a system panic on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued a fix.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-23 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-19 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102667-1

Title: Solaris Link Aggregation Access Restrictions Let Local Users Monitor Network Packets
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A local user can monitor network packets.
Incorrect permission checks in the default Solaris 10 configuration allow local users to invoke '/dev/aggr' nodes to create a raw socket on a Solaris link aggregation.  A local user can gain full access to network packets.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can obtain access to all network traffic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-23 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-19 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102606-1

Title: BSD UNIX systrace STRIOCREPLACE Integer Overflow Lets Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in BSD UNIX systrace().  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can trigger an integer overflow to cause denial of service conditions, read from kernel memory, or obtain elevated privileges on the target system.

Chris Evans of the Google Security Team discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.8/common/019_systrace.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.9/common/014_systrace.patch

Title: Solaris IPv6 Fragment Reassembly Bug Lets Remote Users Cause a Kernel Panic
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can exploit a flaw in the reassembly of IPv6 fragments to cause a kernel panic on the target system.
Impact': A remote user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 116965-22 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 114344-20 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 119075-13 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 116966-21 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 119435-10 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 119076-11 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102144-1

Title: IBM AIX acctctl Command Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
The acctctl command uses the mkdir without specifying the absolute path.  A local user in the 'adm' group can create an alternate mkdir binary and then cause the system to execute the alternate binary with root privileges.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
IBM has issued a fix (APAR IY88681) for IBM AIX 5.3.

The IBM advisory is available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY88681

Title: Apple LoginWindow Lets Local Users Access Another User's Kerberos Tickets or Bypass Access Controls
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple LoginWindow.  A local user may be able to gain access to another user's Kerberos tickets.  A network account can bypass service access controls in certain cases.
The system may not properly delete Kerberos tickets after an unsuccessful login attempt to a network account via LoginWindow [CVE-2006-4397]. A local user may be able to gain access to another user's Kerberos tickets.  Apple credits Patrick Gallagher of Digital Peaks Corporation with reporting this vulnerability.

If Fast User Switching is enabled, a local user may be able to gain access to another user's Kerberos tickets [CVE-2006-4393].  Apple credits Ragnar Sundblad of the Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden with reporting this vulnerability.

A network account without a GUID can bypass service access controls if the system is configured to use service access controls for LoginWindow and to allow network accounts to authenticate without a GUID [CVE-2006-4394].

Version prior to 10.4 are not affected by these vulnerabilities.
Impact':
A local user may be able to gain access to another user's Kerberos tickets.

A network account can bypass service access controls in certain cases.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Mac OS X v10.4.8 and Security Update 2006-006, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

Only one update is needed, and Software Update will select the proper one.

Title: Mac OS X Workgroup Manager May Display the Incorrect Password Authentication Method
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X Workgroup Manager.  The system may display the incorrect pasword hash status for a user.
An account displayed via Workgroup Manager may show the incorrect password hash status.

Workgroup Manager appears to allow the authentication type in a NetInfo parent window to be switched from crypt to ShadowHash but actually does not allow the switch.

Apple cedits Chris Pepper of The Rockefeller University with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A NetInfo account window displayed via Workgroup Manager may show the incorrect password hash status.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Mac OS X v10.4.8 and Security Update 2006-006, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Mac OS X WebCore WebKit Memory Management Error Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X WebCore.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
A remote user can create specially crafted HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will trigger a memory management error in WebCore's WebKit and execute arbitrary code on the target system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

Apple credits Jens Kutilek of Netzallee with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Mac OS X v10.4.8 and Security Update 2006-006, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Mac OS X Preferences May Let Users Retain Administrative Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X Preferences.  A user may retain administrative privileges after having the privileges disabled in certain cases.
The system does not properly remove an account from the 'appserveradm' or 'appserverusr' groups when the "Allow user to administer this computer" checkbox is cleared in System Preferences.  As a result, when an account's administrative privileges are removed, the user of the account may still be able to manage WebObjects applications.

Versions prior to 10.4 are not affected.

Apple credits Phillip Tejada of Fruit Bat Software with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A user may still be able to manage WebObjects applications even after their privileges have been removed via System Preferences.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Mac OS X v10.4.8 and Security Update 2006-006, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

Title: Mac OS X Mach Kernel Exception Error Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
The Mach exception ports can be exploited to cause privileged programs to execute arbitrary code in certain error situations.  A local user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with elevated privileges.

Title: Apple ImageIO Buffer Overflow in Processing JPEG2000 Images Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple ImageIO.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
A remote user can create a specially crafted JPEG2000 image that, when loaded by the target user, will trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the target system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

Versions prior to 10.4 are not affected.

Apple credits Tom Saxton of Idle Loop Software Design with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can create an image that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.

Title: Apple CFNetwork Error May Cause Incorrect SSL Authentication Status to Be Displayed
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple CFNetwork.  A remote, unauthenticated web site may appear to be authenticated.
An application (such as Safari) that uses the CFNetwork library may incorrectly display an unauthenticated SSL site as authenticated. This may occur when the site uses encryption without authentication.

Apple credits Adam Bryzak of Queensland University of Technology with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote unauthenticated site may incorrectly appear to be authenticated.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Mac OS X v10.4.8 and Security Update 2006-006, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

Title: Solaris SSL Kernel Feature Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris in the kernel SSL feature.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send specially crafted SSL data to trigger a kernel panic on the target system.

Solaris 10 is affected.
Impact': A remote user can cause a kernel panic.

A remote or local user can send specially crafted IPv6 packets to cause a system panic.

A local user can disable the syslog(3c) function.  As a result, messages will not be written to the system log.

Title: FreeBSD i386_set_ldt() Integer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the i386_set_ldt() function.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions and may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
A local user can trigger an integer overflow to trigger a kernel panic or potentially execute arbitrary code on the target system.

Adriano Lima discovered this vulnerability.  Rodrigo Rubira Branco researched this vulnerability.
Impact':
A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.

A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution: The vendor has issued a fix as part of 6.0-RELEASE.

Title: FreeBSD Kernel i386_set_ldt() Signed nteger Error Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a vulnerability in FreeBSD kernel in the i386_set_ldt() function.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can exploit a signed integer flaw to trigger a kernel panic.

The vendor was notified on August 16, 2006.

iDEFENSE reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
It is unclear if a solution is available.

The vendor does not plan to issue a security advisory, but may issue Errata Notice.

Title: FreeBSD Kernel i386_set_ldt() Integer Overflow Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a vulnerability in FreeBSD kernel in the i386_set_ldt() function.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can trigger an integer overflow to cause a kernel panic.

iDEFENSE reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution: The vendor issued a source code correction on March 23, 2005.

Title: IBM AIX rdist Command Lets Local Users Overwrite Arbitrary Files
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX in the rdist command.  A local user can overwrite arbitrary files.
A local user can exploit a flaw in 'usr/bin/rdist' to overwrite arbitrary files on the target system.

The '/usr/sbin/rdist' command is not affected.

The 'bos.net.tcp.client' fileset is affected.
Impact': A local user can overwrite arbitrary files on the target system, causing denial of service conditions.
Solution:
IBM has issued the following fixes:

      APAR number for AIX 5.2.0:  IY88688 (available)
      APAR number for AIX 5.3.0:  IY88687 (available approx. 10/04/06)

Interim fixes are available at:

Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX in the cfgmgr command.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
A local user in the system group can execute arbitrary code on the target system with root privileges.

The local user can also overwrite arbitrary system files.

Impact: Denial of service via local system

A local user in the system group and with the 'Diagnostics' role can execute arbitrary commands on the target system with root level privileges.

The local user can also overwrite arbitrary files with root privileges, causing denial of service conditions on the target system.

The 'devices.scsi.tape.diag' fileset is affected.
Impact':
A local user in the system group and with the 'Diagnostics' role can obtain root privileges on the target system.

The local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the target system.

Title: Apple AirPort Wireless Driver Has Buffer Overflows That Let Remote Users on the Wireless Network Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in Apple AirPort.  A remote user on the wireless network can execute arbitrary code on the target system or cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user on the wireless network can send specially crafted frames to trigger a stack overflow in the wireless driver and execute arbitrary code on the target system [CVE-2006-3507].  The code will run with system privileges.  The Power Mac, PowerBook, iMac, Mac Pro, Xserve, and PowerPC-based Mac mini systems equipped with wireless capabilities are affected.  The Intel-based Mac mini, MacBook, and MacBook Pro systems are not affected.

A remote user on the wireless network can send specially crafted frames to trigger a heap overflow in the wireless driver and execute arbitrary code on the target system with system privileges or cause the system to crash [CVE-2006-3508].  The vulnerability resides in the processing of scan cache updates.  The Intel-based Mac mini, MacBook, and MacBook Pro systems equipped with wireless capabilities are affected.  The Power Mac, PowerBook, iMac, Mac Pro, Xserve, and PowerPC-based Mac mini systems are not affected.

A remote user on the wireless network can send specially crafted frames to trigger an integer overflow in the wireless driver's API for 3rd party applications and execute arbitrary code on the target system or cause the system to crash [CVE-2006-3509].  The specific impact depends on the application that uses the API.  The Intel-based Mac mini, MacBook, and MacBook Pro systems equipped with wireless capabilities are affected.  The Power Mac, PowerBook, iMac, Mac Pro, Xserve, and PowerPC-based Mac mini systems are not affected.
Impact':
A remote user on the wireless network can execute arbitrary code on the target system.

A remote user on the wireless network can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of AirPort Update 2006-001 and Security Update 2006-005, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's
Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

Only one of the updates is needed (either AirPort Update 2006-001 or Security Update 2006-005) and Software Update will present the update that applies to your system configuration.

For Mac OS X v10.4.7 Build 8J2135 or 8J2135a
The download file is named:  "AirPortUpdate2006001.dmg"

Title: (OpenBSD Issues Fix) BSD UNIX PPP LCP Options Length Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in PPP on BSD-based systems.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) implementation on FreeBSD, OpenBSD, and NetBSD does not properly validate Line Control Protocol (LCP) options.  A remote user (on the PPP connection) can send specially crafted data to cause the target kernel to panic.

It is not known if remote code execution is possible or not.

Pavel Cahyna discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
OpenBSD has issued the following patches:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.9/common/009_sppp.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.8/common/014_sppp.patch

Title: OpenBSD Kernel Semaphore Allocation Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the OpenBSD Kernel.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can cause more than the default number of semaphores to be allocated to cause a kernel panic.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
OpenBSD has issued the following fixes:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.9/common/007_sem.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.8/common/012_sem.patch

Title: (NetBSD Issues Fix) BSD UNIX PPP LCP Options Length Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in PPP on BSD-based systems.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) implementation on FreeBSD, OpenBSD, and NetBSD does not properly validate Line Control Protocol (LCP) options.  A remote user (on the PPP connection) can send specially crafted data to cause the target kernel to panic.

It is not known if remote code execution is possible or not.

Pavel Cahyna discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
NetBSD has released a fix and has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

For all NetBSD versions, you need to obtain fixed kernel sources,
rebuild and install the new kernel, and reboot the system.

The fixed source may be obtained from the NetBSD CVS repository.        

The following instructions briefly summarise how to upgrade your        
kernel.  In these instructions, replace:

  ARCH     with your architecture (from uname -m), and                  
  KERNCONF with the name of your kernel configuration file.    

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install the kernel:

	# cd src
	# cvs update -d -P sys/net/if_spppsubr.c
	# ./build.sh kernel=KERNCONF
	# mv /netbsd /netbsd.old
	# cp sys/arch/ARCH/compile/obj/KERNCONF/netbsd /netbsd 
	# shutdown -r now

For more information on how to do this, see:    

   http://www.NetBSD.org/guide/en/chap-kernel.html

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-019.txt.asc

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Fix) BSD UNIX PPP LCP Options Length Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in PPP on BSD-based systems.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) implementation on FreeBSD, OpenBSD, and NetBSD does not properly validate Line Control Protocol (LCP) options.  A remote user (on the PPP connection) can send specially crafted data to cause the target kernel to panic.

It is not known if remote code execution is possible or not.

Pavel Cahyna discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
FreeBSD has released a fix and provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE, 5-STABLE, or 6-STABLE,
or to the RELENG_6_1, RELENG_6_0, RELENG_5_5, RELENG_5_4, RELENG_5_3,
or RELENG_4_11 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.11, 5.3,
5.4, 5.5, 6.0, and 6.1 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.x]
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:18/ppp4x.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:18/ppp4x.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.3]
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:18/ppp53.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:18/ppp53.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.4, 5.5, and 6.x]
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:18/ppp.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:18/ppp.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in
<URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the
system.

The FreeBSD advisory is available at

http://security.FreeBSD.org/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:18.ppp.asc

Title: BSD UNIX PPP LCP Options Length Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in PPP on BSD-based systems.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) implementation on FreeBSD, OpenBSD, and NetBSD does not properly validate Line Control Protocol (LCP) options.  A remote user (on the PPP connection) can send specially crafted data to cause the target kernel to panic.

Title: Solaris Buffer Overflow in 'format' Command Lets Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris in the format command.  A local user may be able to obtain root privileges.
A local user with the "File System Management" RBAC profile can exploit a buffer overflow in the format(1M) command to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

Custom profiles that provide access to the format(1M) command with root privileges are also affected.
Impact': A local user with certain RBAC profiles can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 108975-10 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 113072-08 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-18 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 108976-10 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 114423-07 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118997-09 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102519-1

Title: Sun Solaris Default RBAC Configuration May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in the default Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) configuration.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges.
The default RBAC configuration associated with the "File System Management" profile is unsafe.  A local user who has been assigned that profile may be able to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges.  The local user may also be able to write to device files associated with local disks with root privileges.

Solaris 10 is not affected.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 108975-10 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 113072-08 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 108976-10 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 114423-07 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102514-1

Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:

A local user may be able to exploit a flaw in setlocale() via applications with set user id (setuid) or set group id (setgid) privileges that call the function to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.

A local user can exploit a race condition to potentially cause listener programs for databases or other network-based applications that use the libnsl(3LIB) or TLI/XTI APIs to stop responding.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-20 or later

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102576-1

Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
When HP-UX is running in trusted mode, a local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.  No further information was provided.

Title: Solaris netstat/ifconfig Race Condition May Let Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user may be able to trigger a race condition between netstat(1M) (or snmp queries) and ifconfig(1M) to cause a system panic.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause a system panic.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

As a workaround, binary relief is available through normal support channels.

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102569-1

Title: Solaris TCP/IP drain_squeue() Bug May Let Remote Users Panic the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a large amount of rapidly opening and closing TCP connections to cause a system panic.

Many tens of thousands of connections are required to exploit this flaw.

Chip Multi-Threading (CMT) processors are more likely to be able to sustain a high level of throughput while still context switching fast enough to trigger the flaw.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can cause a system panic in certain situations.
Solution:
Sun indicates that binary relief is available through normal support channels.

A final fix is pending.

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102554-1

Title: Solaris Performance Can Be Degraded via a TCP ACK Flood Attack
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can conduct a TCP ACK flood attack (using inherenet features of the TCP protocol) to cause the target system to consume all available resources.  Performance on the target system will be degraded.
Impact': A remote user can cause performance to degrade on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes to protect against TCP ACK storms.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 116965-17 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 118305-07 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-12 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 116966-16 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 117470-06 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-10 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102206-1

Title: Sun Solaris IP_NEXTHOP Option Lets Local Users Bypass the Routing Table
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris.  A local user can bypass the routing table.
A local user can invoke the IP_NEXTHOP socket option to bypass the routing table and send packets to or via a router that is different than specified by the routing table.  As a result, the user may be able to bypass a firewall or reach restricted hosts and services.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can bypass the routing table.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-18 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-15 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102509-1

Title: Sun Solaris Integer Overflow in sysinfo(2) Lets Local Users View Kernel Memory
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a vulnerability in Sun Solaris.  A local user can read portions of kernel memory.
A local user can trigger an integer overflow in sysinfo(2) to view kernel memory.

The flaw resides in '/usr/src/uts/common/syscall/systeminfo.c'.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.

The vendor was notified on December 15, 2005.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.idefense.com/application/poi/display?type=vulnerabilities
Impact': A local user can read portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fix.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-09 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-06 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102343-1

Title: Solaris Event Port API Bugs May Let Local or Remote Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
The Solaris event port API contains several flaws.  A local user can run an application that uses the API in a certain manner to trigger a system panic.

If the application using the API allows remote access (such as the Apache web server), then a remote user may be able to trigger a system panic.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact':
A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.

A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued a fix:

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-12 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-10 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102485-1

Title: Solaris '/net' Mount Point Continuous Loop Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user may be able to invoke the special "/net" mount point (or another mount point that uses the "-hosts" special map) to cause denial of service conditions on the target system.  This occurs due to a continuous loop while performing a directory lookup on 'localhost'.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued a fix:

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-11 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-08 or later

The Sun alert is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102286-1

Title: Solaris Kernel Debugger Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
On an x86-based system that has loaded the kernel debugger kmdb(1), a local user can cause kmdb breakpoints to be written to disk executables, causing the system to hang.

SPARC-based systems are not affected.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued a fix:

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-15 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102512-1

Title: Solaris Kernel Patches May Let Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solaris 10 kernel patches 118822-29 or later for SPARC and 118844-29 or later for x86 are flawed.  A local user can cause kernel memory corruption, application failure, data corruption, or a system panic.

The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) in JRE 1.4.x is one application that can be used to trigger this vulnerability.

If the system is configured for anonymous ftp, a remote user can cause a system panic.

Solaris 8 and Solaris 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118833-11 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118855-08 or later

The Sun alert is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102344-1

Title: HP-UX mkdir Unspecified Bug Lets Local Users Gain Unauthorized Access
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in mkdir on HP-UX.  A local user can gain unauthorized access.
A local user can invoke mkdir(1) to gain unauthorized access.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user can gain unauthorized access.
Solution:
HP has issued the following patches, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

HP-UX B.11.00 PHCO_34533

HP-UX B.11.04 PHCO_35040

HP-UX B.11.11 PHCO_32036

HP-UX B.11.23 PHCO_34151

The HP advisory is available at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00705390

Title: Apple Mac OS X Format String Bug in launchd Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in launchd.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
The 'launchd' application contains a format string flaw in the logging function.  A local user can cause launchd to execute arbitrary code.  The application is configured with set user id (setuid) privileges.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.

Apple credits Kevin Finisterre of DigitalMunition with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (OS X 10.4.7), available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

Title: Apple File Protocol Search Results May Disclose Restricted File and Folder Names
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in the Apple File Protocol implementation.  A local user may be able to view file and folder names.
A user may can view AFP server search results to view the names of files and folders that the user is not authorized to access.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.
Impact': A local user may be able to view file names and folder names for restricted files and folders.
Solution:

Title: Apple Mac OS X ImageIO Stack Overflow in Processing TIFF Images Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X ImageIO.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
A remote user can create a specially crafted TIFF image file that, when loaded by the target user, will trigger a stack overflow and execute arbitrary code on the target system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can create a file that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (OS X 10.4.7), available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.6 (PowerPC)
