Title: HP-UX Unspecified Kernel Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can exploit an unspecified flaw in the HP-UX kernel to cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
HP has issued the following patches, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

PHKL_34192 for B.11.00
PHKL_34193 for B.11.11
PHKL_34194 for B.11.23

The HP advisory is available at:

http://h20000.www2.hp.com/bizsupport/TechSupport/Document.jsp?objectID=c00705283

Title: (NetBSD Issues Fix) FreeBSD Floating Point Unit Kernel Implementation Error May Let Local Users Obtain Sensitive Information
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD when running on AMD processors.  A local user may be able to obtain sensitive information.  NetBSD is also affected.
On "7th generation" and "8th generation" processors manufactured by AMD, the fxsave and fxrstor instructions do not save and restore the FOP, FIP, and FDP registers unless the exception summary bit (ES) in the x87 status word is set (whereas other processors store this information regardless of the ES bit).

As a result, the FreeBSD kernel does not restore the contents of the FOP, FIP, and FDP registers between context switches.  This may allow a local user to monitor the execution path of a process that uses floating-point operations to obtain potentially sensitive information.

Systems that do not use AMD Athlon, Duron, Athlon MP, Athlon XP, Athlon64, Athlon64 FX, Opteron, Turion, or Sempron processors are not affected.

The vendor credits Jan Beulich with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can monitor the execution path of a process that uses floating-point operations, which may allow the user to obtain cryptographic keys or other potentially sensitive information.
Solution:
NetBSD has released a kernel fix.  NetBSD is affected by this vulnerability.

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-015.txt.asc

Title: NetBSD Input Validation Error in Parsing IPv6 Socket Options Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
The system does not properly validate user-supplied IPv6 socket options.  A local user can send an IPv6 packet to an IPv4-mapped socket to trigger a kernel panic.

Only systems configured with net.inet6.ip6.v6only sysctl MIB (global) or IPV6_V6ONLY socket option (per-socket) set to zero are affected.

The vendor credits Christian Biere with discovering this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a kernel fix.

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-016.txt.asc

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Solaris) FreeBSD Hyper-Threading Technology Support May Disclose Information to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD when using Hyper-Threading Technology.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.  Sun Solaris is affected.
A local user may be able to obtain potentially sensitive information.  In "many cases," this may be exploited to gain elevated privileges.

The vendor credits Colin Percival with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain information, leading to privilege escalation.
Solution:
Sun has described workarounds for Sun Solaris, which is affected by this vulnerability.

The workarounds are listed in the Sun advisory, available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-101739-1

Title: FreeBSD smbfs '..\' Input Validation Hole Lets Users Traverse the Directory
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the smbfs filesystem.  A user can escape a chroot'd directory.
smbfs does not properly validate path names that contain a backslash character.  A remote authenticated user can use specially crafted characters ('..\') in a directory name to escape a chroot'd directory.  Other directories on the smbfs mounted filesystem can be accessed.

Mark Moseley discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can bypass chroot restrictions and access other directories on the target smbfs mounted filesystem.
Solution:
FreeBSD has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE, 5-STABLE, or 6-STABLE,
or to the RELENG_6_1, RELENG_6_0, RELENG_5_5, RELENG_5_4, RELENG_5_3,
RELENG_4_11, or RELENG_4_10 security branch dated after the correction
date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.10,
4.11, 5.3, 5.4, 5.5, 6.0, and 6.1 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:16/smbfs.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:16/smbfs.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in
<URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the
system.

The FreeBSD advisory is available at:

http://security.FreeBSD.org/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:16.smbfs.asc

Title: FreeBSD ypserv Does Not Properly Enforce 'securenets' Access Controls
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in ypserv on FreeBSD.  The utility does not properly enforce the '/var/yp/securenets' access controls.
The '/var/yp/securenets' file access controls are indavertently disabled in the ypserv(8) utility.

Hokan discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': Access controls specified in the '/var/yp/securenets' are not enforced.
Solution:
FreeBSD has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 5-STABLE or 6-STABLE, or to the
RELENG_6_1, RELENG_6_0, RELENG_5_5, RELENG_5_4, or RELENG_5_3 security
branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5.3, 5.4,
5.5, 6.0, and 6.1 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:15/ypserv.patch
# fetch http://security.FreeBSD.org/patches/SA-06:15/ypserv.patch.asc

b) Execute the following commands as root:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch
# cd /usr/src/usr.sbin/ypserv
# make obj && make depend && make && make install

The FreeBSD advisory is available at:

http://security.FreeBSD.org/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:15.ypserv.asc

Title: IBM AIX lsmcode Bug Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can trigger a flaw in 'lsmcode' and execute arbitrary code on the target system with root level privileges.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor plans to issue the following fixes:

      APAR number for AIX 5.1.0:  IY85518 (available approx. 7/19/06)
      APAR number for AIX 5.2.0:  IY88524 (available approx. 8/23/06)
      APAR number for AIX 5.3.0:  IY85517 (available approx. 8/23/06)

The vendor plans to issue interm fixes "within the coming week," to be available at:

ftp://aix.software.ibm.com/

Title: HP-UX Kernel Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can exploit an unspecified flaw in the HP-UX kernel to cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
HP has issued a patch, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

B.11.00 - PHKL_34406 or subsequent
B.11.04 - PHKL_34940 or subsequent

The HP advisory is available at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00676467

Title: Apple Mac OS X Kernel Components Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
A remote user can create an archive, such as a Zip archive, that contains a file with a long path name that, when expanded by the target user, will trigger a heap overflow in the BOM component and execute arbitrary code.

An archive with specially crafted directory traversal symbolic links may allow a remote user to create or overwrite arbitrary files when the target user expands the archive.

A remote user can send specially crafted chunked transfer encoding data to trigger an integer overflow in the CFNetwork component and execute arbitrary code on the target system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target service.  Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected by the CFNetwork vulnerability.

A remote user can create HTML that references a specially crafted Internet Location item (e.g., URL) that appears to the target user to be benign but, when loaded by the target user, will load a different URL scheme.  This may allow arbitrary code to be executed.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-003, available via Software Update preferences and at Apple Downloads:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

The Apple security advisory is available at:

http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=303737

Title: Apple LaunchServices Lets Remote Users Bypass Download Validation in Certain Cases
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple LaunchServices.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
A remote user can create a file with a specially crafted filename extension that, when loaded by the target user via Safari, will bypass Download Validation if the "Open 'safe' files after downloading" option is enabled and certain applications are not installed on the target user's system.  As a result, a remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can create a file that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-003, available via Software Update preferences and at Apple Downloads:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

The Apple security advisory is available at:

http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=303737

Title: Apple Mac OS X CoreFoundation Untrusted Bundles or the CFStringGetFileSystemRepresentation() API May Let Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X CoreFoundation.  A user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target system.
An application can register an untrusted bundle that will load and execute an arbitrary dynamic library.  This may allow a user to execute arbitrary code.

Also, the CFStringGetFileSystemRepresentation() API contains an integer overflow.  A user can invoke this API or a related API to execute arbitrary code.
Impact': A user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.  The specific impact depends on the applications that use the affected CoreFoundation functions.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Apple Mac OS X CoreGraphics May Let Local Users Obtain Secure Text Field Inputs
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X CoreGraphics.  A local user may be able to obtain secure input.
If "Enable access for assistive devices" is enabled, a local user can invoke Quartz Event Services to intercept events even when secure event input is enabled.  This allows a local user to, for example, obtain characters entered into a secure text field within the same window session.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.

Apple credits Damien Bobillot with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain secure text field input.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-003, available via Software Update preferences and at Apple Downloads:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

The Apple security advisory is available at:

http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=303737

Title: Mac OS X Preview Buffer Overflow in Navigating Deep Directory Hierarchies May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X Preview.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user can create a specially crafted directory hierarchy.  When the target user navigates into deep directory hierarchies using Preview, a stack overflow may occur and arbitrary code may be executed on the target system.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-003, available via Software Update preferences and at Apple Downloads:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

The Apple security advisory is available at:

http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=303737

Title: NetBSD Audio Subsystem May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can change the sample rate of an audio device during playback to cause the target system to crash.

The audio_write() function does not check to determine if the filter list has been changed while the function is in the process of reading data.  A local user can cause the audiosetinfo() function to change the filter during this process to cause the kernel to crash.

Versions prior to 3.0 are not affected.

Christian Biere reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

For all NetBSD versions, you need to obtain fixed kernel sources,
rebuild and install the new kernel, and reboot the system.

The fixed source may be obtained from the NetBSD CVS repository.

The following instructions briefly summarise how to upgrade your
kernel.  In these instructions, replace:

  ARCH     with your architecture (from uname -m), and 
  KERNCONF with the name of your kernel configuration file.

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install the kernel:

        # cd src
        # cvs update -d -P sys/dev/audio.c
        # cvs update -d -P sys/dev/audio_if.h
        # cvs update -d -P sys/dev/audiovar.h
	# ./build.sh kernel=KERNCONF
	# mv /netbsd /netbsd.old
	# cp sys/arch/ARCH/compile/obj/KERNCONF/netbsd /netbsd
	# shutdown -r now

For more information on how to do this, see:

   http://www.NetBSD.org/guide/en/chap-kernel.html

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

  ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-014.txt.asc

Title: Sun Solaris libpkcs11 May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris libpkcs11.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
When a privileged application links to the Sun libpkcs11(3LIB) library and invokes the getpwnam(3C) function or related functions to access password entries, the function may overwrite thread-specific data.  A local user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed with the privileges of the target application.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.  The specific impact, if any, depends on the application using the libpkcs11 library.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118918-14 or later [Global]
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118562-09 or later [Restricted]

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118919-12 or later [Global]
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118563-07 or later [Restricted]

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102316-1

Title: FreeBSD Floating Point Unit Kernel Implementation Error May Let Local Users Obtain Sensitive Information
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD when running on AMD processors.  A local user may be able to obtain sensitive information.
On "7th generation" and "8th generation" processors manufactured by AMD, the fxsave and fxrstor instructions do not save and restore the FOP, FIP, and FDP registers unless the exception summary bit (ES) in the x87 status word is set (whereas other processors store this information regardless of the ES bit).

As a result, the FreeBSD kernel does not restore the contents of the FOP, FIP, and FDP registers between context switches.  This may allow a local user to monitor the execution path of a process that uses floating-point operations to obtain potentially sensitive information.

Systems that do not use AMD Athlon, Duron, Athlon MP, Athlon XP, Athlon64, Athlon64 FX, Opteron, Turion, or Sempron processors are not affected.

The vendor credits Jan Beulich with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can monitor the execution path of a process that uses floating-point operations, which may allow the user to obtain cryptographic keys or other potentially sensitive information.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE, 5-STABLE, or 6-STABLE,
or to the RELENG_6_0, RELENG_5_4, RELENG_5_3, RELENG_4_11, or
RELENG_4_10 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.10,
4.11, 5.3, 5.4, and 6.0 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:14/fpu4x.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:14/fpu4x.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.x and 6.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:14/fpu.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:14/fpu.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in
<URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the
system.

The FreeBSD advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.freebsd.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:14.fpu.asc

Title: IBM AIX rm_mlcache_file Command May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX in the rm_mlcache_file command.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
A local user can exploit the rm_mlcache_file command to overwrite arbitrary files on the target system.

This can be exploited to cause data loss or denial of service conditions.

The rm_mlcache_file command is part of the bos.rte.install fileset.

Yang Jilong of NSFocus Security Team found the vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.nsfocus.com/english/homepage/research/0603.htm
Impact': A local user can overwrite arbitrary files on the target system to cause data loss or denial of service conditions.
Solution:
IBM has issued or plans to issue the following fixes:

      APAR number for AIX 5.1.0: IY82866 (available approx. 07/19/06)
      APAR number for AIX 5.2.0: IY82285 (available approx. 04/26/06)
      APAR number for AIX 5.3.0: IY82357 (available)

Interim fixes are available at:

ftp://aix.software.ibm.com/aix/efixes/security/rm_mlcache_file_ifix.tar.Z

Title: NetBSD sysctl() Buffer Validation Error Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can invoke a sysctl(3) call to cause the system to allocate all available physical memory.  As a result, the target system may crash.

The vulnerability occurs because the sysctl(3) call does not properly check the size of a user-supplied buffer.

The vendor credits Matthias Drochner with reporting this vulnerabilities.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following solution information [quoted]:

The fixed source may be obtained from the NetBSD CVS repository.

The following instructions briefly summarise how to upgrade your
kernel.  In these instructions, replace:

  ARCH     with your architecture (from uname -m), and 
  KERNCONF with the name of your kernel configuration file.

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install the kernel:

        # cd src
        # cvs update -d -P sys/kern/kern_sysctl.c
	# ./build.sh kernel=KERNCONF
	# mv /netbsd /netbsd.old
	# cp sys/arch/ARCH/compile/obj/KERNCONF/netbsd /netbsd
	# shutdown -r now

For more information on how to do this, see:

   http://www.NetBSD.org/guide/en/chap-kernel.html

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-
013.txt.asc

Title: NetBSD SIOCGIFALIAS ioctl Error Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can attempt to gather information on a non-existent alias of a network interface via the SIOCGIFALIAS ioctl to trigger a NULL dereference and cause the target system to crash.

The vendor credits Sean Boudreau with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following solution information [quoted]:

The fixed source may be obtained from the NetBSD CVS repository.

The following instructions briefly summarise how to upgrade your
kernel.  In these instructions, replace:

  ARCH     with your architecture (from uname -m), and 
  KERNCONF with the name of your kernel configuration file.

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install the kernel:

        # cd src
        # cvs update -d -P sys/netinet/in.c
	# ./build.sh kernel=KERNCONF
	# mv /netbsd /netbsd.old
	# cp sys/arch/ARCH/compile/obj/KERNCONF/netbsd /netbsd
	# shutdown -r now

For more information on how to do this, see:

   http://www.NetBSD.org/guide/en/chap-kernel.
html

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-012.txt.asc

Title: NetBSD Intel RNG Driver May Use a Constant Stream for Randomization
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD.  The driver for the Intel random number generator may feed a constant stream into the entropy pool.
The NetBSD kernel may incorrectly detect a hardware-based random number generator, causing a constant stream of bytes (255 value) to be fed into the kernel random number generator.

This could, for example, result in the use of predictable keys for cryptography.

The vendor credits Thor Lancelot Simon and Matthias Scheler with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': The random number generator may be fed with a constant stream.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a kernel fix and the following solution information [quoted]:

The fixed source may be obtained from the NetBSD CVS repository.

The following instructions briefly summarise how to upgrade your
kernel.  In these instructions, replace:

  ARCH     with your architecture (from uname -m), and 
  KERNCONF with the name of your kernel configuration file.

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install the kernel for any of
the netbsd-2, netbsd-2-0, netbsd-2-1, netbsd-3 or netbsd-3-0 branches:

        # cd src
        # cvs update -d -P sys/arch/i386/pci/pchb_rnd.c
	# ./build.sh kernel=KERNCONF
	# mv /netbsd /netbsd.old
	# cp sys/arch/ARCH/compile/obj/KERNCONF/netbsd /netbsd
	# shutdown -r now

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install the kernel for 
the -current (a.k.a HEAD) branch:

        # cd src
        # cvs update -d -P sys/arch/x86/pci/pchb_rnd.c 
	# ./build.sh kernel=KERNCONF
	# mv /netbsd /netbsd.old
	# cp sys/arch/ARCH/compile/obj/KERNCONF/netbsd /netbsd
	# shutdown -r now

For more information on how to do this, see:

   http://www.NetBSD.org/guide/en/chap-kernel.html

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-009.txt.asc

Title: Solaris Bug in sh Temporary File Creation Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in sh on Sun Solaris.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can cause sh(1) to crash while creating temporary files.  This can result in denial of service conditions on the target system for scripts or users that use the Bourne shell.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 109324-09 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 118535-03 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 121004-01 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 109325-09 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 118536-03 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 121005-01 or later

Title: HP-UX su LDAP Netgroup Bug Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in su on HP-UX.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
When su(1) is used with the LDAP netgroup feature, a local user may be able to exploit an unspecified flaw to gain elevated privileges.
Impact': A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
HP has issued the following patch, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

B.11.11 - PHCO_34545 or subsequent

The HP advisory is available at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00637553

Title: Mac OS X Firmware Password Can By Bypassed on Intel-Based Systems
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X on Intel-based systems.  A physically local user can bypass the firmware password.
A physically local user can bypass the firmward password and gain 'Single User Mode' access on the target system.

Apple credits David Pugh of the University of Michigan with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A physically local user can bypass the firmward password feature.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix for OS X version 10.4.5, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: NetBSD elf_load_file() Validation Error Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
The elf_load_file() function does not properly handle interpreters without a PT_LOAD section defined in the header.  A malformed ELF interpreter can trigger a NULL pointer deference in the kernel.

The NetBSD 2.x branches are only affected if the kernel is compiled with the USE_TOPDOWN_VM option (not the default in GENERIC kernels).

Eric Haszlakiewicz reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
NetBSD has issued a fix.

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-008.txt.asc

Title: NetBSD if_bridge() May Disclose Portions of Kernel Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD in the bridge(4) implementation.  A local user can view portions of kernel memory.
The if_bridge(4) code does not properly initialize stack memory used to temporarily store ioctl(2) request results.  As a result, the calling process may be able to access portions of kernel stack memory.

Only a small number of bytes is exposed.

Xin LI reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can view portions of kernel stack memory.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.  The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-005.txt.asc

Title: (NetBSD Issues Fix) FreeBSD pf(4) Scrub Rule Error Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the pf(4) packet filter function.  A remote user can cause the kernel to crash.  NetBSD is affected.
A remote user can send specially crafted IP packet fragments to trigger a logic error in writing to the pf IP fragment cache when the 'scrub fragment crop' or 'scrub fragment drop-ovl' rules are used.  The packet fragment may be inserted twice, causing the kernel to crash.

Systems that do not use pf are not affected.

Systems that do not use the 'scrub fragment crop' or 'scrub fragment drop-ovl' pf rules are also not affected.

The vendor credits Jakob Schlyter and Daniel Hartmeier with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
NetBSD has issued a kernel fix.

The NetBSD advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-004.txt.asc

Title: Sun Solaris '/usr/ucb/ps' May Disclose Sensitive Information to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in the 'ps' utility.  A local user may be able to view potentially sensitive information.
A local user may be able to exploit '/usr/ucb/ps' with the '-e' switch to view environment variables and their contents for processes of other users.

The '/usr/bin/ps' utility is not affected.
Impact': A local user may be able to view environment variables and their contents for processes of other users.
Solution:
Sun has issued a fix.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 109023-05 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 120240-01 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 109024-05 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 120239-01 or later

The Sun advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102215-1

Title: AIX mklvcopy Lets Certain Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM's AIX operating system.  A local user can gain root privileges.
A flaw exists in mklvcopy when calling external commands.  A local user with system group privileges can execute arbitrary commands with root user privileges.

Yang Jilong of NSFocus Security Team discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.nsfocus.com/english/homepage/research/0602.htm
Impact': A local user with system group privileges can execute arbitrary commands with root user privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued APAR IY82739, available at:

http://www.ibm.com/servers/eserver/support/unixservers/aixfixes.html

A temporary patch is available at:

ftp://aix.software.ibm.com/aix/efixes/security/mklvcopy_ifix.tar.Z

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY82739

Title: HP-UX usermod Lets Local Users Modify File and Directory Permissions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX.  A local user may be able to gain unauthorized access to files and directories.
Certain versions of the HP-UX usermod(1M) command contain an unspecified vulnerability.  A local user can supply specially crafted command options to change the ownership of all directories and files under a target user's new home directory.  As a result, the user can gain access to those directories and files.
Impact': A local user can gain access to certain files and directories on the target system.
Solution:
HP has issued the following patches, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

B.11.00 - install PHCO_34763 or subsequent.
B.11.11 - install PHCO_33142 or subsequent.
B.11.23 - install PHCO_34764 or subsequent.

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00614838

Title: Apple Mac OS X CoreTypes Bug in Archive Processing Lets Remote Users Conduct Cross-Domain Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X CoreTypes.  A remote user can conduct cross-domain scripting attacks.
A remote user can create specially crafted archives containing JavaScript.  When the archive document is loaded by the target user, the JavaScript may execute in an arbitrary domain on the target user's system.
Impact': A remote user can create a document that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary JavaScript in the domain of an arbitrary site.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2006-002, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.5 (PowerPC) and Mac OS X Server v10.4.5
The download file is named: "SecUpd2006-002Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is: b30acb6dda4fc1b2c9372c7da79763d42fa5e025

For Mac OS X v10.4.5 (Intel)
The download file is named: "SecUpd2006-002Intel.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is: 90166d4a40491364a0fd041216dc9d40c6430968

Title: Sun Solaris Memory Leak in Proc Pagedata Subsystem Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Solaris proc file system.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
The pagedata subsystem of the process file system "/proc" (proc(4)) contains a memory leak.  A local user can trigger a null pointer dereference to cause performance degradation, cause the system to hang, or cause a kernel panic.
Impact': A local user can cause system performance to degrade or cause the system to hang or crash.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 117350-33 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 118558-22 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118822-29 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 117351-33 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 118559-22 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118844-29 or later

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102159-1

Title: Sun Solaris Unspecified hsfs File System Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service and Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in the HSFS file system.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions or gain elevated privileges.
The Solaris file system driver for hsfs(7FS) file systems contains an unspecified vulnerability.  A local user may be able to cause a system panic.  A local user may also be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
Impact':
A local user can cause a system panic.

A local user can execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.

SPARC platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 109764-06 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 116047-03 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 119596-03 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 109765-06 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 121995-01 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118813-03 or later

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102161-1

Title: SCO UnixWare ptrace Lets Local Users Inject Code into setuid Processes to Obtain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a vulnerability in SCO UnixWare in ptrace.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
The ptrace() system call does not properly check the permissions of processes before attaching to them.  A local user can invoke ptrace to attach to a process with set user id (setuid) root user privileges.  Then, the user can inject arbitrary data into the process to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

The vendor was notified on September 15, 2005.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.iDefense.com/application/poi/display?type=vulnerabilities
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.

UnixWare 7.1.3

	Location of Fixed Binaries

	ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/SCOSA-2006.9


	Verification

	a31512eee4940c6ba048a1b1878ac4fc  p533176.713.image

	Installing Fixed Binaries

	# pkgadd -d /var/spool/pkg/p533176.713.image


UnixWare 7.1.4

	Location of Fixed Binaries

	ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/SCOSA-2006.9


	Verification

	1b8fa986357036a8be043b642cc47e56  p533176.714.image

	Installing Fixed Binaries

	Upgrade the affected binaries with the following sequence:

	Download p533176.714.image to the /var/spool/pkg directory

	# pkgadd -d /var/spool/pkg/p533176.714.image

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/SCOSA-2006.9/SCOSA-2006.9.txt

Title: Sun Solaris in.rexecd(1M) on Kerberos Systems Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in rexecd on Sun Solaris when running Kerberos.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges.
A local user can exploit an unspecified flaw in the in.rexecd(1M) daemon running on Kerberos systems to overwrite thread-specific data and obtain elevated privileges.

Solaris 8 and Solaris 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 120329-02 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 120330-02 or later

Title: Mac OS X Undocumented System Call Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X kernel.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can invoke an undocumented system call to cause the kernel to crash.

The vendor credits David Goldsmith of Matasano with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix as part of Mac OS X 10.4.5, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.4 (PowerPC)
The download file is named:  "MacOSXUpd10.4.5PPC.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  c794af16563470fb16610bbaecedb59624a24dee

For Mac OS X v10.4.4 (Intel)
The download file is named:  "MacOSXUpd10.4.5Intel.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  23def8fb52839c008d313c7cd301aa16efbdfd64

For Mac OS X v10.4 through Mac OS X v10.4.3
The download file is named:  "MacOSXUpdCombo10.4.5PPC.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  1e1309d0a37aeb8fb42cf92480d2bba2db3372db

For Mac OS X Server v10.4.4

Title: (IBM Issues Fix for AIX 5.3) IBM AIX lscfg Command May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in AIX.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
The AIX 'lscfg' command creates temporary trace files in an unsafe manner.  A local user can create a symbolic link (symlink) from a critical file on the system to a temporary file to be used by the lscfg command.  Then, when the command is run by the target user, the symlinked file will be modified with the privileges of the target user.

This may allow the allow the user to corrupt system files or potentially obtain root privileges on the target system.
Impact': A local user can corrupt system files and may be able to gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
IBM has issued the following fixes:

AIX Version     APAR Number     Availability    Corresponding Filesets
- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5.2.0           IY77624         available       devices.chrp.base.rte 5.2.0.85
5.3.0           IY77638         available       devices.chrp.base.rte 5.3.0.40

AIX Version 5 APARs can be downloaded from:

    http://www-03.ibm.com/servers/eserver/support/unixservers/aixfixes.html

Security related Interim Fixes can be downloaded from:

    ftp://aix.software.ibm.com/aix/efixes/security

Title: (HP Issues Revised Patch) HP Tru64 UNIX TruCluster Server Interconnect Has an Unspecified Flaw That May Let Remote Users Crash the Server
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the HP Tru64 UNIX TruCluster Server Interconnect.  A remote or local user may be able to cause the server to crash.
HP issued a security bulletin warning of a potential security flaw in HP TruCluster Server Interconnect.  A remote or local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote or local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
HP has issued a revised Early Release Patch (ERP) for V5.1.  The following ERPs are available.

HP TruCluster Server 5.1A:
Prerequisite: V5.1A with Patch Kit 3 (BL3) installed
ERP Kit Name: tcv51ab3-c0008601-15346-es-20020905.tar
Kit Location: http://ftp1.support.compaq.com/public/unix/v5.1a/

HP TruCluster Server 5.1:
Prerequisite: V5.1 with Patch Kit 6 (BL20) installed
ERP Kit Name: TCV51B20-C0035800-17180-ES-20030304.tar
Kit Location: http://ftp1.support.compaq.com/public/unix/v5.1/

HP TruCluster Server 5.1:
Prerequisite: V5.1 with Patch Kit 5 (BL19) installed
ERP Kit Name: tcv51b19-c0030403-15347-es-20020905.tar
Kit Location: http://ftp1.support.compaq.com/public/unix/v5.1/

HP TruCluster Server 5.1 with PK4(BL18) installed: update to a minimum of PK5 (BL19) then install

ERP tcv51b19-c0030403-15347-es-20020905.tar

HP TruCluster Server 5.0A
Prerequisite: V5.0A with Patch Kit 3 (BL17) installed
ERP Kit Name: tcv50ab17-c0005202-15352-es-20020905.tar
Kit Location: http://www1.itrc.hp.com/service/home/home.do?lang=en&cc=us&LANGUAGE_OPTION=english&admit=-682735245+1134404058068+28353476

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=HPSBTU01185

Title: FreeBSD TCP SACK Processing May Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the TCP/IP stack.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
If there is insufficient memory available on the target system to process an incoming selective acknowledgement (SACK), the TCP/IP stack may enter an infinite loop.  A remote user can open a TCP connection to the target system and send a specially crafted series of packets to cause denial of service conditions.

Scott Wood is credited with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause a denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following solution instructions [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 5-STABLE or to the RELENG_5_4 or
RELENG_5_3 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patch have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5.3 and
5.4 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:08/sack.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:08/sack.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in
<URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the
system.

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.freebsd.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:08.sack.asc

Title: Solaris 10 x64 Kernel setcontext() Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris 10 in the x64 kernel.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can invoke a setcontext() call to trigger a system panic on x64 platforms when running in 64-bit mode.

SPARC and 32-bit x86 platforms are not affected.

Solaris 8 and Solaris 9 are not affected because they don't support for the x64 architecture.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version:

Solaris 10 with patch 118844-14 or later

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/search/document.do?assetkey=1-26-102149-1

Title: FreeBSD pf(4) Scrub Rule Error Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the pf(4) packet filter function.  A remote user can cause the kernel to crash.
A remote user can send specially crafted IP packet fragments to trigger a logic error in writing to the pf IP fragment cache when the 'scrub fragment crop' or 'scrub fragment drop-ovl' rules are used.  The packet fragment may be inserted twice, causing the kernel to crash.

Systems that do not use pf are not affected.

Systems that do not use the 'scrub fragment crop' or 'scrub fragment drop-ovl' pf rules are also not affected.

The vendor credits Jakob Schlyter and Daniel Hartmeier with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 5-STABLE or 6-STABLE, or to the
RELENG_6_0, RELENG_5_4, or RELENG_5_3 security branch dated after the
correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5.3, 5.4,
and 6.0 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:07/pf.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:07/pf.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in
<URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the
system.

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.freebsd.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:07.pf.asc

Title: FreeBSD Kernel ioctl() Functions May Disclose Kernel Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD kernel.  A local user can obtain portions of kernel memory.
A buffer allocated from the kernel stack may not be properly initialized before being copied to user-controlled memory [CVE-2006-0379].

A logic error in determining the appropriate buffer length may cause too much data to be copied to user-controlled memory [CVE-2006-0380].

The vendor credits Xin LI and Karl Janmar with reporting these vulnerabilities.
Impact': A local user can obtain portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 5-STABLE or 6-STABLE, or to the
RELENG_6_0 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5.4 and 6.0
systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 5.4-STABLE and 6.0-STABLE]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:06/kmem.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:06/kmem.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 6.0-RELEASE]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:06/kmem60.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:06/kmem60.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in
<URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the
system.

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.freebsd.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/advisories/FreeBSD-SA-06:06.kmem.asc

Title: HP-UX Unspecified Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
No further details were provided.

The vendor credits NCC Group with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
HP has issued a fix, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

HP-UX B.11.00:  PHCO_29249

HP-UX B.11.04:  PHCO_32280

HP-UX B.11.11:  PHCO_30402

Title: FreeBSD 802.11 Response Frame Integer Overflow May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the 802.11 implementation.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
The IEEE 802.11 network subsystem of FreeBSD contains an integer overflow in the processing of IEEE 802.11 beacon or probe response frames when scanning for existing wireless networks.  A remote user with the ability to broadcast a specially crafted beacon or probe response frame may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target system.

Karl Janmar discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.signedness.org/advisories/sps-0x1.txt
Impact': A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target system with kernel-level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 6-STABLE or to the RELENG_6_0
security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 6.0 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the
detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:05/80211.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-06:05/80211.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in
<URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the
system.

Title: Solaris find Command Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris in the find command.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local unprivileged user can invoke find(1) to search against the "/proc" filesystem to trigger a kernel panic.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause a system panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118822-24 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118844-24 or later

Title: Solaris x86 mm Driver Lets Local Users Gain Root Access
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris in the mm driver.  A local user may be able to gain root access or cause a kernel panic.
A local user can exploit the mm(5) driver to obtain root privileges or trigger a kernel panic.

x86-based systems running Solaris 9 or 10 and with patch 112234-11, 112234-12, or 117172-16 installed are affected.

Solaris 8 is not affected.

SPARC-based systems are not affected.
Impact':
A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.

A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 9 with patch 118559-19 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118844-24 or later

Title: NetBSD settimeofday() Lets Certain Local Users Set the Time Backwards
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD in the settimeofday() function.  A local user with certain permissions can set the time backwards.
A local user with securelevel permissions greater than "1" can invoke settimeofday() to cause the clock time to wrap to "Fri Dec 13 20:45:52 UTC 1901" which then allows the user to set any time value.  As a result, the local user can move the time backwards.

The vendor credits Markus Vervier from RedTeam Pentesting with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user with securelevel > 1 permissions can set the time backwards.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a kernel fix.

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2006-002.txt.asc

Title: OpenBSD Kernel dupfdopen() Bug May Let Local Users Re-open Files With Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the OpenBSD kernel in the dupfdopen() function.  The impact was not specified.
A local user may be able to cause an application that has set user id (setuid) privileges to reopen certain files.
Impact': The impact was not specified.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.8/common/002_fd.patch

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.7/common/008_fd.patch

Title: IBM AIX getcommand/getshell Commands Disclose Contents of Shell Files to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX.  A local user can view shell documents.  A local user can determine if files exist on the target system.
The getCommand and getShell commands allow a local user to determine if a file exists or not because the commands return different information if a non-existent file is specified.

A local user can also view shell files on the target system.

A demonstration exploit command is provided:

./getCommand.new ../../../../../tmp/k.sh

The vendor was notified on December 26, 2005.

XFOCUS discovered these vulnerabilities.
Impact':
A local user can view the contents of shell documents on the target system.

A local user can determine if files exist on the target system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: IBM AIX Buffer Overflow in slocal Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM's AIX operating system in slocal.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges.
A local user can invoke slocal to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

David Litchfield of NGS Software reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges.
Solution:
IBM plans to issue the following fixes, available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/servers/eserver/support/pseries/aixfixes.html

      APAR number for AIX 5.1.0: IY78224 (available approx. 01/30/06)
      APAR number for AIX 5.2.0: IY78225 (available approx. 01/30/06) 
      APAR number for AIX 5.3.0: IY78226 (available approx. 01/30/06)

An Interim fix is available at:

ftp://aix.software.ibm.com/aix/efixes/security/slocal_ifix.tar.Z

Title: IBM AIX Buffer Overflow in muxatmd Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM's AIX operating system in muxatmd.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges.
A local user can invoke muxatmd to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

David Litchfield of NGS Software reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges.
Solution:
IBM plans to issue the following fixes:

      APAR number for AIX 5.1.0: IY78221 (available approx. 01/30/06)
      APAR number for AIX 5.2.0: IY78222 (available approx. 01/30/06) 
      APAR number for AIX 5.3.0: IY78223 (available approx. 01/30/06)

An Interim Fix is available at:

ftp://aix.software.ibm.com/aix/efixes/security/libisode_ifix.tar.Z

Title: HP-UX TCP/IP Stack May Consume Excessive System Resources When Under IP Fragment Attacks
Version(s): HP-UX B.11.00, B.11.04, B.11.11, B.11.23 running TCP/IP.
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX in the TCP-IP implementation.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
No further details were provided.

[Editor's note:  In their advisory, HP referenced CVE-2004-0744, which covers a denial of service vulnerability in the TCP-IP stack on Apple Mac OS X.  Apple reported that a remote user can conduct a "Rose Attack", sending specially crafted IP fragments to cause the target system to consume excessive system resources, which can prevent legitimate connections.  See Alert ID 1010905.]
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to consume excessive system resources.
Solution:
The vendor has issued patches, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

In addition to the patch, a system parameter must also be set.  See the vendor's advisory for specific instructions:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00579189

For B.11.00:

install PHNE_33395 or subsequent
then run "sqmax 1000"

For B.11.04:

install PHNE_33427 or subsequent
then run "sqmax 1000"

For B.11.11:

install PHNE_31091 or subsequent
then run "sqmax 1000"

For B.11.23:

install PHKL_31500
sqmax not required

Title: SCO UnixWare uidadmin '-S' Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a vulnerability in uidadmin on SCO UnixWare.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
The uidadmin command does not properly limit the length of user-supplied file names when invoked with the '-S' command line switch. A local user can supply a specially crafted file name that is longer than 1,600 bytes to trigger a buffer overflow.  Arbitrary code can be executed with root level privileges.

The vendor was notified on October 12, 2005.

iDefense Labs discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.idefense.com/application/poi/display?id=350&type=vulnerabilities
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix, available at:

ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/SCOSA-2005.54

The vendor's advisory is available at:

ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/SCOSA-2005.54/SCOSA-2005.54.txt

Title: Sun Solaris Sun Update Connection Services May Disclose Web Proxy Password to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris when running Sun Update Connection Services.  A local user may be able to obtain the web proxy password.
A local user may be able to view the web proxy password.  No details were provided.

Also, a local user on the web proxy server may be able to view the web proxy password in the web proxy log files.

Sun credits Nicholas Brealey of Culham Electromagnetics and Lightning with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain the web proxy password.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 119107-04 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 119108-04 or later

Title: IBM AIX umountall Absolute Path Bug Has Unspecified Impact
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX in the umountall command.  The impact was not specified.
The '/usr/sbin/umountall' command contains an unspecified 'absolute path' flaw.  No further details were provided.
Impact': The impact was not specified.
Solution:
The vendor has issued APARs IY75294, IY75283, and IY79485.

The vendor's advisories are available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY75283
http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY75294
http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY79485

Title: Mac OS X syslog May Let Local Users Forge Log Entries
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in syslog on Mac OS X.  A local user may be able to obfuscate or forge log entries.
A local user can submit syslog messages that contain specially crafted control characters, such as the newline character, to forge entries in the log.  As a result, a system administrator may be mislead by the entries.

Systems prior to Mac OS X version 10.4 are not affected.

Apple credits HELIOS Software GmbH with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to forge syslog entries.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2005-009, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.3
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-009Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  544f51a7bc73a57dbca95e05693904aadb2f94b1

For Mac OS X Server v10.4.3
The download file is named:  "SecUpdSrvr2005-009Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  b7620426151b8f1073c9ff73b2adf43b3086cc60

Title: Mac OS X passwordserver May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in passwordserver.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
When an Open Directory master server is created, credentials may be compromised.  As a result, a local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2005-009, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.3

Title: Mac OS X iodbcadmintool Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in iodbcadmintool.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
The iodbcadmintool (a helper tool included with the ODBC Administrator utility) includes a helper tool contains an unspecified flaw.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary commands on the target system with elevated privileges.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary commands with elevated privileges.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2005-009, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.3
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-009Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  544f51a7bc73a57dbca95e05693904aadb2f94b1

For Mac OS X Server v10.4.3
The download file is named:  "SecUpdSrvr2005-009Ti.dmg"

For Mac OS X v10.3.9

Title: Mac OS X CoreFoundation Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in CoreFoundation.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed.
A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when resolved via CoreFoundation will trigger a buffer overflow and cause a crash or cause arbitrary code to be executed.

CoreFoundation is used by Safari and other applications.

Systems prior to Mac OS X version 10.4 are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when resolved via CoreFoundation, will cause a crash or cause arbitrary code to be executed.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2005-009, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.3
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-009Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  544f51a7bc73a57dbca95e05693904aadb2f94b1

For Mac OS X Server v10.4.3
The download file is named:  "SecUpdSrvr2005-009Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  b7620426151b8f1073c9ff73b2adf43b3086cc60

Title: IBM AIX diagela Absolute Path Vulnerability Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM AIX in the Automatic Error Log Analysis (diagela) command.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges.
The '/usr/lpp/diagnostics/bin/diagela.sh' command has a security vulnerability related to the specification of (or lack of specification of) an absolute path.  A local user that is in the system group and that has the RunDiagnostics role can execute arbitrary code on the target system.

IBM indicates that exploit code is publicly available.
Impact': A local user in the system group with the RunDiagnostics role can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
Solution:
IBM plans to issue the following fixes:

APAR number for AIX 5.1.0: IY78926 (available approx. 01/18/06)
APAR number for AIX 5.2.0: IY78800 (available approx. 01/30/06)
APAR number for AIX 5.3.0: IY78801 (available approx. 01/30/06)

An Interim Fix is available at:

ftp://aix.software.ibm.com/aix/efixes/security/diagela_ifix.tar.Z

The vendor's advisories are available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY78800
http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY78801

Title: Sun Solaris IKE Processing Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in the 'libike' library.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a specially crafted IKE packet to cause the in.iked(1M) process to crash.

Solaris 8 is not affected.
Impact': A remote user can cause the IKE daemon to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 9 with patch 113451-10 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118371-06 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 9 with patch 114435-09 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 118372-06 or later

Title: Sun Solaris in.named Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in the name service daemon.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can cause in.named(1M) to make unnecessary queries for address records to root domain servers.  This can be triggered by requests for domains that the target server is not authoritative for.  The system will then query the root server, even though the results are cached locally.  As a result, systems that use the Domain Name System may fail.

Solaris 8 and Solaris 10 are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the target DNS service.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 9 with patch 112970-09 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 9 with patch 114354-08 or later

Title: HP-UX Trusted Mode Unspecified remshd Bug Lets Remote Users Access the System
Version(s): HP-UX B.11.00, B.11.11, and B.11.23; running in Trusted Mode
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX Trusted Mode systems.  A remote user may be able to access the system.
The remshd daemon contains an unspecified vulnerability.  A remote user can gain unauthorized access on the target system.

HP-UX systems running in Trusted Mode are affected.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote user may be able to access the system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

HP-UX B.11.00 PHNE_33790 or subsequent
HP-UX B.11.11 PHNE_33791 or subsequent
HP-UX B.11.23 PHNE_33792 or subsequent

Title: HP-UX envd Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX envd.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
A local user can exploit HP-UX systems running the envd(1M) to execute arbitrary code and/or gain elevated privileges.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixes, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

HP-UX B.11.00 PHCO_33989 or subsequent
HP-UX B.11.11 PHCO_33967 or subsequent

Title: NetBSD Bugs in Kernel, Networking, and Application Code May Let Local Users Deny Service or Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in NetBSD.  A local user may be able to deny service or potentially obtain elevated privileges.
The IPsec-AH calculation is always based on the same key in AES-XCBC-MAC.

A user may be able to specify negative offsets when reading the message buffer to read arbitrary kernel memory.

The imake(1) function uses unsafe temporary files, which may allow a local user to gain elevated privileges.

A bug exists in the sh(1) command, affecting big endian systems.  A buffer underflow may occur when evaluating output from a back tick substitution, causing the system to crash.

Several other kernel and networking bugs exist that may allow a local user to deny service.  A remote user may be able to deny service in certain cases.
Impact':
A local user may be able to cause the system to crash.

A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.

In some cases, a remote user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (2.0.3), available as a source only update.

The list of download sites is available at at:

http://www.NetBSD.org/mirrors/

Title: Mac OS X Kernel May Disclose Memory Contents to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X kernel.  A local user may be able to obtain kernel memory.
A local user may be able to invoke certain kernel interfaces to obtain portions of unitialized kernel memory, which may contain sensitive information.
Impact': A local user can obtain portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix as part of Mac OS X v10.4.3, available via the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Mac OS X memberd Membership Changes May Be Significantly Delayed
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in memberd.  Changes made to group membership may be delayed.
The group membership cache may not be properly flushed.  In certain situations, changes made to a group's membership via memberd may not be enforced for a time period of up to several hours.  As a result, a remote authenticated user may be able to access files or other resources even after the user has been removed from a group.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.
Impact': Changes made to group membership may be delayed.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix as part of Mac OS X v10.4.3, available via the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Mac OS X Software Update Bug May Prevent Updates from Installing
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in Software Update.  Some important updates may not be installed.
If a user instructs Software Update to ignore all applicable updates, Software Update will exit without providing the user with the ability to reset the selection.  As a result, some important updates may be skipped.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.
Impact': Some important updates may not be installed.
Solution:

Title: Mac OS X Finder May Display Misleading Ownership Information
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in Finder.  The system may display misleading file ownership information.
The Finder utility may display incorrect file and group ownership information in the Finder Get Info window.  In certain cases, the displayed ownership information is not synchronized with the actual ownership information.

Systems prior to Mac OS X v10.4 are not affected.
Impact': The system may display misleading file ownership information.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix as part of Mac OS X v10.4.3, available via the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.2
The download file is named:  "MacOSXUpdate10.4.3.dmg"
