Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: OpenBSD sysctl(3) Flaw Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
OpenBSD has issued the following fixes for OpenBSD 3.4 and 3.3:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.4/common/007_uvm.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.3/common/012_uvm.patch

Title: OpenBSD semctl() and semop() Bugs Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the OpenBSD in semctl() and semop() functions.  A local user can cause the kernel to crash.
It is reported that a local user can supply specially crafted arguments to the semctl(2) or semop(2) system calls to cause the system to crash.  The flaw is reportedly due to improper bounds checking in 'sysv_sem.c'.
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
OpenBSD has issued the following fixes:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.4/common/008_sem.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.3/common/013_sem.patch

Title: OpenBSD sysctl(3) Flaw Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: IBM AIX rcp Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the rcp command on IBM's AIX operating system.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the system.
It is reported that a local user may be able execute arbitrary code wtih root privileges.

IBM notes that the flaw was discovered during an internal review.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain root privileges.
Solution:
IBM has issued the following fixes:

APAR number for AIX 4.3.3: IY48272 (available)
APAR number for AIX 5.1.0: IY48747 (available)
APAR number for AIX 5.2.0: IY49238 (available)

Title: (OpenBSD Issues Fix for 3.3) OpenBSD Kernel ibcs Overflow Yields Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the OpenBSD kernel.  A local user can execute arbitrary code to gain root privileges.
Georgi Guninski reported that there is a stack based kernel overflow in OpenBSD in the 'ibcs2_exec.c'.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message and in the original advisory.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.guninski.com/msuxobsd2.html

The vendor was reportedly notified on November 15, 2003.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges.
Solution:
OpenBSD has released a fix for OpenBSD 3.3 (in addition to the previously reported patch for OpenBSD 3.4):

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.4/i386/006_ibcs2.patch

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.3/i386/011_ibcs2.patch

Title: Mac OS X Predictable TCP Timestamps Disclose Uptime to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X operating system in the generation of TCP timestamp values.  A remote user can gain information about system up-time.
It is reported that the TCP timestamp is initialized with a constant number.  A remote user can inspect the values to determine how long the system has been up.

Apple credits Aaron Linville with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can determine how long the system has been up.
Solution: Apple has released a fix as part of Mac OS X 10.3 Panther.

Title: Mac OS X Secure System Preferences Can Be Accessed By Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in controlling access to the System Preferences.  A local user may be able to access some Preference Panes without proper privileges.
It is reported that after an administrator has authenticated to the system, a local user can gain unauthorized access to secure Preference Panes for a short period of time.

Apple credits Anthony Holder with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A local user can access some secure System Preference panes.
Solution: Apple has released a fix as part of Mac OS X 10.3 Panther.

Title: OpenBSD Kernel ibcs Overflow Yields Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the OpenBSD kernel.  A local user can execute arbitrary code to gain root privileges.
Georgi Guninski reported that there is a stack based kernel overflow in OpenBSD in the 'ibcs2_exec.c'.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message and in the original advisory.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.guninski.com/msuxobsd2.html

The vendor was reportedly notified on November 15, 2003.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for OpenBSD 3.4, available via CVS at:

http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb/src/sys/compat/ibcs2/ibcs2_exec.c.diff?r1=1.14.6.1&r2=1.14.6.2 

Fixes for earlier versions will reportedly be made available shortly.

Title: (Sun Issues Fix) Re: Solaris cachefsd cfsd_calloc() Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A heap overflow vulnerability was reported in the Solaris cachefsd daemon.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
In May 2002, the Last Stage of Delirium reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted cache name to trigger an overflow in the cfsd_calloc() function. Arbitrary code can be executed with root privileges on the target system.

A demonstration exploit trace is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC

     * Solaris 2.5.1 with patch 104849-09 or later
     * Solaris 2.6 with patch 105693-13 or later
     * Solaris 7 with patch 108800-02 or later
     * Solaris 8 with patch 110896-02 or later
     * Solaris 9 with patch 114008-01 or later

x86 Platform

     * Solaris 2.5.1 with patch 104848-09 or later
     * Solaris 2.6 with patch 105694-13 or later
     * Solaris 7 with patch 108801-02 or later
     * Solaris 8 with patch 110897-02 or later
     * Solaris 9 with patch 114009-01 or later

Title: Solaris cachefsd cfsd_calloc() Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A heap overflow vulnerability was reported in the Solaris cachefsd daemon.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
In May 2002, the Last Stage of Delirium reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted cache name to trigger an overflow in the cfsd_calloc() function. Arbitrary code can be executed with root privileges on the target system.

A demonstration exploit trace is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of the original report.

Title: HP-UX Partition Manager (parmgr) Certification Validation Flaw May Grant Access to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP-UX in the Partition Manager.  A remote user may be able to gain access to the system.
HP reported that parmgr(1M) does not properly validate certificates sent from the 'cimserver'.  A remote or local user may be able to compromise the target system.

Only HP-UX version B.11.23 is affected, according to the report.
Impact': A remote user can gain information about the target system and gain access to the target system.
Solution:
HP has released a fixed version (B.11.23.02.00), available at:

http://software.hp.com/portal/swdepot/displayProductInfo.do?productNumber=ParMgr

The software can be installed using Software Distributor (SD).

Title: (SCO Issues Fix) Re: SCO UNIX procfs 'as' Access Control Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in SCO UnixWare and Open UNIX in the processing of procfs descriptors.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Texonet reported that a local user can bypass security restrictions on the process ID address space image file ('/proc/$PID/as') and write to the file.

A local user can obtain a file descriptor for a process owned by the local user and then have that process call the execve() function for a binary that has set user id (setuid) permissions.  According to the report, the execve() function will replace the process image and provide setuid privileges while the descriptor remains open.  The local user can then write to the file to obtain setuid privileges.

The following notification timeline is provide:

10/24/2003: Vendor notified by e-mail
11/12/2003: Public release of advisory
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges, including root level privileges, on the target system.
Solution:
SCO has issued the following fixes:

For UnixWare 7.1.3:

ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/CSSA-2003-SCO.32

SCO notes that erg712482c should only be installed on UnixWare 7.1.3.

The verification checksum is:

MD5 (erg712482c.Z) = 50c98884a6dcb14ccf57d71aad135045

For Open UNIX 8.0.0:

ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/CSSA-2003-SCO.32

SCO notes that erg712482b should only be installed on UnixWare 7.1.2 or Open UNIX 8.0.0.

The verification checksum is:

MD5 (erg712482b.Z) = 54d3568e631d4739034815537242dc0d

For UnixWare 7.1.1:

ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/CSSA-2003-SCO.32

SCO notes that erg712482a should only be installed on UnixWare 7.1.1.

The verification checksum is:

MD5 (erg712482a.Z) = 15776bcbaf01155eb28087ee213fecf8

See the Source Message for installation instructions.

Title: SCO UNIX procfs 'as' Access Control Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in SCO UnixWare and Open UNIX in the processing of procfs descriptors.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Texonet reported that a local user can bypass security restrictions on the process ID address space image file ('/proc/$PID/as') and write to the file.

A local user can obtain a file descriptor for a process owned by the local user and then have that process call the execve() function for a binary that has set user id (setuid) permissions.  According to the report, the execve() function will replace the process image and provide setuid privileges while the descriptor remains open.  The local user can then write to the file to obtain setuid privileges.

The following notification timeline is provide:

10/24/2003: Vendor notified by e-mail
11/12/2003: Public release of advisory
Impact': A local user can obtain elevated privileges, including root level privileges, on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly issued fixes for UnixWare 7.1.1, UnixWare 7.1.3 and Open UNIX 8.0.0 [a separate Alert will be issued containing the vendor's official advisory]:

ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/UnixWare/CSSA-2003-SCO.32

Title: OpenBSD Kernel Bug in Processing File Headers Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the OpenBSD kernel.  A local user can trigger a kernel panic.
Georgi Guninski reported that a local user can execute a specially crafted binary on the target system to cause a kernel panic. OpenBSD indicated that an invalid header in the binary can trigger the flaw and that the flaw resides in 'ibcs2_exec.c' and 'exec_elf.c'.

Some demonstration exploit code is available at:

http://www.guninski.com/msuxobsd.c
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
OpenBSD has issued the following fixes:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.3/common/010_exec.patch
ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.4/common/005_exec.patch

Title: SCO OpenServer Scripts Use of Unsafe Temporary Files May Give Local Users Elevated Privileges
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in some SCO OpenServer scripts.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges on the system.
It is reported that several scripts create, read, or write files in the '/tmp' directory in an unsafe manner.  A local user can create a symbolic link (symlink) from a critical file on the system to a temporary file to be used by one of the scripts.  Then, when the affected script is executed, it may be possible for the local user to cause the symlinked file to be overwritten or modified with elevated privileges.

The following binaries are reportedly affected:

/etc/init.d/VDISK
/etc/init.d/VDRESTORE
/etc/tcp
/usr/lib/mkdev/hostmib
/etc/init.d/hostmib
/etc/nfs
/etc/nis
/etc/rpcinit
/usr/lib/cleantmp
Impact': A local user may be able to modify files with elevated privileges to gain elevated privileges on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix for OpenServer 5.0.5:

Location of Fixed Binaries

	ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/updates/OpenServer/CSSA-2003-SCO.27

Verification

	MD5 (VOL.000.000) = 24ea1000e89272a3d2f12d9fd05de83f

Installing Fixed Binaries

Upgrade the affected binaries with the following sequence:

1) Download the VOL* files to the /tmp directory

2) Run the custom command, specify an install from media images, and specify the /tmp directory as the location of the images.

SCO reports that OpenServer 5.0.6 and later include a fix for these flaws.

Title: Sun Solaris pipe(2) Race Condition May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A race condition vulnerability was reported in the Sun Solaris operating system.  A local user may be able to trigger a kernel panic.
A local user can reportedly exploit the "namefs" pipe(2) command and certain unspecified STREAMS routines to cause a kernel panic. The report indicates that when a Solaris system is functioning as a print server, high loads may also trigger a kernel panic.

Sun reports that the flaw is "most likely" to occur on systems that have more than one CPU.
Impact': A local user may be able to cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued a fix in the following releases:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 114941-01 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 114944-01 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 114984-01 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 114971-01 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 114942-01 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 114945-01 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 114985-01 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 114972-01 or later

Title: Sun Solaris sysinfo(2) May Disclose Kernel Memory to Local Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Sun Solaris sysinfo(2) system call.  A local user may be able to read kernel memory.
It is reported that a flaw in the Solaris sysinfo(2) system call may allow a local user to read portions of kernel memory.  The kernel memory may contain sensitive data that may allow the local user to gain elevated privileges on the system.
Impact': A local user may be able to view portions of the operating system kernel memory.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 105181-35 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 106541-27 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 108528-24 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 112233-01 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 105182-35 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 106542-27 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 108529-24 or later

Title: (OpenBSD Issues Fix) Re: BSD arplookup() May Let Local Subnet Users Crash the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X and other BSD-based operating systems.  A remote user on a local subnet can consume all available operating system memory on the target system.
It is reported that a remote user on the local subnet can send a number of spoofed address resolution protocol (ARP) requests to the target system to cause kernel memory to become exhausted.  As a result, denial of service conditions may occur.  This is reportedly due to a flaw in the arplookup() function.

According to FreeBSD, various BSD-derived systems may be affected, as the vulnerable code dates well back to the CSRG branches.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
The following patch is available for OpenBSD 3.3:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.3/common/008_arp.patch

Title: FreeBSD Kernel procfs uiomove() Overflow Discloses Sensitive Kernel Memory to Local Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD kernel in procfs.  A local user may be able to cause the system to crash.  A local user may be able to view kernel memory, which could lead to privilege escalation.
It is reported that Joost Pol discovered a flaw in the process file system [procfs(5)].  In the uiomove(9) system call, components of the 'struct uio' variable are not properly validated.  A local user can reportedly set the 'uio_offset' parameter to be "extremely" large or negative to cause the kernel to crash or cause the function to return a large potion of kernel memory to the user.  The memory may contain sensitive information.
Impact': A local user can cause the kernel to crash.  A local user may be able to view a large portion of kernel memory, which may contain sensitive information that would allow the local user to gain elevated privileges on the system.
Solution:
FreeBSD has issued a fix.  You can upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE, or to the RELENG_5_1, RELENG_4_8, or RELENG_4_7 security branch dated after the correction date [see the Source Message for the correction dates].

To patch your system:

Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

[FreeBSD 4.3]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:17/procfs43.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:17/procfs43.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 4.4 and later 4.x]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:17/procfs4x.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:17/procfs4x.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.0]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:17/procfs50.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:17/procfs50.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.1]
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:17/procfs51.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:17/procfs51.patch.asc

Then, apply the patch:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

Then, recompile your kernel as described in:

http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html

Then, reboot the system.

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Fix) FreeBSD Kernel readv(2) Integer Overflow Lets Local Users Crash the System or Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD operating system kernel in the readv(2) system call.  A local user can cause the kernel to crash.  A local user may be able to gain read and write access to files on the system to obtain elevated privileges.
Pine Digital Security reported that the readv(2) system call fails to make a call to the fdrop() function at a particular point. A local user can reportedly issue a readv(2) call and supply an oversized 'iovcnt' parameter to cause the system call to fail to release the associated file reference.  As a result, a local user can repeatedly call readv(2) on a file descriptor until the reference counter (int f_count) wraps to a negative value and then call close() on that file descriptor to cause a kernel panic.

In a similar fashion, a local user may be able to cause a file descriptor to reference unallocated kernel memory while remaining valid.  If the kernel later opens a new file allocating the new file structure at the same (previously unallocated) memory location, then the local user may be able to gain read or write access to the file.  This can lead to privilege escalation, the report said.

According to the report, FreeBSD 5.x versions are not affected.

The vendor was reportedly notified on September 23, 2003.
Impact':
A local user may be able to cause a kernel panic.

A local user may be able to read or modify files with higher privileges, thereby obtain elevated privileges on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch for FreeBSD 4.3, 4.4, 4.5, 4.6, 4.7, and 4.8 systems:

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:16/filedesc.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:16/filedesc.patch.asc

Apply the patch with the following commands:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

Then, recompile the kernel as described in:

http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html

Then, reboot the system.

Title: FreeBSD Kernel readv(2) Integer Overflow Lets Local Users Crash the System or Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD operating system kernel in the readv(2) system call.  A local user can cause the kernel to crash.  A local user may be able to gain read and write access to files on the system to obtain elevated privileges.
Pine Digital Security reported that the readv(2) system call fails to make a call to the fdrop() function at a particular point. A local user can reportedly issue a readv(2) call and supply an oversized 'iovcnt' parameter to cause the system call to fail to release the associated file reference.  As a result, a local user can repeatedly call readv(2) on a file descriptor until the reference counter (int f_count) wraps to a negative value and then call close() on that file descriptor to cause a kernel panic.

In a similar fashion, a local user may be able to cause a file descriptor to reference unallocated kernel memory while remaining valid.  If the kernel later opens a new file allocating the new file structure at the same (previously unallocated) memory location, then the local user may be able to gain read or write access to the file.  This can lead to privilege escalation, the report said.

According to the report, FreeBSD 5.x versions are not affected.

The vendor was reportedly notified on September 23, 2003.
Impact':
A local user may be able to cause a kernel panic.

A local user may be able to read or modify files with higher privileges, thereby obtain elevated privileges on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix, available via CVS.

The following patch is also available for FreeBSD 4.3, 4.4, 4.5, 4.6, 4.7, and 4.8 systems:

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:16/filedesc.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:16/filedesc.patch.asc

Title: IBM AIX getipnodebyname() Socket Closure Flaw Lets Users Create Denial of Service Conditions
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the IBM AIX operating system in the getipnodebyname() API.  A remote or local user can create denial of service conditions.
It is reported that, in certain situations, the getipnodebyname() API does not close sockets.  A remote or local user can attempt to deny service via an application that uses this API.

IBM notes that the only application that ships with AIX that uses the vulnerable API is the Sendmail program.

[Editor's note:  IBM's advisory mentions the incorrect CVE number.  The correct CVE number is CVE-2003-0696.]
Impact': A remote or local user can create denial of service conditions for applications that use the getipnodebyname() function.
Solution:
IBM has issued a fix:

APAR number for AIX 5.1.0:  IY46273 (available)
APAR number for AIX 5.2.0:  IY46024 (available)

AIX Version 5 APARs are available at the eServer pSeries Support web site:

https://techsupport.services.ibm.com/server/aix.fdc

Title: (HP Issues Updated Fix) HP/UX 'ipcs' Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the ipcs interprocess communication status utility on the HP/UX operating system.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
It is reported that a local user can trigger a buffer overflow in /usr/bin/ipcs.  It may be possible to exploit the overflow to execute arbitrary code on the system with 'sys' group privileges, but that was not confirmed in the report.

A demonstration exploit is provided:

/usr/bin/ipcs -C `perl -e 'print "A" x 2232'`
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated ('sys' group) privileges on the system.
Solution:
HP has released a general release patch.  HP reports that if you have previously installed the temporary depot, you must remove the temporary depot before applying the new general release patch.

You can remove the temporary depot using Software Distributor (SD), then apply PHCO_29043 for release HP-UX B.11.00.

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Fix) arplookup() May Let Local Subnet Users Crash the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X and other BSD-based operating systems.  A remote user on a local subnet can consume all available operating system memory on the target system.
It is reported that a remote user on the local subnet can send a number of spoofed address resolution protocol (ARP) requests to the target system to cause kernel memory to become exhausted.  As a result, denial of service conditions may occur.  This is reportedly due to a flaw in the arplookup() function.

According to FreeBSD, various BSD-derived systems may be affected, as the vulnerable code dates well back to the CSRG branches.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
FreeBSD has released a fix and recommends that you do one of the following:

1) Upgrade your vulnerable system to 4-STABLE; or to the RELENG_5_1, RELENG_5_0, RELENG_4_8, or RELENG_4_7 security branch dated after the correction date.  [See the Source Message for the correction dates.]

2) To patch your present system:

The following patch has been verified to apply to FreeBSD 5-CURRENT, 4.9-PRERELEASE, and 4.8 systems.

a) Download the relevant patch from the location below, and verify the detached PGP signature using your PGP utility.

ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:14/arp.patch
ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:14/arp.patch.asc

b) Execute the following commands as root:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

c) Rebuild your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

See the Source Message for the FreeBSD correction dates and details.

Title: BSD arplookup() May Let Local Subnet Users Crash the System
Version(s): Mac OS X prior to 10.2.8; FreeBSD 5.1 and prior
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X and other BSD-based operating systems.  A remote user on a local subnet can consume all available operating system memory on the target system.
It is reported that a remote user on the local subnet can send a number of spoofed address resolution protocol (ARP) requests to the target system to cause kernel memory to become exhausted.  As a result, denial of service conditions may occur.  This is reportedly due to a flaw in the arplookup() function.

According to FreeBSD, various BSD-derived systems may be affected, as the vulnerable code dates well back to the CSRG branches.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
Individual BSD vendors are issuing fixes.  The Apple Mac OS X fix is described below.  For other BSD-based systems, see the Message History.

Apple has issued a fix as part of Mac OS X 10.2.8.  The update is available via:

  * Software Update pane in System Preferences

  * Apple's Software Downloads web site

The following updates are available via the Apple Software Download site:

    Mac OS X Client (updating from 10.2 - 10.2.5):
    http://www.info.apple.com/kbnum/n120244
    The download file is: "MacOSXUpdateCombo10.2.8.dmg"
    The SHA-1 digest is: 47c4e354516d7d577c57389207e4207f2b9b2ea2

    Mac OS X Client (updating from 10.2.6 - 10.2.7):
    http://www.info.apple.com/kbnum/n120245
    The download file is: "MacOSXUpdate10.2.8.dmg"
    The SHA-1 digest is: 2fd24114274f9a1c59b2eb492301a90234215c73

    Mac OS X Server (updating from 10.2 - 10.2.5):
    http://www.info.apple.com/kbnum/n120246
    The download file is: "MacOSXSrvrUpdCombo10.2.8.dmg"
    The SHA-1 digest is: d87b3e7bd5668046f22b551ccf9bb75a4139e653

    Mac OS X Server (updating from 10.2.6 - 10.2.7):
    http://www.info.apple.com/kbnum/n120247
    The download file is: "MacOSXServerUpdate10.2.8.dmg"
    The SHA-1 digest is: 74ce19ab7488a41328bee2ba7156489f997abe7c

Title: Solaris sadmind Weak Authentication May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Commands With Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An authentication vulnerability was reported in the Sun Solaris sadmind daemon.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges in certain cases.
It is reported that if the sadmind(1M) daemon has been enabled in inetd.conf(4) and if the system is using the default security level of AUTH_SYS, a remote user may be able to forge AUTH_SYS credentials and execute arbitrary commands on the system.  The commands will run with the privileges of sadmind, which is typically root level privileges, according to the report.

Sun reports that an exploit has been discovered in the wild.

CVE number CVE-2003-0722 has been assigned to this issue.

Sun credits iDefense with reporting this issue.
Impact': A remote user may be able to execute commands on the target system with the privileges of the sadmind daemon (typically root privileges).
Solution:
Sun does not plan to issue patches.  Instead, Sun has described the following workaround [quoted]:

"Either disable the sadmind(1M) on the systems or enable strong (AUTH_DES) authentication by adding "-S 2" to the sadmind(1M) entry of the inetd.conf(4) file.

To disable sadmind(1M) on a Solaris system, do the following:

1. Edit the "/etc/inetd.conf" file and comment out the following line by adding the "#" symbol to the beginning of the line as follows:

     #100232/10   tli   rpc/udp wait root /usr/sbin/sadmind    sadmind

2. Tell the inetd(1M) process to reread the newly modified "/etc/inetd.conf" file by sending it a hangup signal, SIGHUP:

     # /usr/bin/pkill -HUP inetd

To enable strong (AUTH_DES) authentication for sadmind(1M) on a Solaris system, do the following:

1. Edit the "/etc/inetd.conf" file and append "-S 2" to the end of the sadmind line as follows:

     100232/10   tli   rpc/udp wait root /usr/sbin/sadmind    sadmind -S 2

2. Tell the inetd(1M) process to reread the newly modified "/etc/inetd.conf" file by sending it a hangup signal, SIGHUP:

     # /usr/bin/pkill -HUP inetd

Title: OpenBSD Semaphore Integer Overflow Lets Local Root Users Bypass 'securelevel()' Access Controls
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the OpenBSD kernel.  A local user with root privileges may be able to bypass 'securelevel(7)' access controls and write to kernel memory.
It is reported that there is an integer overflow in the semget(2) system call (src/sys/kern/sysv_sem.c).  A local user with root privileges can write to certain kernel memory locations regardless of the securelevel(7) controls.

A local user with root privileges can reportedly set the 'seminfo.semmns' and 'seminfo.semmsl' variables to arbitrary values via sysctl(), causing a buffer to be incorrectly malloc'd.
Impact': A local user with root privileges may be able to bypass securelevel() access controls and write to kernel memory locations.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix in the -STABLE and -CURRENT versions (available via CVS).

Also, the following patch for the 3.3 kernel is available:

http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb.cgi/src/sys/kern/sysv_sem.c

Title: OpenBSD semget() Boundary Overflow Bug Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the OpenBSD operating system in the semget(2) system call.  A local user can trigger a kernel panic.
It is reported that the semget(2) system call does not properly validate the bounds of user-supplied input.  A local user can make a specially crafted call to cause the function to consume all available kernel memory, resulting in a kernel panic.

The vendor reports that the vulnerable code was introduced into OpenBSD version 3.3.  Previous versions are not affected, the report said.

The vendor credits blexim for discovering and reporting the flaw.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
The vendor has issue a fixed in the OpenBSD-current and 3.3 stable branches.  A patch is also available for OpenBSD 3.3:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.3/common/002_semget.patch

Title: SGI Checkpoint/Restart 'libcpr' Flaw Lets Local Users Overwrite Files With Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in a Checkpoint/Restart (CPR) library on SGI IRIX.  A local user can overwrite certain files with elevated privileges.
According to the report, the vulnerability resides in the libcpr library.  Applications that load libcpr may be affected.  A local user can invoke an affected application to overwrite or truncate certain files with elevated privileges.

The vulnerable library is reportedly installed by default (but as part of an optional package).
Impact':
A local user may be able to overwrite or truncate certain files with elevated privileges.

[Editor's note:  It is not clear what the level of elevated privileges are.  Because of the uncertainty, we have categorized the impact as potentially allowing root access until we receive clarification from the vendor.]
Solution:
SGI has issued a fixed version IRIX (6.5.22) as well as patches 5264 through 5269 for previous versions of IRIX:

IRIX 6.5.19f, 5267

IRIX 6.5.20f, 5268

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Revised Advisory Text) FreeBSD Kernel Flaw in Checking Signal Numbers May Let Local Users Modify Kernel Memory or Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD kernel in the checking of signal number values.  A local user may be able to trigger a kernel panic.  In some configurations, a local user may be able to modify kernel memory and take full control of the system.
It is reported that a local user can cause certain applications to send a negative or out-of-range signal number to the kernel. Those applications reportedly include the ptrace(2) system call and the 'spigot' video capture device driver.

The flaw in ptrace(2) was reportedly introduced into FreeBSD version 4.2.  The vulnerable `spigot' device driver was reportedly introduced in FreeBSD 2.0.5, but is not part of the default kernel (only systems with 'device spigot' in the kernel configuration are affected).

According to the report, a local user can trigger an assertion failure and kernel panic.

On some FreeBSD 5.x systems (those where the 'INVARIANTS' kernel option is not used; including the default configuration of FreeBSD 5.0-RELEASE and 5.1-RELEASE), the assertion code is not included.  As a result, a local user may be able to modify kernel memory.
Impact':
A local user can cause the system to crash.

A local user may be able to modify kernel memory on certain kernel configurations.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix and recommends that you upgrade your system to 4.8-STABLE, or to any of the RELENG_4_8 (4.8-RELEASE-p2), RELENG_4_7 (4.7-RELEASE-p12), or RELENG_5_1 (5.1-RELEASE-p1) security branches dated after the respective correction dates [see the Source Message for the correction dates].

Alternately, you can download the following patch:

[FreeBSD 5.1-RELEASE]

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:09/signal51.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:09/signal51.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 5.0-RELEASE]

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:09/signal50.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:09/signal50.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 4.8-RELEASE, 4.8-STABLE, 4.7-STABLE dated Jan 2 20:39:13 2003 UTC or later]

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:09/signal4s.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:09/signal4s.patch.asc

[FreeBSD 4.3-RELEASE through 4.7-RELEASE, 4.7-STABLE dated before Jan 2 20:39:13 2003 UTC]

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:09/signal47.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:09/signal47.patch.asc

The patch can be applied with the following commands:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

After applying the patch, you must then recompile the kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

Title: FreeBSD 'ibcs2.ko' Loadable Kernel Module May Disclose Kernel Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD kernel in the 'ibcs2.ko' loadable kernel module.  A local user can read portions of kernel memory and may be able to gain elevated privileges based on information contained in the kernel memory contents.
It is reported that the statfs(2) function copies a kernel data structure to a user-level application based on a user-supplied length parameter.  A local user can reportedly supply a large length parameter to gain read access to additional kernel memory.  Information disclosed may include passwords that allow the local user to gain elevated privileges.

According to the report, the vulnerable module only loads if the 'option IBCS2' statement is set in the kernel configuration file, if kldload(8) is used to dynamically load it, or if 'ibcs2_enable' is set in the rc.conf(5) file.

The vendor credits David Rhodus <drhodus@catpa.com> with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A local user can obtain portions of kernel memory.  Using the information obtained from memory, a local user may be able to gain elevated privleges on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix and recommends that you upgrade to 4.8-STABLE, or to any of the RELENG_4_8 (4.8-RELEASE-p3), RELENG_4_7 (4.7-RELEASE-p13), or RELENG_5_1 (5.1-RELEASE-p2) security branches dated after the respective correction dates [see the Source Message for the correction dates].

Or, you can apply the following patch:

# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:10/ibcs2.patch
# fetch ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/CERT/patches/SA-03:10/ibcs2.patch.asc

The patch can be applied with the following commands:

# cd /usr/src
# patch < /path/to/patch

Then, you must recompile your kernel as described in <URL:http://www.freebsd.org/handbook/kernelconfig.html> and reboot the system.

As a workaround, you can reportedly disable iBCS2 support (if it is enabled).

Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the FreeBSD kernel in the checking of signal number values.  A local user may be able to trigger a kernel panic.  In some configurations, a local user may be able to modify kernel memory and take full control of the system.
It is reported that a local user can cause certain applications to send a negative or out-of-range signal number to the kernel. Those applications reportedly include the ptrace(2) system call and the 'spigot' video capture device driver.

The flaw in ptrace(2) was reportedly introduced into FreeBSD version 4.2.  The vulnerable `spigot' device driver was reportedly introduced in FreeBSD 2.0.5, but is not part of the default kernel (only systems with 'device spigot' in the kernel configuration are affected).

Title: NetBSD OSI Networking Code (netiso) May Let Remote Users Crash the System
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the NetBSD operating system's OSI networking code.   A remote user may be able to crash the system.
It is reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted OSI networking packet to a target NetBSD system that is running the OSI protocol to cause the target system to crash.  According to the report, the flaw resides in the 'sys/netiso' OSI networking kernel in a function that returns error indications to the sender of an OSI packet when certain error conditions are present.

If the kernel was compiled with the "options DEBUG" setting, a system panic will occur.  Otherwise, the system will crash in potentially erratic ways, the report said.

To determine if you are affected, you can run the following command and look for any 'iso' addresses assigned to any interface:

'ifconfig -a | grep iso'

If the command response does not show any iso addresses assigned to any interface, the vendor indicates that the system is not vulnerable.

The vendor credits Ignatios Souvatzis.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause a kernel panic and crash the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixes:

NetBSD-current:		May 26, 2003
NetBSD-1.6 branch:	May 26, 2003 (1.6.2 will include the fix)
NetBSD-1.5 branch:	May 28, 2003

See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing installation instructions.  The advisory is also available at:

ftp://ftp.NetBSD.org/pub/NetBSD/security/advisories/NetBSD-SA2003-010.txt.asc

Title: Rpc.mountd May Disclose File Existence to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in rpc.mountd [originally reported on August 24, 1997].  A remote user may be able to determine if a file exists on a target system based on the error messages returned.
It is reported that some operating systems return different rpc.mountd error messages depending on whether the requested mount exists or not.

If a remote user attempts to mount a file or directory that does not exist on the target server, the server will reportedly return an error message that includes the following string:

"reason given by server: No such file or directory"

However, if the file exists on the target server but the user does not have the appropriate privileges to read the file, the server's error message will include the following string:

"reason given by server: Permission denied"

By examining the returned error messages, a remote user can determine whether specified files exist on the system.
Impact': A remote user can determine whether specified files exist on the server.
Solution:
HP has issued a new version of 'rpc.mountd'.  For HP-UX 11.00 and 11.11, a patch is available that should be applied before installing the new rpc.mountd:

      HP-UX B.11.00 - PHNE_28567
      HP-UX B.11.11 - PHNE_28568

The patches and new rpc.mountd is available at:

        System:    hprc.external.hp.com  (192.170.19.51)
        Login:     rpcmd
        Password:  rpcmd

        FTP Access: ftp://rpcmd:rpcmd@hprc.external.hp.com/
                or: ftp://rpcmd:rpcmd@192.170.19.51/
                or: ftp hprc.external.hp.com

The md5 sums are:

    1918843242 49152 rpc.mountd.11.00
    1875800265 49152 rpc.mountd.11.11
    1579713161 49152 rpc.mountd.11.22

    MD5 (rpc.mountd.11.00) = 6269e2fe7f9f1af5c290ffa5350c9429

For specific installation instructions, see the vendor's advisory in the Source Message.

Title: Sun Solaris psig() Race Condition May Let Local Users Cause a System Panic
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Sun Solaris operating system.  A local user can invoke a system panic.
It is reported that a "rare" race condition exists in the psig() function.  A local user can reportedly cause the lwp_cursig variable to be zero and proc.p_sig to be non-zero to trigger the flaw and cause a system panic.

If the system is affected, the log files may show a generic "BAD TRAP: type=31" panic string, according to the report.
Impact': A local user can cause a system panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

     * Solaris 2.6 with patch 105181-35 or later
     * Solaris 7 with patch 106541-25 or later
     * Solaris 8 with patch 108528-19 or later
     * Solaris 9 with patch 112233-05 or later

x86 Platform

     * Solaris 2.6 with patch 105182-35 or later
     * Solaris 7 with patch 106542-25 or later
     * Solaris 8 with patch 108529-19 or later
     * Solaris 9 with patch 112234-05 or later

Title: HP-UX Unspecified 'libxti' Bug May Let Remote Users Crash Some Services
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the HP-UX operating system.  A remote user can cause certain network-enabled daemons to crash.
HP reported that a remote user can generate "certain network traffic" to cause some programs (such as nfsd) to fail.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote user can cause some network services to crash.
Solution:
HP has released patches for B.11.00 and B.11.11.

For HP-UX B.11.00, install PHNE_27902 or subsequent
For HP-UX B.11.11, install PHNE_27703 or subsequent

For HP-UX B.11.22, the vendor indicates that you should download and install the following files:

        System:    hprc.external.hp.com  (192.170.19.51)
        Login:     nfsd
        Password:  nfsd

        FTP Access: ftp://nfsd:nfsd@hprc.external.hp.com/
                or: ftp://nfsd:nfsd@192.170.19.51/
                or: ftp hprc.external.hp.com

See the Source Message for the vendor's installation instructions.

Title: Sun Solaris 'ld.so.1' Runtime Linker Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in in Sun Solaris operating system in the ld.so.1(1) runtime linker.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
iDEFENSE reported that a local user can supply a large, specially crafted LD_PRELOAD value to the linker to trigger a stack overflow. According to the report, the overflow occurs in a non-executable portion of the stack, but it is still possible to execute arbitrary code.

The report indicates that a local user can feasibly exploit this flaw to execute arbitrary code with root privileges if there is at least one set user id (setuid) root application on the system that is dynamically linked.  iDEFENSE states that nearly all default installations of Solaris 8 and 9 meet this criteria and, therefore, are affected.

The following notification timeline is provided:

01 JUN 2003      Issue disclosed to security-alert@sun.com
02 JUN 2003      Response from Sun Security Coordination Team
03 JUN 2003      Email to Sun Security Coordination Team
04 JUN 2003      Issue disclosed to iDEFENSE
16 JUL 2003      Status Request to Sun Security Coordination Team
22 JUL 2003      Response from Sun Security Coordination Team
28 JUL 2003      iDEFENSE clients notified
29 JUL 2003      Coordinated Public Disclosure
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued Sun Alert ID 55680.  The following fixes are available:

SPARC Platform

    * Solaris 2.6 with patch 107733-11 or later
    * Solaris 7 with patch 106950-23 or later
    * Solaris 8 with patch 109147-25 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 112963-09 or later

x86 Platform

    * Solaris 2.6 with patch 107734-11 or later
    * Solaris 7 with patch 106951-23 or later
    * Solaris 8 with patch 109148-25 or later
    * Solaris 9 with patch 113986-05 or later

Title: Sun Solaris 8 Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending IPv6 Packets
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris.  A remote user can cause a system panic.
Sun reported that when Solaris 8 is configured to use Internet Protocol Version 6 (ip6(7P)), a remote or local user can send specially crafted IPv6 packets to the target system to cause a system panic.  No further details were provided.

Sun reports that Solaris 2.6, Solaris 7 and Solaris 9 are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can cause a system panic.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 8 with patch 108528-21 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 8 with patch 108529-21 or later

Title: SGI IRIX Login Hole May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in SGI's IRIX operating system in the login utility (/usr/lib/iaf/scheme).  A local user may be able to gain root privileges on the system.
SGI reported that a local user can set specific environment variables and then call /usr/lib/iaf/scheme (login) to cause the scheme binary to dump core.  The binary is reportedly configured with set user id (setuid) root user privileges.  A local user may be able to gain root access on the system.

SGI credits Walter Roberson with reporting this flaw.

SGI notes that this is a different vulnerability than the flaw reported in CERT advisories CA-2001-34 and CA-1997-21.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version of IRIX (6.5.21).  The vendor has also issued a patch (5182) for 6.5.16 - 6.5.20.

Title: (Apple Issues Fix) Mac OS X Screensaver Flaw Lets Physically Local Users Access a Locked Desktop
Description:
Delfim Machado reported a vulnerability in the Mac OS X screensaver.  A local user can crash a locked screensaver and gain access to the desktop.
A physically local user can reportedly leave a key pressed for 5 minutes or longer and then press the enter key to crash the screensaver and gain access to the desktop, even if the screensaver is locked with a password.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A physically local user can gain access to the system when the screensaver is locked.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix (Security Update 2003-07-14), available at:

* Software Update pane in System Preferences

OR

* Apple's Software Downloads web site:

http://www.info.apple.com/kbnum/n120232

The download file is named: "SecurityUpd2003-07-14.dmg"

The SHA-1 digest is: 210f4819b8559b590632cd62b4055a437b9a0267

Title: Mac OS X Screensaver Flaw Lets Physically Local Users Access a Locked Desktop
Description:
Delfim Machado reported a vulnerability in the Mac OS X screensaver.  A local user can crash a locked screensaver and gain access to the desktop.
A physically local user can reportedly leave a key pressed for 5 minutes or longer and then press the enter key to crash the screensaver and gain access to the desktop, even if the screensaver is locked with a password.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A physically local user can gain access to the system when the screensaver is locked.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: HP Tru64 UNIX /usr/bin/ksh Flaw Lets Local Users Consume All CPU Processing Time
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in HP Tru64 UNIX in the KornShell (/usr/bin/ksh).  A local user can introduce denial of service conditions.
It is reported that in certain system configurations, a local user can abruptly close a telnet session to cause the ksh process to continue to run.  This can cause the process to consume up to 100% of CPU processing time, according to HP.

HP notes that the flaw can be triggered by a local user closing a telnet window by clicking on the upper right hand "X" box (as an example).

The flaw reportedly occurs when a startup script or a script executed within the current shell process contains a trap(1) definition.
Impact': A local user can consume 100% of the available CPU processing resources.
Solution:
The vendor has released an ECO patch for several versions of HP Tru64 UNIX

ECO Name: T64V51BB1-C0017400-19077-E-20030625
ECO Kit Approximate Size: 2.19MB
Kit Applies To: HP Tru64 UNIX 5.1B PK1 (BL1)

Title: SGI IRIX Operating System 'inetd' Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in certain versions of the SGI IRIX operating system.  A remote user can cause 'inetd' to hang.
SGI issued an advisory warning that a remote user can conduct a portscan of the target system to cause inetd on the target system to hang.

The vulnerability was reportedly introduced in IRIX 6.5.19 when IPv6 capabilities were added to the operating system.  The flaw is also present in 6.5.20, according to SGI.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system's inetd daemon to hang.
Solution:
SGI has issued a fixed version of IRIX (6.5.21) and also a patch (5084) for IRIX 6.5.19 and 6.5.20.

Title: (HP Issues Additional Fix) HP-UX 'rpc.yppasswd' Daemon Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in rpc.yppasswdd on the HP-UX operating system.  A remote user could cause denial of service conditions or potentially gain access to the system
It is reported that a remote user may be able to trigger a buffer overflow to execute arbitrary code on the target server.

No further details were provided.

HP credits LSD Research Group (http://lsd-pl.net) with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target server with the privileges of the rpc.yppasswd daemon.  A remote user may also be able to cause the daemon to crash.
Solution:
HP has released patches for 11.00, 11.11, and 11.22.  For HP-UX 10.20, a preliminary fix is available.

For B.11.00, install PHNE_28102.
For B.11.11, install PHNE_28103.
For B.11.22, install PHNE_28138.

For B.10.20 install rpc.yppasswdd_10.20, as described by HP:

      rpc.yppasswdd_10.20
        cksum rpc.yppasswdd_10.20
        575931685 28672 rpc.yppasswdd_10.20
        MD5 (rpc.yppasswdd_10.20) =
               cf362f855dbb9493282686cf4823afec

        System:    hprc.external.hp.com  (192.170.19.51)
        Login:     yppass
        Password:  yppass

        FTP Access: ftp://bind:bind1@hprc.external.hp.com/
                or: ftp://bind:bind1@192.170.19.51/

        ftp://yppass:yppass@hprc.external.hp.com/
        ftp://yppass:yppass@192.170.19.51/

Copy the appropriate file to a protected directory (called "<new_rpc.yppasswdd_path>" below) and rename it "rpc.yppasswdd".

         /sbin/rc2.d/S410nis.server stop
         cd  /usr/lib/netsvc/yp
         cp  rpc.yppasswdd rpc.yppasswdd.orig
         cp /<new_rpc.yppasswdd_path>/rpc.yppasswdd rpc.yppasswdd
         /sbin/rc2.d/S410nis.server stop

Title: (Sun Issues Alert) Re: Sun Solaris 'syslogd' Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the Daemon
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Sun Solaris syslogd daemon.  A remote user can cause the daemon to crash.
It is reported that the syslogd daemon contains a buffer overflow.  A remote user can connect to the daemon and send a specially crafted packet to trigger the buffer overflow.

The report indicates that a remote user can send a UDP packet larger than 1024 bytes to cause syslogd to dump core.

The report also indicates that it may be possible for a remote user to execute arbitrary code, but the author was unable to successfully demonstrate code execution.

The following notification timeline is provided:

	2003-01-18:	Problem discovered, platforms tested.
	2003-01-21:	Sun Security Coordination Team notified.
	2003-02-04:	Sun confirms the problem and assigns bug ID.
	2003-05-29:	Patch released.
Impact': A remote user can cause the daemon to crash.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 2.6: patch 106439-13 or later
Solaris 7: patch 106541-25 or later
Solaris 8: patch 110945-08 or later
Solaris 9: patch 112998-03 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 2.6: patch 106440-14 or later
Solaris 7: patch 106542-25 or later
Solaris 8: patch 110946-08 or later
Solaris 9: patch 114932-01 or later

Title: Apple Mac OS X 'dsimportexport' Tool Discloses Password to Local Users
Version(s): Mac OS X 10.2 and prior versions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple's OS X operating system in the dsimportexport command.  A local user can view a certain password.
Apple reported that a local user can potentially view the username and password of the account that is running the dsimportexport utility.
Impact': A local user can view the password of the account running dsimportexport.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix (Security Update 2003-06-12), available at:

* Software Update pane in System Preferences, or

* Apple's Software Downloads web site:

     http://www.info.apple.com/kbnum/n120215

The download file is named: "SecurityUpd2003-06-12.dmg"
The SHA-1 digest is: 1f8e101111ae059ebd6eaf91b69267808517b4a1

Title: Sun Solaris utmp_update Buffer Overflow Yields Root Access to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Sun Solaris in the 'utmp_update' command.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the system.
It is reported that a local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  The nature of the buffer overflow was not disclosed.

Solaris versions 2.6, 7, 8, and 9 are affected.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the system.
Solution:
Sun has released the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 113754-02 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 113752-02 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 113650-02 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 113718-02 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 113755-02 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 113753-02 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 113651-02 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 113996-02 or later

Title: HP/UX Network Stack Bug May Let Remote Users Crash Certain Applications
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the HP/UX operating system.  A remote user can send certain types of network traffic to cause the target application to fail.
HP reported that a flaw in 'sys_socket.o' may result in denial of service conditions for certain applications.  HP listed 'diagmond' as an example of an application that may be affected by this flaw.

HP did not disclose any information regarding the nature of the flaw.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause a target application to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches:

HP-UX B.11.00 - PHNE_28538
HP-UX B.11.11 - PHNE_28895

For HP-UX B.11.22, apply sys_socket.o.ia.1122.  See the Source Message for specific instructions on how to download and install sys_socket.o.ia.1122 for HP-UX B.11.22.

Title: Sun Solaris 'syslogd' Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the Daemon
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Sun Solaris syslogd daemon.  A remote user can cause the daemon to crash.
It is reported that the syslogd daemon contains a buffer overflow.  A remote user can connect to the daemon and send a specially crafted packet to trigger the buffer overflow.

The report indicates that a remote user can send a UDP packet larger than 1024 bytes to cause syslogd to dump core.

The report also indicates that it may be possible for a remote user to execute arbitrary code, but the author was unable to successfully demonstrate code execution.

The following notification timeline is provided:

	2003-01-18:	Problem discovered, platforms tested.
	2003-01-21:	Sun Security Coordination Team notified.
	2003-02-04:	Sun confirms the problem and assigns bug ID.
	2003-05-29:	Patch released.
Impact': A remote user can cause the daemon to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released patches:

Patch 110945-08 for SPARC
Patch 110946-08 for x86

Title: Mac OS X May Transmit LDAP Passwords Without Encryption in Certain Cases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple's Mac OS X Server.  When using a Kerberos login with an LDAPv3 server, user account passwords may be transmitted in clear text.
Apple reported that the 'Login Window' function is vulnerable when the 'AuthenticationAuthority' attribute is not set.  The function will attempt to authenticate using an encrypted password, but will then attempt a 'simple bind' that transmits the password in clear text.  A remote user that is monitoring the network between the OS X server and the LDAP server can obtain the password during transmission.
Impact': A remote user monitoring the network may be able to view user passwords as they are transmitted over the network.
Solution:
Apple has issued a knowledge base article (107579) describing how to prevent this by mapping the AuthenticationAuthority attribute to an existing non-null attribute in your LDAP server.  See the document for complete instructions:

http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=107579

Title: Sun Solaris in.telnetd Unspecified Bug May Let Remote Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the in.telnetd(1M) daemon on Sun Solaris.  A remote user may be able to cause the system to become unresponsive.
Sun issued Alert 54181 warning that a local or remote user may be able to cause the in.telnetd(1M) daemon to enter an infinite processing loop, consuming "large amounts" of CPU resources.  If multiple telnet processes are affected, the entire system may become unresponsive.

The cause of the flaw was not disclosed.
Impact': A remote or local user may be able to cause excessive CPU resource consumption, potentially causing the system to become unresponsive.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 106049-05 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 107475-05 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 110668-04 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 114729-01 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 106050-05 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 107476-05 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 110669-04 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 114730-01 or later

Title: (HP Issues Fix) HP/UX 'ipcs' Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the ipcs interprocess communication status utility on the HP/UX operating system.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
It is reported that a local user can trigger a buffer overflow in /usr/bin/ipcs.  It may be possible to exploit the overflow to execute arbitrary code on the system with 'sys' group privileges, but that was not confirmed in the report.

A demonstration exploit is provided:

/usr/bin/ipcs -C `perl -e 'print "A" x 2232'`
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated ('sys' group) privileges on the system.
Solution:
HP has released a temporary fix.  A temporary depot file is available to fully rectify the problem.  However, HP notes that this temporary depot file must be removed before the official patch is installed, otherwise system corruption may occur.

Until a final patch is available, you can download and install the UNOF_29043.depot from:

     System:    hprc.external.hp.com  (192.170.19.51)
     Login:     ipcs
     Password:  ipcs1

    FTP Access: <ftp://ipcs:ipcs1@hprc.external.hp.com/>
            or: <ftp://ipcs:ipcs1@192.170.19.51/>

     The file is: UNOF_29043.depot

     cksum 1511742840 92160 UNOF_29043.depot

     MD5 (UNOF_29043) = 8C3F0818C00413ACE87EB5E4B735CAC9

To install, copy the depot to a protected directory and launch Software Distributor (SD).

HP credits Davide Del Vecchio with reporting this flaw.

Title: IBM AIX Printer Commands Let Local Users Gain Elevated or Root Privileges and Also Crash the 'lpd' Server
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A format string vulnerability was reported in some of the printer commands on IBM's AIX operating system.  A local user can obtain elevated privileges, potentially including root privileges.
IBM issued a security advisory warning that a local user may be able to obtain 'printq' user privileges or root privileges due to a format string flaw in several command line utilities that allow users to control print queue characteristics.

It is also reported that a local user may be able to cause the remote print server (lpd) to crash.
Impact': A local user can obtain 'printq' or 'root' user privileges.  A local user can cause the lpd server to crash.
Solution:
IBM has issued the following fixes:

      APAR number for AIX 4.3.3:  IY42089 (available)
      APAR number for AIX 5.1.0:  IY42090 (available)
      APAR number for AIX 5.2.0:  IY42091 (available)

For versions prior to 4.3, customers must upgrade to 4.3.3 or 5.1.0 at the latest maintenance level.

AIX APARs are available at the following URLs.

For 4.3.3 APARs:

http://techsupport.services.ibm.com/rs6k/fixdb.html

 For 5.1.0 APARs:

http://techsupport.services.ibm.com/server/aix.fdc

For 5.2.0 APARs:

http://techsupport.services.ibm.com/server/aix.fdc

Title: (HP Issues Fix) HP/UX 'wall' Utility Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in '/usr/sbin/wall' on the HP/UX operating system.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code to gain additional privileges.
It is reported that a local user can trigger a buffer overflow by creating a large, specially crafted file to be broadcast by the wall utility.  It may be possible for the local user to exploit this to execute arbitrary code with 'tty' group privileges, as 'wall' is reportedly configured with set group id (setgid) tty group privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain 'tty' group privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following patches:

PHCO_28717         for 10.20,
PHCO_28718         for 11.00,
PHCO_28719         for 11.11.

Title: (HP Has a Fix) Re: HP/UX rwrite Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the 'rwrite' command on HP/UX.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code to gain root privileges on the target system.
It is reported that /usr/lbin/rwrite does not properly check the length of user-supplied input.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.  According to the report, rwrite is installed with set user id (setuid) root user privileges by default.  A local user can potentially exploit this to take full control of the target server.

A demonstration exploit command is provided:

/usr/lbin/rwrite something `perl -e 'print "A" x 14628'` something
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges to gain full control of the system.
Solution:
HP implied that the fix described in HP Security Bulletin HPSBUX0208-213 from August 2002 regarding the lp subsystem corrects the rwrite buffer overflow.  In the attached note, HP reported being unable to reproduce the flaw when the referenced patch was applied.  However, in January 2004, HP issued Security Bulletin HPSBUX0401-312 that provides new patches against this vulnerability for HP-UX 11.00 and 11.11 [see Alert ID 1008803 by following the Message History].

The patches are:

HP-UX 10.20          PHCO_27133,
HP-UX 11.00          PHCO_27132,
HP-UX 11.11          PHCO_27020.

Title: HP/UX rwrite Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the 'rwrite' command on HP/UX.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code to gain root privileges on the target system.
It is reported that /usr/lbin/rwrite does not properly check the length of user-supplied input.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.  According to the report, rwrite is installed with set user id (setuid) root user privileges by default.  A local user can potentially exploit this to take full control of the target server.

A demonstration exploit command is provided:

/usr/lbin/rwrite something `perl -e 'print "A" x 14628'` something
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges to gain full control of the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report indicates that you can remove the setuid bit until a patch is available.

Title: (HP Issues Fix) HP/UX 'rexec' Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the rexec client on HP/UX.  A local user may possibly be able to gain root privileges on the system.
Davide Del Vecchio reported that a local user can supply a specially crafted '-l' command line parameter to trigger the overflow. 

A demonstration exploit is provided:

$ rexec 127.0.0.1 -l `perl -e 'printf "A" x 9777'` -n something

The report did not confirm whether it is possible to execute arbitrary code or not.  The rexec utility is reportedly configured with set user id (setuid) root user privileges, so if code execution is possible, a local user could obtain root privileges.
Impact':
A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

[Editor's note:  The report did not confirm whether code execution is possible or not.]
Solution:
HP has released a fix.

For 11.00:

Install PHCO_24723 or subsequent.  PHCO_24723 has been superseded.  To find the recommended superseding patch and the latest superseding patch, search the technical knowledge base on itrc.hp.com for "PHCO_24723".

For 10.20:

Download and install libc.1.10.20 (which also corrects the vulnerabilities listed in in HPSBUX0208-209 and HPSBUX0303-252)

     System:           hprc.external.hp.com  (192.170.19.51)
     Login:            rexec
     Password:         rexec

     Browser ftp access:

       ftp://rexec:rexec@hprc.external.hp.com/
       ftp://rexec:rexec@192.170.19.51/

cksum:

     2506697268 1867776 libc.1.10.20

     MD5 (libc.1.10.20) = cabd081cee3e980d7f3075bb7c6a505d

HP indicates that you should:

     Go to init state 2

      #DIR=[path to new libc.1]

      #cd /usr/lib
      #cp libc.1 libc.1.orig
      #cp $DIR/libc.1.10.20 libc.1.new
      #chown bin libc.1.new
      #chgrp bin libc.1.new
      #chmod 555 libc.1.new
      #/sbin/mv libc.1 was.libc.1
      #/sbin/mv libc.1.new libc.1

Then, reboot the system.

Title: (Sun Issues Patches) Re: Sun RPC Library Integer Overflow in xdrmem_getbytes() May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Sun RPC External Data Representation (XDR) library and related implementations, including libnsl, libc, and glibc.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed by an application that uses one of the affected libraries.
It is reported that the xdrmem_getbytes() function contains an integer overflow that could result in dynamic memory allocation errors. Depending on how the application that uses the function is implemented, a buffer overflow could occur.

No further details were provided.

[Editor's note:  The report appeared to be an advance copy of a CERT vulnerability note.  However, the text not distributed by CERT.  The text contained a CERT copyright notice, so we are unable to redistributed it at this time.]
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed by an application that uses one of the affected libraries.  The specific impact will depend on the application.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following patches for libnsl:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 105401-44 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 108993-18 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 113319-11 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 105402-44 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 106943-27 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 108994-18 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 113719-04 or later

Sun is working on a final resolution for Solaris 7 SPARC.  A T-patch (T106942-27) is available for Solaris 7 SPARC.

Solaris 2.5.1 requires an upgrade to Solaris 2.6 (or later) with the appropriate patches 
once available.

Title: (Sun Issues Fix) Re: 'wall' (/usr/sbin/wall) Bug Lets Local Users Spoof Broadcast Messages
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the wall application on Sun Solaris and possibly other UNIX operating systems.  A local user can send spoofed messages.
It is reported that a local user can broadcast spoofed messages to all users currently logged in on the system.

According to the report, the /usr/sbin/wall application determines if a message is sent by a local user or a remote user by checking to see if the file descriptor pointed to by stderr corresponds to a tty.  If it does not, the application determines if the the first 5 bytes of the message are set to "From ", followed ultimately by a character string in the form of 'user@host'.  So, a local user can spoof a 'rpc.walld' message by closing stderr before executing /usr/sbin/wall and then sending a bogus "From " header.  A local user can exploit this to attempt to convey apparently official messages to users on the system.

A demonstration exploit transcript and code is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can send a message to all logged in users on the system that appears to be a remotely generated broadcast message from an arbitrary source.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following patches:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 114889-01 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 114891-01 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 114673-01 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 114861-01 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 114890-01 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 114892-01 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 114674-01 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 114862-01 or later

Title: HP/UX 'rexec' Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the rexec client on HP/UX.  A local user may possibly be able to gain root privileges on the system.
Davide Del Vecchio reported that a local user can supply a specially crafted '-l' command line parameter to trigger the overflow. 

A demonstration exploit is provided:

$ rexec 127.0.0.1 -l `perl -e 'printf "A" x 9777'` -n something

The report did not confirm whether it is possible to execute arbitrary code or not.  The rexec utility is reportedly configured with set user id (setuid) root user privileges, so if code execution is possible, a local user could obtain root privileges.
Impact':
A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

[Editor's note:  The report did not confirm whether code execution is possible or not.]
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is reportedly working on a fix.

Title: Sun Solaris rpcbind Unspecified Flaw Lets Remote Users Terminate the Service
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in rpcbind(1M) for Sun Solaris.  A remote user can cause the service to crash.
Sun reported that a remote user can cause rpcbind(1M) to be terminated.  No further details were provided.

[Editor's note:  This appears to be a separate and different flaw than the rpcbind bug reported in February 2003 in Alert ID 1006131.]
Impact': A remote user could cause rpcbind to terminate, causing denial of service conditions for rpc services.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 105401-42 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 106942-25 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 108827-40 (patch 108827-40 has been obsoleted by patch 108993-18)
Solaris 8 with patch 108993-18 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 113319-07 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 2.6 with patch 105402-42 or later
Solaris 7 with patch 106943-25 or later
Solaris 8 with patch 108828-40 (patch 108828-40 has been obsoleted by patch 108994-18)
Solaris 8 with patch 108994-18 or later
Solaris 9 with patch 113719-02 or later

Title: Sun Solaris 'lofiadm' Kernel Memory Leak May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Sun Solaris lofiadm(1M) command.  A local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Sun reported that a local user may be able to trigger a kernel memory leak to cause the system to degrade or crash.

Solaris 8 is affected.  Sun reports that Solaris 2.6, 7, and 9 are not affected.
Impact': A local user may be able to cause the system to degrade or to crash.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes:

SPARC Platform

Solaris 8 with patch 114162-01 or later

x86 Platform

Solaris 8 with patch 114163-01 or later

Title: SGI IRIX libns_ldap Bug May Let Remote Users Access Systems Without a Password
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in SGI's name service daemon LDAP implementation on the IRIX operating system.  A remote user may be able to access a system without having to authenticate.
It is reported that the LDAP name service implementation in IRIX does not properly detect whether a remote LDAP server provides the USERPASSWORD attribute for each entry in the password database.  A remote user could login to a system that uses the LDAP service without having to supply a password.
Impact': A remote user could login to a system that uses the LDAP authentication service without having to supply a password.
Solution:
The vendor is releasing a fixed version (6.5.20) of the operating system.

The vendor has also released patch 5063 for IRIX 6.5.15 - 6.5.19.  The patch file checksums are:
