Title: NetBSD Operating System Kernel Race Condition May Let a Local User Obtain Root Privileges on the Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): NetBSD-current:	prior to January 14, 2002, NetBSD-1.5.*: up to and including 1.5.2, NetBSD-1.4.*: up to and including 1.4.3
Description:
NetBSD issued an advisory warning of a kernel security flaw in the NetBSD operating system.  A local user could theoretically obtain root access on the system.
It is reported that a process may be able to exec a set user id (suid) root binary and gain ptrace control over the process in a short period before the process is activated.  Then the ptrace controller process could modify the address space of the controlled process and perform functions with root privileges.

The bug is reportedly due to a race condition.  No technical details were provided.
Impact': A local user could obtain root privileges on the host.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  The vendor recommends that anyone who grants or has granted user accounts to untrusted users on their systems should apply the patch for this issue immediately.  NetBSD has provided the following instructions that describe how to upgrade your kernel by updating your source tree or patching it:

* NetBSD-current:

        Systems running NetBSD-current dated from before 2002-01-14
        should be upgraded to NetBSD-current dated 2002-01-15 or later.

        The following files need to be updated from the
        netbsd-current CVS branch (aka HEAD):
                sys/kern/kern_exec.c
                sys/kern/sys_process.c
                sys/sys/proc.h
                sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_ctl.c
                sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_mem.c
                sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_regs.c
                sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_vnops.c

        To update your kernel sources from CVS:
                # cd src
                # cvs update -d -P sys/kern/kern_exec.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/kern/sys_process.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/sys/proc.h
                # cvs update -d -P sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_ctl.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_mem.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_regs.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_vnops.c

        Then build and install a new kernel. If you are not familiar
        with this process, documentation is available at:

                http://www.netbsd.org/Documentation/kernel/#how_to_build_a_kernel

* NetBSD 1.5, 1.5.1, 1.5.2:

        Systems running NetBSD 1.5-branch sources dated from
        before 2002-01-14 should be upgraded from NetBSD 1.5-branch
        sources dated 2002-01-15 or later.

        The following files need to be updated from the
        netbsd-1-5 CVS branch:
                sys/kern/kern_exec.c
                sys/kern/sys_process.c
                sys/sys/proc.h
                sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_ctl.c
                sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_mem.c
                sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_regs.c

        To update your existing checkout of 1.5-branch kernel sources from CVS:

                # cd src
                # cvs update -d -P sys/kern/kern_exec.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/kern/sys_process.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/sys/proc.h
                # cvs update -d -P sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_ctl.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_mem.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_regs.c
                # cvs update -d -P sys/miscfs/procfs/procfs_vnops.c

        Then build and install a new kernel. If you are not familiar
        with this process, documentation is available at:

                http://www.netbsd.org/Documentation/kernel/#how_to_build_a_kernel

        Alternatively, apply the following patch (with potential offset
        differences):

                ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD/security/patches/SA2002-001-ptrace-1.5.patch

        To patch:

                # cd src
                # patch < /path/to/SA2002-001-ptrace-1.5.patch

        Then build and install a new kernel. If you are not familiar
        with this process, documentation is available at:

                http://www.netbsd.org/Documentation/kernel/#how_to_build_a_kernel


* NetBSD 1.4, 1.4.1, 1.4.2, 1.4.3:

        Apply the following patch (with potential offset differences):

                ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD/security/patches/SA2002-001-ptrace-1.4.patch

        To patch:

                # cd src
                # patch < /path/to/SA2002-001-ptrace-1.4.patch

        Then build and install a new kernel. If you are not familiar
        with this process, documentation is available at:

                http://www.netbsd.org/Documentation/kernel/#how_to_build_a_kernel

Title: HP-UX File System Deadlock Condition Allows Local Users to Cause the Operating System to Crash
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
HP reported a denial of service vulnerability in their HP-UX operating system.  A local user could cause the system to crash.
It is reported that a local user could exploit a file system weakness to cause the operating system to hang.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user could cause the operating system to hang.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix with the following patches:

10.20  Series 700,       PHKL_24517,
10.20  Series 800,       PHKL_24518,
11.00,                   PHKL_22932,
11.04  (VVOS),           PHKL_25033,
11.11,                   PHKL_23335.

The vendor notes that HP-UX 10.24 (VVOS) is not vulnerable.
Underlying OS Comments: HP9000 Series 700/800 running HP-UX releases 10.20, 10.24, 11.00, 11.04, and 11.11 only.

Title: IBM AIX Loadable Authentication Modules Gives Root Access to Remote Users
Description:
IBM reported an authentication vulnerability in IBM's AIX UNIX operating system's loadable authentication modules.  A remote user can obtain root access on the system.
It is reported that there is a password checking flaw under integrated login in AIX.  A remote user can log into a system with an invalid password if the system is configured to use loadable authentication modules, as used in integrated login methods.  IBM notes that this vulnerability does not occur when using only local password files (the default authentication mechanism for AIX) or when using NIS.
Impact': A remote user can log into the system with root level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released an APAR to fix this vulnerability:

AIX 5.1L: APAR #IY26302

The fix can be obtained via the Vendor URL or by following instructions contained in the Source Message.

Title: (Caldera Issues Revised Fix) Caldera OpenServer (SCO) Kernel Flaw May Let Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Caldera reported a vulnerability in the OpenServer kernel.  A local user could execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.
The kernel flaw lets local unprivileged user processes reprogram segment descriptors and certain other CPU registers.  
The following files are affected:

/etc/conf/pack.d/kernel/os.a(machdep.o)
/etc/conf/pack.d/kernel/os.a(sysi86.o)
Impact': A local user could execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.
Solution:
Warning:  Caldera reports that the fixed mentioned in this advisory is also flawed.  They have released an updated advisory with a corrected fix (see the Message History for a separate alert containing the corrected fix).

Do not use the fix in this advisory.

Title: Sun Solaris on Enterprise 10000 May Allow Local Users to Prevent the System from Booting or Potentially Obtain Root Access
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
Sun reported a denial of service vulnerability in Solaris 2.6 for the Enterprise 10000 platform only.
A local user may be able to prevent an Enterprise 10000 system from booting.  The vendor also notes that a local user may be able to gain root access on the system.

This issue only affects the Enterprise 10000 systems.

No details were provided by the vendor.
Impact': A local user may be able to prevent the system from booting or may be able to gain root access on the system.
Solution: The vendor has developed a fix in Solaris 2.6 with patch 105181-30 or later.
Underlying OS Comments: Solaris 2.6 with patches 105181-05 through 105181-29 on Enterprise 10000 only

Title: FreeBSD AIO Input/Output Routines May Allow Local Users to Execute Arbitrary Code With Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in FreeBSD's AIO implementation for performing POSIX-compliant asynchronous input and output.  Under certain conditions, a local user may execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
It is reported that, under certain conditions, scheduled AIO operations may persist after an execve() call, allowing memory of the new process to be arbitrarily overwritten.  If the subsequent process has set user id (suid) permissions, the local user could obtain elevated privileges.  Only certain types of file descriptors can be exploited in this manner.

It is reported that VFS_AIO is not currently enabled in the default FreeBSD kernel configuration and that comments in ``LINT'' suggest that security issues have been known for some time.

Demonstration exploit code is apparently available at: http://elysium.soniq.net/dr/tao/tao.c
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges, giving that user elevated privileges on the system.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report has made an unofficial patch available to limit the use of AIO syscalls to root:

http://elysium.soniq.net/dr/tao/patch-01

Title: (OpenBSD Issues Fix) BSD Line Printer Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Level Access to the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): OpenBSD CURRENT and earlier, FreeBSD 4.3 and earlier, NetBSD 1.5.1 and earlier, BSD/OS 4.1 and earlier
Description:
Internet Security Systems announced a vulnerability in the BSD Line Printer daemon ('in.lpd') that allows remote users to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges.  This affects BSD/OS, NetBSD, FreeBSD, and OpenBSD.
A remote user can submit a specially crafted, incomplete print job and then can request a display of the printer queue to trigger a buffer overflow.  It is reported that the code that parses the first request (the incomplete print job) contains a static buffer overflow.  This allows a remote user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, thereby gaining root level access on the server.

It is reported that FreeBSD and OpenBSD do not enable in.lpd by default and that BSD/OS enables in.pld by defaut but with with an empty configuration file.  As a result, those platforms are not vulnerable in the default configuration.

It is reported that the remote user must initiate an attack from a host that is listed in the "/etc/hosts.equiv" or "/etc/hosts.lpd" file of the target host.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges and can gain root level access to the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  This problem is fixed in OpenBSD-current, the 3.0 patch branch (aka 3.0-stable) and the 2.9 branch (aka 2.9-stable).

A patch exists to fix the problem:

For OpenBSD-2.9 (as well as OpenBSD-2.8):
    ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/2.9/common/017_lpd.patch

For OpenBSD-3.0
    ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.0/common/008_lpd.patch

Title: OpenBSD UNIX Operating System Kernel Pipe() Error Lets Local Users Crash the Kernel
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability has been reported in the OpenBSD UNIX operating system.  A local unprivileged user can cause the kernel to crash.
A local non-root user can cause the kernel to crash.  If a user attempts to open a pipe() with a null file descriptor, the kernel will crash.  The flaw is reportedly due to some incorrect code in the sys_pipe() function in the uipc_syscalls.c source code file.  When the sys_pipe() function encounters a certain file descriptor error, it releases a user-level variable (retval) instead of the kernel-level variable (rval).  Because pipe() was originally called with a NULL file descriptor and, as a result, the retval pointer was pointing at NULL, the release of the retval space causes unexpected and unstable behavior.

This flaw was apparently discovered by Marco Peereboom <marcodsl@swbell.net>.  

This flaw has reportedly been verified by Rapid 7.

Some demonstration exploit code is contained in the Source Message.
Impact': A local non-root user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution: An unofficial patch for kernel version 2.9 is included in the Source Message.  Official patches will likely be released shortly.

Title: Caldera OpenServer (SCO) Kernel Flaw May Let Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Caldera reported a vulnerability in the OpenServer kernel.  A local user could execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.
The kernel flaw lets local unprivileged user processes reprogram segment descriptors and certain other CPU registers.  
The following files are affected:

/etc/conf/pack.d/kernel/os.a(machdep.o)
/etc/conf/pack.d/kernel/os.a(sysi86.o)
Impact': A local user could execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix:

ftp://stage.caldera.com/pub/security/openserver/CSSA-2001-SCO.35/

The md5 checksum is:

        89a6894b514d0175676d12745158aaea        VOL.000.000

Caldera has provided the following instructions and warnings:

        Upgrade the affected binaries with the following commands:

        Download the VOL.000.000 file to /tmp

        # custom

        Instruct custom to install from images, and supply /tmp as the
        directory of the VOL image.

        Closing this family of security holes does, however, result in
        a functionality change which may prevent certain applications
        from running -- they will exit with an error, or dump core,
        instead of running properly.  For example, the i286emul and
        x286emul emulators will not work, so any '286 executables
        which require those emulators will not work.  It is our
        intention to enhance this patch in the future, such that it
        enables full functionality of such applications while still
        closing the security holes.

        If this patch breaks any crucial applications, the system
        administrator may choose to disable the patch, by editing the
        file /etc/conf/pack.d/kernel/space.c and setting the value of
        the allow_dscr_remap parameter to 1.  This will return the
        kernel to the old (not-secure) behavior.

Title: (NetBSD Issues Fix) BSD Line Printer Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Level Access to the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): OpenBSD CURRENT and earlier, FreeBSD 4.3 and earlier, NetBSD 1.5.1 and earlier, BSD/OS 4.1 and earlier
Description:
Internet Security Systems announced a vulnerability in the BSD Line Printer daemon ('in.lpd') that allows remote users to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges.  This affects BSD/OS, NetBSD, FreeBSD, and OpenBSD.
A remote user can submit a specially crafted, incomplete print job and then can request a display of the printer queue to trigger a buffer overflow.  It is reported that the code that parses the first request (the incomplete print job) contains a static buffer overflow.  This allows a remote user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, thereby gaining root level access on the server.

It is reported that FreeBSD and OpenBSD do not enable in.lpd by default and that BSD/OS enables in.pld by defaut but with with an empty configuration file.  As a result, those platforms are not vulnerable in the default configuration.

It is reported that the remote user must initiate an attack from a host that is listed in the "/etc/hosts.equiv" or "/etc/hosts.lpd" file of the target host.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges and can gain root level access to the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  The vendor reports that NetBSD 1.3 and later install with lpd disabled by default and that a NetBSD system is vulnerable to this security hole only if it is running /usr/sbin/lpd and access to lpd is allowed by entries in /etc/hosts.lpd.  If this is the case, the vendor recommends updating the binary.

The vendor has provided the following workaround:

"If you are running /usr/sbin/lpd, and you do not need it, stop it. 
If you have /etc/hosts.lpd which is open to everyone, you will want to
tighten the setup so that no malicious parties can access your remote printer."


* NetBSD -current, 1.5, 1.5.1, 1.5.2:

For systems running NetBSD-current dated from before 2001-08-28, upgrade to NetBSD-current dated 2001-08-28 or later.

For systems running NetBSD 1.5, 1.5.1 or 1.5.2 dated from before 2001-09-30, upgrade to NetBSD-1.5 branch sources dated 2001-09-30 or later.

The following directory needs to be updated from the netbsd-current CVS branch (aka HEAD) for NetBSD-current, or netbsd-1-5 CVS branch for NetBSD 1.5, 1.5.1 or 1.5.2:

src/usr.sbin/lpr

To update from CVS, re-build, and re-install lpd(8):
                # cd src/usr.sbin/lpr
                # cvs update -d -P
                # make cleandir dependall install


        Alternatively, apply the following patch (with potential offset
        differences) and rebuild & re-install lpd(8):
                ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD/security/patches/SA2001-018-lpd.patch

        To patch, re-build and re-install lpd(8):
                # cd src/usr.sbin/lpr/common_sources
                # patch < /path/to/SA2001-012-lpd.patch
                # make cleandir dependall install

* NetBSD 1.4, 1.4.x:

For systems running NetBSD-1.4.x releases, apply the following patch (with potential offset differences):
                ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD/security/patches/SA2001-018-lpd.patch

        To patch, re-build and re-install lpd(8):
                # cd src/usr.sbin/lpr/common_sources
                # patch < /path/to/SA2001-012-lpd.patch
                # make cleandir dependall install


The vendor reports that the anonymous CVS branch netbsd-1-4 should be updated with a fix in the near future.

Title: Sun Solaris Kernel send() Library Input Validation Flaw Enables Local Users to Cause the Kernel to Consume Excessive CPU Resources
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
Sun reported an input validation flaw in the Solaris kernel send(3SOCKET) library.  A local user can cause the kernel processing performance to degrade significantly or completely.
Sun reports that an unprivileged local user may create socket-based applications that pass invalid arguments to the "send(3SOCKET)" library function.  This can result in the kernel entering a busy loop, causing "significant degradation" in the system's performance.

This vulnerability has been assigned Sun BugID: 4432295
Impact': A local user can cause the kernel to consume a significant amount of or all available CPU resources.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  Obtain the following patches from the vendor:

SPARC 

     Solaris 7 with patch 106541-18 or later 
     Solaris 8 with patch 108528-10 or later 

Intel 

     Solaris 7 with patch 106542-18 or later 
     Solaris 8 with patch 108529-10 or later
Underlying OS Comments: SPARC: Solaris 7 without patch 106541-18, Solaris 8 without patch 108528-10; Intel: Solaris 7 without patch 106542-18, Solaris 8 without patch 108529-10; Solaris 2.6 and earlier are not affected.

Title: Sun Solaris pt_chmod Access Control Vulnerability Lets Local Users Obtain Write Access to Another User's TTY
Description:
The Dublin City University Networking Society (RedBrick) reported a vulnerability in pt_chmod.  The utility does not recognize access control lists and allows local users to obtain write access on relinquished ttys as they are allocated to other users.
It is reported that a local user can obtain full write access on all tty's previously allocated to another user when they are reallocated. A local user can ammend the access control list (ACL) on a tty that they own such that when the tty is later allocated to another user, the original user retains write access.  This allows a local user to send bogus output to another user's tty.

It is reported that read/execute permissions are not retained.

The author of the report notes that this issue has been previously discussed on the comp.unix.solaris and comp.unix.security newsgroups.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain write access to another user's tty.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report provides the following recommendations:

        "adding  " setfacl -s user::6,group::2,mask:2,other:0 `tty` "
        to shell profile startup scripts as a temporary solution.
        Be aware that this solution has an inherent race condition
        allowing your tty to be written to in the short time between
        tty allocation and your shell processing the startup file.
        It is also common for setups to allow the non-processing of such
        startup files. For our own purposes we have patched the pt_chmod
        source, however we believe that distribution of the (or at least
        a contextual ) patch violates the license. The neccessary 
        ammendments which need to be made to pt_chmod.c are:

        include the sys/acl.h header

        declare in main() :
        aclent_t aclbuf[4]={
                                { USER_OBJ  , 0, 6 },
                                { GROUP_OBJ , 0, 2 },
                                { OTHER_OBJ , 0, 0 },
                                { CLASS_OBJ , 0, 2 }
                           };

        implement towards end of main() :

        if(acl(ptsname(fd),SETACL,4,aclbuf))
                exit(-1);

        ps. if you mess up installation of pt_chmod you can render your
            machine unusable, you have been warned."

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Re: BSD Line Printer Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Level Access to the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): OpenBSD CURRENT and earlier, FreeBSD 4.3 and earlier, NetBSD 1.5.1 and earlier, BSD/OS 4.1 and earlier
Description:
Internet Security Systems announced a vulnerability in the BSD Line Printer daemon ('in.lpd') that allows remote users to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges.  This affects BSD/OS, NetBSD, FreeBSD, and OpenBSD.
A remote user can submit a specially crafted, incomplete print job and then can request a display of the printer queue to trigger a buffer overflow.  It is reported that the code that parses the first request (the incomplete print job) contains a static buffer overflow.  This allows a remote user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, thereby gaining root level access on the server.

It is reported that FreeBSD and OpenBSD do not enable in.lpd by default and that BSD/OS enables in.pld by defaut but with with an empty configuration file.  As a result, those platforms are not vulnerable in the default configuration.

It is reported that the remote user must initiate an attack from a host that is listed in the "/etc/hosts.equiv" or "/etc/hosts.lpd" file of the target host.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges and can gain root level access to the system.
Solution:
Red Hat has issued a fix:

Red Hat Linux 6.2:

SRPMS:
ftp://updates.redhat.com/6.2/en/os/SRPMS/lpr-0.50.5-1.src.rpm

alpha:
ftp://updates.redhat.com/6.2/en/os/alpha/lpr-0.50.5-1.alpha.rpm

i386:
ftp://updates.redhat.com/6.2/en/os/i386/lpr-0.50.5-1.i386.rpm

sparc:
ftp://updates.redhat.com/6.2/en/os/sparc/lpr-0.50.5-1.sparc.rpm

The verification checksums are:

MD5 sum                          Package Name
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
084ffb7aad218ce6bba390de33218ad8 6.2/en/os/SRPMS/lpr-0.50.5-1.src.rpm
19111f0738ddeac4f9ed29c59b3c3656 6.2/en/os/alpha/lpr-0.50.5-1.alpha.rpm
c1f8f77d761223d42ee90367a716aa8e 6.2/en/os/i386/lpr-0.50.5-1.i386.rpm
be898ec1250c4a3f5d06da6e12c62176 6.2/en/os/sparc/lpr-0.50.5-1.sparc.rpm

These packages are GPG signed by Red Hat, Inc. for security.  The GPG key is available at:
    http://www.redhat.com/about/contact/pgpkey.html

You can verify each package with the following command:
    rpm --checksig  <filename>

If you only wish to verify that each package has not been corrupted or tampered with, examine only the md5sum with the following command:
    rpm --checksig --nogpg <filename>

Title: HP-UX OS for Itanium Processor Family Has Incorrect Permissions on All HP-UX Commands, Letting Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges
Description:
HP reported a security vulnerability in HP-UX 11.20 running on the Itanium processor.  All HP-UX commands are incorrectly built and allow local users to gain elevated privileges.
It is reported that security restrictions are not consistently enforced when starting applications under HP-UX 11.20.
Impact': A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
HP has issued a patch:

HP-UX 11.20:       PHSS_25454
Underlying OS Comments: Only the native Itanium version of HP-UX is affected

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) BSD Line Printer Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Level Access to the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): OpenBSD CURRENT and earlier, FreeBSD 4.3 and earlier, NetBSD 1.5.1 and earlier, BSD/OS 4.1 and earlier
Description:
Internet Security Systems announced a vulnerability in the BSD Line Printer daemon ('in.lpd') that allows remote users to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges.  This affects BSD/OS, NetBSD, FreeBSD, and OpenBSD.
A remote user can submit a specially crafted, incomplete print job and then can request a display of the printer queue to trigger a buffer overflow.  It is reported that the code that parses the first request (the incomplete print job) contains a static buffer overflow.  This allows a remote user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, thereby gaining root level access on the server.

It is reported that FreeBSD and OpenBSD do not enable in.lpd by default and that BSD/OS enables in.pld by defaut but with with an empty configuration file.  As a result, those platforms are not vulnerable in the default configuration.

It is reported that the remote user must initiate an attack from a host that is listed in the "/etc/hosts.equiv" or "/etc/hosts.lpd" file of the target host.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges and can gain root level access to the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix, avaliable at the ftp locations listed in the Source Message.

The packages can be updated with the command `rpm -Uhv file.rpm'.  The vendor indicates that users should, as root, invoke the command "/etc/rc.d/lpd stop" to shutdown the old lpd daemon and "/etc/rc.d/lpd start" afterwards to start the patched daemon.

Title: (Patches Have Been Available) Re: IBM's High Availability Cluster Multi-Processing (HACMP) Software Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM's High Availability Cluster Multi-Processing (HACMP) clustering software.  Remote users can cause the clustered servers to crash by port scanning them.
It is reported that IBM's HACMP 4.4 clustering software can be made to crash by remote users by conducting a TCP CONNECT port scan.  It is reported that TCP SYN port scans will not crash the clustered hosts.
Impact': A remote user can cause the servers in the cluster to crash.
Solution:
A user reports that the problem was due to a bug in snmpd and that patches have been available for a while.

For AIX 4.3 users, upgrading to Maintenance Level 7 will reportedly fix the problem.   For AIX 4.3.3 users, the APAR to apply is IY17630.  For AIX 5.1 users, apply APAR IY20943.

These APARs are reportedly available at:

http://techsupport.services.ibm.com/rs6000/fixes

Title: (Users Report a Potential Solution) Re: IBM's High Availability Cluster Multi-Processing (HACMP) Software Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM's High Availability Cluster Multi-Processing (HACMP) clustering software.  Remote users can cause the clustered servers to crash by port scanning them.
It is reported that IBM's HACMP 4.4 clustering software can be made to crash by remote users by conducting a TCP CONNECT port scan.  It is reported that TCP SYN port scans will not crash the clustered hosts.
Impact': A remote user can cause the servers in the cluster to crash.
Solution: Several users have reported that applying Maintenance Level 7 on AIX 4.3.3 has corrected the problem for them.

Title: IBM's High Availability Cluster Multi-Processing (HACMP) Software Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in IBM's High Availability Cluster Multi-Processing (HACMP) clustering software.  Remote users can cause the clustered servers to crash by port scanning them.
It is reported that IBM's HACMP 4.4 clustering software can be made to crash by remote users by conducting a TCP CONNECT port scan.  It is reported that TCP SYN port scans will not crash the clustered hosts.
Impact': A remote user can cause the servers in the cluster to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Login Class Capability Database Lets Local Users Read Any File on the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the login_cap login class capability database library utility that allows local users to read any file on the system (with root level privileges).
Login classes, which are configured in the user account database (/etc/master.passwd), are used to determine session accounting, resource limits, and user environment settings.  Certain set user id (suid) root applications that do not drop privileges before querying the login capabilities database can be tricked into reading any file on the system by a valid local user.  The local user can edit their login.conf file to specify a target file to be read in place of the master.passwd file.  Then, when the suid application calls login_cap(), the target file will be read with elevated privileges.

This can reportedly be exploited by using OpenSSH to read any file on the system if the user puts the following settings in their login.conf file:

default:\
	:copyright=/etc/master.passwd:

or
	:welcome=/etc/master.passwd:

It is reported that login(1) can also be used to exploit this vulnerability:

default:\
	:nologin=/etc/master.passwd:
Impact': A local user can read any file on the system.
Solution:
FreeBSD has reportedly committed a fix to the CVS source code repository:

http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/cvsweb.cgi/~checkout~/src/lib/libutil/login_cap.c?rev=1.17.2.3&content-type=text/plain
Underlying OS Comments: specifically confirmed on FreeBSD 4.4 and earlier; other BSD-based systems may be affected

Title: HP Warns of Local Denial of Service Vulnerability in 'libsecurity' for HP-UX Virtual Vault Operating System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): HP9000 Servers running HP-UX 11.04 (VVOS), VirtualVault only
Description:
HP reported that there is a vulnerability in libsecurity for HP-UX Virtual Vault OS that could allow a local user to cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that a problem in libsecurity.2 causes unexpected resource handling problems.

The vendor provided no further details.
Impact':
A local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.  The exact nature of these conditions was not disclosed by the vendor. 

[Editor's note:  Be warned that HP has a history of using the term 'denial of service' for some HP product vulnerabilities that have enabled users to obtain elevated user privileges or root level privileges.]
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch:

HP-UX 11.04 (VVOS): PHCO_24852

Title: IBM AIX Line Printer Daemon (lpd) Has Buffer Overflow That Lets Remote Users Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
It is reported that the line printer daemon, lpd, that is shipped with IBM's AIX operating system contains several buffer overflow vulnerabilities that could allow a remote user to obtain root level privileges on the server.
IBM reports that two of the three vulnerabilities require the remote user to be on a host listed in the /etc/hosts.lpd or /etc/hosts.equiv files.  The third vulnerability reportedly requires that the remote attacker have control over the target's domain name server (DNS).

This vulnerability is reportedly similar to those recently reported for Solaris and for BSD implementations.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server in certain situations, leading to root level access on the system.
Solution:
The vendor will be releasing a fix soon with the following patch numbers:

AIX 4.3:  APAR #IY23037
AIX 5.1:  APAR #IY23041

For workaround suggestions, see the Source Message for the vendor's advisory.

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Revised Instructions) Fts Libc File Traversal Routines May Let Local Users Cause the Routines to Make Unauthorized Modification to or Removal of Files on the System
Version(s): FreeBSD 4.3-RELEASE, 4.3-STABLE prior to the correction date; other OSs may also be affected
Description:
FreeBSD announced a race condition vulnerability in the fts routines that are used to traverse a file system that may allow a local user to cause the application using fts to access other parts of the file system.
The fts standard C library (libc) routines are reportedly vulnerable to a race condition when ascending a file hierarchy, which allows a local user that has control over part of the hierarchy into which fts is descending to cause the application to ascend beyond the starting point of the file traversal and enter other parts of the filesystem.

If the fts routines are being used by an application to perform operations on the filesystem (such as a recursive find or rm), the application may cause system damage or unauthorized modification of files.
Impact': A local user may be able to cause files to be removed or modified when another user executes a command that uses the fts routines in a vulnerable manner.
Solution: The vendor has released revised compilation instructions.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.
Underlying OS Comments: Advisory is for FreeBSD, but it also applies to other OSs

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Updated Fix) FreeBSD's rmuser User Management Script Discloses the Password File to Local Users
Version(s): FreeBSD 4.2-RELEASE, 4.3-RELEASE, FreeBSD 4.3-STABLE prior to the correction date.
Description:
FreeBSD reported a vulnerability in their 'rmuser' perl-based user management script that allows a local user to access the /etc/master.passwd file due to a race condition.
When the rmuser script removes a user from the system, it updates the /etc/master.passwd file in a non-secure way by creating a new master.passwd file with an unsafe umask and then using chmod to set its permissions to 0600.  As a result, the file is world-readable during a brief period of time.

It is reported that all versions of FreeBSD prior to the correction date including FreeBSD 4.3 contain this problem.  The base system that will ship with FreeBSD 4.4 reportedly will not contain this problem.
Impact': A local user can read the /etc/master.passwd file to obtain password hashes.  These hashes can then be subject to brute force or dictionary attacks in an attempt to crack the passwords.
Solution: The vendor has released an updated fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the new fix.

Title: (NetBSD Issues Fix) Fts Libc File Traversal Routines May Let Local Users Cause the Routines to Make Unauthorized Modification to or Removal of Files on the System
Version(s): FreeBSD 4.3-RELEASE, 4.3-STABLE prior to the correction date; other OSs may also be affected
Description:
FreeBSD announced a race condition vulnerability in the fts routines that are used to traverse a file system that may allow a local user to cause the application using fts to access other parts of the file system.
The fts standard C library (libc) routines are reportedly vulnerable to a race condition when ascending a file hierarchy, which allows a local user that has control over part of the hierarchy into which fts is descending to cause the application to ascend beyond the starting point of the file traversal and enter other parts of the filesystem.

If the fts routines are being used by an application to perform operations on the filesystem (such as a recursive find or rm), the application may cause system damage or unauthorized modification of files.
Impact': A local user may be able to cause files to be removed or modified when another user executes a command that uses the fts routines in a vulnerable manner.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.
Underlying OS Comments: Advisory is for FreeBSD, but it also applies to other OSs

Title: (Sun Issues Fix) Sun Solaris SNMP-to-DMI Network Management Protocol Mapper Allows Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root-Level Access to the Affected Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was discovered in the Sun Solaris SNMP-to-DMI mapper daemon that can allow a remote user to execute arbitrary code on the affected host and obtain root level privileges.  Desktop Management Interface (DMI) and Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) are remote network management protocols.
The SNMP-to-DMI mapper daemon contains a buffer overflow in its handling of an "indication" (a DMI event that is converted into an SNMP Trap). This "indication" is transmitted to the mapper daemon over RPC service 1000249.

The author of the report notes that an exploit was successfully tested on Solaris 8 sun4u, but that previous versions are likely vulnerable.  The affected daemon was reportedly bundled with Solaris 2.6, 7 and 8.
Impact': A local or remote user could execute arbitrary code on the server and obtain root level privileges.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: NetBSD Kernel Security Holes Let Local Users Panic the System and/or Execute Arbitrary Code to Gain Root Level Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): NetBSD-current source prior to August 5, 2001, NetBSD-1.5.1, NetBSD-1.5, NetBSD-1.4.*
Description:
NetBSD issued a security advisory warning of several kernel security issues that were discovered during a recent code audit.  The security holes are due to insufficient length checking on variables passed to the kernel and can allow a local user to panic the system or obtain root level privileges.
The following issues have been reported:

semop(2) - Any local user can exploit this to deny service or to execute arbitrary kernel code.  If a local user passes a large 'nsops' value (>INT_MAX) via the sempo(2) call, the kernel function sys_semop() will not check for an oversized value (negative value), allowing data from user memory space to be written to the process's kernel stack.

mount args - If user mounts are enabled, any local user can exploit this to deny service.  User mounts are disabled by default on NetBSD 1.5 and later.  It is reported that NFS does not check the nfs file handle size and the size of some other strings, allowing a local user to cause a kernel panic.

some device ioctls - Any local user with write access to the appropriate device files can exploit this.  Note that, by default, only root has write access on most device files.  Some device drivers (listed in the Source Message) performed checking  in their ioctl(9) routines, allowing a local user to cause a kernel panic.  In addition, the lfs_markv(2) system call (which is restricted to root users) does not check the blkcnt argument, allowing a local root-level user to cause a kernel panic.
Impact': A local user can cause a kernel panic or can execute arbitrary code with root level privileges to gain root level access on the host.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix in the following branches:

NetBSD-current August 5, 2001
NetBSD-1.5 branch August 16, 2001 (1.5.2 includes the fix)

For further patch instructions, see the Source Message.

Title: OpenBSD nfs Kernel Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code in Kernel Mode
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
OpenBSD reported a vulnerability in their NFS mount code that allows a local user to execute arbitrary code in kernel mode.
Only users with mount privileges can trigger the vulnerability, which is limited to root level users in default installations.
Impact': A local user with access to the mount(2) utility can execute arbitrary code in kernel mode.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/2.9/common/012_nfs.patch

Title: FreeBSD's rmuser User Management Script Discloses the Password File to Local Users
Version(s): FreeBSD 4.2-RELEASE, 4.3-RELEASE, FreeBSD 4.3-STABLE prior to the correction date.
Description:
FreeBSD reported a vulnerability in their 'rmuser' perl-based user management script that allows a local user to access the /etc/master.passwd file due to a race condition.
When the rmuser script removes a user from the system, it updates the /etc/master.passwd file in a non-secure way by creating a new master.passwd file with an unsafe umask and then using chmod to set its permissions to 0600.  As a result, the file is world-readable during a brief period of time.

It is reported that all versions of FreeBSD prior to the correction date including FreeBSD 4.3 contain this problem.  The base system that will ship with FreeBSD 4.4 reportedly will not contain this problem.
Impact': A local user can read the /etc/master.passwd file to obtain password hashes.  These hashes can then be subject to brute force or dictionary attacks in an attempt to crack the passwords.
Solution:
The vendor has released patches.  Patch information is included in the Source Message.

As a workaround, the vendor suggests using the pw(8) utility to remove users instead of rmuser:

    - "pw userdel <username>" will only remove the user from
      /etc/passwd, /etc/master.passwd and /etc/group
    - "pw -r userdel <username>" will also remove the user's home
      dirrectory

The correction date for the following versions is:
2001-07-28 12:10:15 UTC (4.3-STABLE)
2001-09-04 07:46:57 UTC (RELENG_4_3)

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Fix) BSD Line Printer Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Level Access to the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): OpenBSD CURRENT and earlier, FreeBSD 4.3 and earlier, NetBSD 1.5.1 and earlier, BSD/OS 4.1 and earlier
Description:
Internet Security Systems announced a vulnerability in the BSD Line Printer daemon ('in.lpd') that allows remote users to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges.  This affects BSD/OS, NetBSD, FreeBSD, and OpenBSD.
A remote user can submit a specially crafted, incomplete print job and then can request a display of the printer queue to trigger a buffer overflow.  It is reported that the code that parses the first request (the incomplete print job) contains a static buffer overflow.  This allows a remote user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, thereby gaining root level access on the server.

It is reported that FreeBSD and OpenBSD do not enable in.lpd by default and that BSD/OS enables in.pld by defaut but with with an empty configuration file.  As a result, those platforms are not vulnerable in the default configuration.

It is reported that the remote user must initiate an attack from a host that is listed in the "/etc/hosts.equiv" or "/etc/hosts.lpd" file of the target host.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges and can gain root level access to the system.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: BSD Line Printer Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Root Level Access to the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): OpenBSD CURRENT and earlier, FreeBSD 4.3 and earlier, NetBSD 1.5.1 and earlier, BSD/OS 4.1 and earlier
Description:
Internet Security Systems announced a vulnerability in the BSD Line Printer daemon ('in.lpd') that allows remote users to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the server with root level privileges.  This affects BSD/OS, NetBSD, FreeBSD, and OpenBSD.
A remote user can submit a specially crafted, incomplete print job and then can request a display of the printer queue to trigger a buffer overflow.  It is reported that the code that parses the first request (the incomplete print job) contains a static buffer overflow.  This allows a remote user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, thereby gaining root level access on the server.

It is reported that FreeBSD and OpenBSD do not enable in.lpd by default and that BSD/OS enables in.pld by defaut but with with an empty configuration file.  As a result, those platforms are not vulnerable in the default configuration.

It is reported that the remote user must initiate an attack from a host that is listed in the "/etc/hosts.equiv" or "/etc/hosts.lpd" file of the target host.

Solution:
Vendor patches are available or are pending.  See the following URLs or check the Message History for future updates:

http://www.BSDI.COM/services/support/patches/patches-4.1/M410-044
http://www.openbsd.com/errata.html
http://www.netbsd.org/security
http://www.freebsd.org/security

Title: Caldera (SCO) UnixWare/Open UNIX uidadmin Utility May Let Local Users Obtain Root Level Access via a Buffer Overflow
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Caldera (SCO) reported a vulnerability in the uidadmin utility for Open Linux (UnixWare).  The security hole may allow local users to execute arbitrary code on the system with root level privileges.
It is reported that a long argument supplied to the uidadmin admin using the "-S" (scheme) command line switch will cause uidadmin to crash due to a buffer overflow.  A local user may be able to obtain root privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix, available at:

ftp://ftp.sco.com/pub/security/openunix/sr847563/

md5 checksums:
6778640ca80a88ed3af993adbe839bfb
erg711722a.Z

Title: NetBSD dump Utility Lets Local Users Obtain 'tty' Group Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): NetBSD-current: source prior to August 8, 2001, NetBSD 1.5.1, NetBSD 1.5, NetBSD 1.4.x
Description:
NetBSD reports that the dump utility for NetBSD contains a vulnerability that allows a local user to obtain tty group privileges.
It is reported that the dump(8) command (installed as /sbin/dump) and the dump_lfs(8) command (installed as /sbin/dump_lfs) are configured with set group id (setgid) tty group privileges.  The programs apparently do not drop those setgid tty rights when not needed, including when a user supplied RCMD_CMD environment variable is executed.

These programs reportedly require tty group rights in order to notify members of the operator group to change backup media.

A similar vulnerability was reported with the dump utility on other operating systems last year, but that prior vulnerability resulted in local users gaining root privileges.
Impact': A local user can gain tty group privileges on the host.

Title: FreeBSD procfs Process Filesystem Discloses Sensitive Process Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the FreeBSD procfs process filesystem that allows local users to extract process memory contents from certain processes.
Procfs can be used to extract process information.  It runs with the set group id (setgid) 'kmem' group privilege to allow direct kernel memory access.  The procfs code checks for gid kmem privilege when granting access to the /proc/<pid>/mem file.  However, there is a flaw in the access control code.  Instead of granting read-only access to kmem group members, the process grants read-only access to the caller as long as the caller has an open file descriptor for the procfs mem file.

As a result, if a process initially has debugging rights to a second process, it may retain access to the target process' memory space, even if the target process has obtained elevated privileges via an execve() call on a set user id (setuid) or setgid process.  Sensitive information from such processes could be leaked to the caller.

The vendor reports that this vulnerability may only be exploited on processes that initially are "debuggable" by the attacking process.  Because of this, any attack is reportedly limited to executed processes which gain privilege via setuid or setgid and cannot be targeted against other processes which are already running with a particular privileges.

It is reported that the linprocfs filesystem is also vulnerable if procfs support is available in the kernel.

All released versions of FreeBSD 4.x including FreeBSD 4.3-RELEASE if procfs filesystem is in use.
Impact': A local user may be able to extract sensitive system information (e.g., password hashes from the /etc/master.passwd file or from setuid or setgid processes such as su) from process memory.  This information could be used by a local user to potentially gain elevated privileges on the host.
Solution:
The vendor has provided patches to the following releases as of the following release correction dates:

2001-08-12 07:29 PDT (4.3-STABLE), 2001-08-13 12:45 PDT (RELENG_4_3)

The vulnerability was reportedly corrected prior to the (pending) release of FreeBSD 4.4-RELEASE.

Title: (FreeBSD Issues Revised Fix) FreeBSD Kernel May Allow Local Users to Obtain Root Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): All released versions of FreeBSD 4.x, FreeBSD 4.3-STABLE prior to July 9, 2001
Description:
Georgi Guninski reported a signal handler vulnerability in the FreeBSD kernel that may allow local users to obtain root level privileges.
It is reported that a flaw exists in FreeBSD signal handler clearing that may allow some signal handlers to remain in effect after an exec() call.  This allows a local user to execute arbitrary code with set user id (setuid) root privileges.

When a process forks using rfork(), the child process inherits the parent's signals.  When the child process performs an exec() function, the kernel clears the signal handlers because they are not valid in the new address space.  The vulnerability is due to rfork(RFPROC|RFSIGSHARE), which shares the signal handlers between parent and child processes.  If the child process performs an exec() on a setuid program and then the parent process subsequently sets a signal handler, the signal handler is replicated in the child process.  The address of the signal handler may therefore be available in the environment, so sending a signal to the child process may result in the shared signal handler being executed by the child process.
Impact': A local user can obtain root level privileges on the system.
Solution: The vendor has released a revised fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: (NetBSD Also Vulnerable - Fix is Available) Re: OpenBSD Kernel Race Condition Lets Local Users Gain Root Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Georgi Guninski reported a vulnerability in OpenBSD that lets local users obtain root level access on the host by exploiting a race condition that apparently exists in the kernel.  NetBSD is reportedly also vulnerable.
The vulnerability allows a user to attach to a process id (of /usr/bin/su, for example) using the ptrace function and then cause arbitrary code to be executed with the privileges of the original process (root, for example) before the process is killed.

It is reported that PT_DETACH allows specifying an address to which execution is continued (this is contrary to what is listed in the ptrace man page).

A demonstration exploit is included in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain root level privileges on the host.
Solution: A fix is available for NetBSD.  See the Source Message for details.

Title: SCO Unix su Utility Environment Variable Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Obtain Root Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Caldera reported a vulnerability in the SCO Unix su substitute user utility that allows local users to gain elevated privileges, including root level privileges.
It is reported that if a local user sets the TERM environment variable to a particular long length and then executes the su utility, the user can trigger a buffer overflow that will cause arbitrary code to be executed with root level privileges.
Impact': A local user can obtain root level privileges.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor advisory.

Title: IBM AIX libil8n Library Buffer Overflow May Allow Local Users to Obtain Root Privileges on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
IBM released an advisory for AIX's libil8n library warning that it contains a buffer overflow that could allow local users to obtain root level privileges.
IBM reports that AIX ships with the library "libi18n" located in the "/usr/ccs/lib" directory and that the library contains a buffer overflow in its processing of the LANG environment variable.

A local user can set the "LANG" environment variable to a special value so that when a program is executed that uses the library, arbitrary code may be exectued with the privileges of the program.  If the program is a set user id (suid) root program, the local user could obtain root level privileges.
Impact': A local user could execute arbitrary code on the system with root level privileges, givign the user root level access on the server.
Solution:
IBM is reportedly working on the following fixes:           AIX 4.3.x   -  IY20867
           AIX 5.1.0   -  IY21309

Title: HP Virtual Vault mkacct Utility May Let Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges
Version(s): HP9000 Servers running HP-UX 11.04 (VVOS), VirtualVault only.
Description:
HP reports that the mkacct account creation utility contains a vulnerability that may allow local users to gain privileged access.
The program /sbin/mkacct incorrectly performs its functions, according to the vendor.  As a result, a local user may be able to obtain "privileged access" on the server.  It is not clear if this includes root level access or not.

No further details were provided by the vendor.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch:             VirtualVault 4.0               PHSS_24169,
             VirtualVault 4.5               PHSS_24212.

Title: HP/UX 11.11 Dynamically Loadable Kernel Modules Feature Lets Local Users Get Root Privileges
Version(s): HP9000 Series 700/800 running HP-UX release 11.11 only
Description:
HP reported a vulnerability in HP/UX 11.11 in the Dynamically Loadable Kernel Modules feature that allows a local user to obtain root level privileges on the host.
HP notes that the dlkm static kernel symbol table is incorrectly configured.  No further details were provided by HP.

The vendor reports that HP-UX 11.00 is not vulnerable.
Impact': A local user could obtain root level privileges on the host.
Solution: The vendor has released a patch:  HPUX 11.11 PHCO_23492.  [Editor's note:  The Source Message contains the incorrect patch ID.  The vendor subsequently updated their advisory to include the correct patch ID (PHCO_23492).]

Title: HP/UX Default Configuration Lets Remote Users Cause Increased TCP Overhead and Increased CPU Resource Consumption
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in several operating systems that allows remote users to cause the host to transmit a significantly higher number of packets and consume increased CPU resources to do so, creating a potential denial of service condition.
In the TCP protocol, the initiating host specifies a Maximum Segment Size (MSS) value to request that the remote host send an amount of TCP data no larger than the MSS value in any single IP packet. The purpose is presumably to indicate the largest TCP segment that, if fragmented during transmission, can be reassembled by the initiating host. 

The default configuration of HP/UX allows this value to be set to one. At such a low level, the remote host will send only one byte of data in each TCP segment, which results in a significant increase in packets transmitted (with large headers and a small payload) and in a significant increase in CPU resources consumed to participate in the TCP protocol with these values.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service by setting a low MSS value and then requesting a large amount of data.  This will result in the remote host transmitting a significantly higher number of packets and TCP overhead than would normally be sent and consuming increased CPU resources to do this.
Solution: There is reportedly a method to alter the default MSS configuration value, however, the report did not elablorate on this method.

Title: Solaris Operating System in Default Configuration Lets Remote Users Cause Increased Packet Overhead and Increased CPU Resource Consumption
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in several operating systems that allows remote users to cause the host to transmit a significantly higher number of packets and consume increased CPU resources to do so, creating a potential denial of service condition.

In the TCP protocol, the initiating host specifies a Maximum Segment Size (MSS) value to request that the remote host send an amount of TCP data no larger than the MSS value in any single IP packet.  The purpose is presumably to indicate the largest TCP segment that, if fragmented during transmission, can be reassembled by the initiating host.  

The default configuration of Solaris allows this value to be set to one.  At such a low level, the remote host will send only one byte of data in each TCP segment, which results in a significant increase in packets transmitted (with large headers and a small payload) and in a significant increase in CPU resources consumed to participate in the TCP protocol with these values.
Impact': A remote user can create a potential denial of service condition by causing a remote host to transmit a significantly higher number of packets and TCP overhead than would normally be sent and consume increased CPU resources to do this.
Solution: For Solaris, it is reportedly possible to increase the minimum MSS value from its default setting of "1" using ndd: ndd -set /dev/tcp tcp_mss_min 128

Title: (CIAC Issues Advisory L-111) Re: FreeBSD Kernel May Allow Local Users to Obtain Root Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): All released versions of FreeBSD 4.x, FreeBSD 4.3-STABLE prior to July 9, 2001
Description:
Georgi Guninski reported a signal handler vulnerability in the FreeBSD kernel that may allow local users to obtain root level privileges.
It is reported that a flaw exists in FreeBSD signal handler clearing that may allow some signal handlers to remain in effect after an exec() call.  This allows a local user to execute arbitrary code with set user id (setuid) root privileges.

When a process forks using rfork(), the child process inherits the parent's signals.  When the child process performs an exec() function, the kernel clears the signal handlers because they are not valid in the new address space.  The vulnerability is due to rfork(RFPROC|RFSIGSHARE), which shares the signal handlers between parent and child processes.  If the child process performs an exec() on a setuid program and then the parent process subsequently sets a signal handler, the signal handler is replicated in the child process.  The address of the signal handler may therefore be available in the environment, so sending a signal to the child process may result in the shared signal handler being executed by the child process.
Impact': A local user can obtain root level privileges on the system.
Solution: Upgrade to the fixed version or apply the patch, as described in the Source Message.

Title: (Exploit Code is Provided) Re: FreeBSD Kernel May Allow Local Users to Obtain Root Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): All released versions of FreeBSD 4.x, FreeBSD 4.3-STABLE prior to July 9, 2001
Description:
Georgi Guninski reported a signal handler vulnerability in the FreeBSD kernel that may allow local users to obtain root level privileges.
Exploit code is provided in the Source Message.  For details on the vulnerability, refer to the Message History.
Impact': A local user can obtain root level privileges on the system.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Message History or the Vendor URL for information about the fix.

Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
